I can imagine a speedbus being a new form of transportation.  It can have its own lane or tracks, and go as fast or faster than a train.
I can imagine an self-driving car company with a lot of cars. You would use an app on your phone like Uber. The car would automatically leave the lot and come pick you up.

I can imagine my neighborhood having a high speed maglev train. It will levitate on top of a rail that will span around the entire city to avoid traffic. It will be fast and efficient to provide good transportation services.
I can see a series of tubes where people can step out of their house and dial in a destination and be delivered there instantaneous.  All travel will be tracked via a smartphone or implanted device.

I can see a transport type system where someone steps on a pad and it transport them digitally over to where they want to go within a town. kinda like the thing they had in willy wonkas chocolate factory but without the death ray pointer thing it would be just a pad like a dance dance revolution pad.
I can use the battery bike to avoid the air pollution in my home town

I could imagine single rider tram cars. The cars would be tethered to cables above the streets. Something akin to ski lift carriage, but completely enclosed in glass. Advantage would be thy could run off electric current and would reduce ground street traffic
I could see a trolley style system that ran on solar panels so that there would be no wires hanging.

I don't anticipate the transportation system changing too much in my area no matter the time frame. I think the car will rule for the next several decades, but I would like the cars to change. They need not be so huge, and would be powered by plug-in type electrical engines. Each home would have a solar array and this would power your home, and your car. A back-up natural gas power plant would help out if it's cloudy for weeks. Cars would be there for longer trips, but I would also like to see normal bicycle travel increase in the small city I live in. People are fat, lazy, and gross. We don't need anymore technology to go 100 yards, just less lazy people.
I doubt I would take a bus but having them as an option would help some people
I envision a new transportation system where we use old school busses to transport people to work.  The busses should be turned into green vehicles electric, hybrid or the like.
I feel like there could be a uber shuttle, sort of like a train system.

I feel that in the future there will be futuristic cars that will slowly evolve away from gasoline use more natural resources for fuel.  I think that the cars will continue to evolve into more sustainable, aerodynamic shapes and designs.
I feel the best is a transportation tunnel.  It should run around 150 miles per hour and provide food accommodations as well as sleeping areas!

I get out of my house and before I leave my apartment on my 12th floor I just press a button on my app on my phone to type a location of the place i need to go.This would in turn contact all local data base systems of GPS based transport systems irrespective of the vendors available or government supported transport systems which include Cabs,Buses,Trains,Subway,3 Wheelers and most importantly assuming the people of the future will care a lot more about the environment and all the people who are going alone in a 5 seater car would have a option of sharing there carbon footprint left by the vehicle.And if the co-ordinates of the person with the car and the co-ordinates of the Person who is using the app matches then a Random Unique (one time use)Number or Picture or Anything which would be visible from atleast 10 feet away on a Min 6 inch screen.However this interface can be avoided by tracking the dots on the GPS system or by sending a snap shot of the car number or a photo of the person himself which will be destroyed automatically by the system once the person is down from the Vehicle.Punch Line Before I get to the main gates of the apartment.I should have the list of Vehicles available to me and the time it would take the vehicle to reach my place based on GPS and traffic conditions and also how much time would it take to reach my destination again based on real time traffic conditions and also most importantly.if i take  the public transport system.How much time would it take to reach the same destination and also how much Carbon foot print would i save from doing it.And also the time required by the vehicle to reach the local transport systems if it is not a walkable distance.There are many more ,But i think that is enough for the day.

GIVE THE CUSTOMER ALL THE POSSIBLE OPTIONS OF COMMUTING WITH THE CARBON FOOTPRINT AND THE COST AND THE TIME INVOLVED IRRESPECTIVE OF THE VENDOR OR GOVERNMENT SYSTEMS...
I have an idea of using only one big bus for our entire residence association

I have no problem visualizing a new mode of transportation in my neighborhood. Years ago coal trains ran behind my house and the old gully is still there where the tracks were. Would love to see them back again, but it will never happen.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

I have seen a lot on the news lately about 'self-driving' cars, and I think it would be neat if this technology could someday be applied to public transportation. I think 'self driving' buses would be an excellent mode of transportation. I think this would be particularly useful for smaller cities or towns that can't afford to have subway systems. Self driving buses could be programmed to stop at every stop timely and efficiently and could save the city money by eliminating the need to hire drivers and would cut out the issue of human error when it comes to being on time, not showing up for work, or causing accidents.
I hope to see people in flying vehicles in my neighborhood in the future. I would also like to see more amphibious vehicles.
I imagine a hot air balloon attached to cables that direct it at a low altitude to various stops. people get can out on platforms that they bring you to the ground with elevators.

I imagine a kind of moving walkway in the sky.  The moving walkway would be built on stilts above the ground. An individual can hop on the moving walkway and can walk to another part of the city, but at a faster rate than normal walking. This would encourage taking our own two feet as transportation.

I imagine a loop in my city where anyone would be able to have a short walk to the 'main artery' and be able to get anywhere at a major point within minutes; perhaps this would be a rail suspended above the city, or otherwise away from other major traffic; it would really help in efficiency of moving people around.
I imagine a magnetic public hovercraft system that goes to individual homes on a grid.
I imagine a railway system that goes through my town and all around the united states. It would be a bullet train like they have in europe that hovers and goes fast. It would be affordable too.

I imagine a series of widening arches or loops of roadway and of several different sizes to accompany different types of pubic transport. Cars wouldn't be allowed in the city but stored at various exit point garages which would be provided by the city. Small roads would have small shuttles, large roads would have large fast moving shuttles that span the city. Independently, smaller walkways would be used for pedestrians and cyclists (and other man powered or tiny engine machines.) Larger walkways could become festival street fair type roads that are common in places like Greece.

I imagine a taxi speed boat that could take you downtown in a matter of minutes. It will help skip all the traffic on the street and cut your time in half. Perfect for people who live by bodies of water and are in a rush like NYC.
I imagine a train line that rings the entire city, with interstitial lines to service the downtown areas.
I imagine a train system that runs parallel to the street but is separated from it, unlike a streetcar. It could be elevated from the terrain when necessary to cross over obstacles.

I imagine a transportation system in which we all use underground super chutes. They move us from place to place within our town super fast. It would have to be set up so everything is safe of course. I imagine a network of these chutes spreading throughout the city and they pop you up wherever you want to go. Wouldn't that be amazing?

I imagine a type of highway for bicycles where people can use on and off ramps easily to reach their destination. They wont have to worry about cars since its a bike only highway system. it will get people to their destination quicker since they dont have to stop at traffic lights and watch out for pedestrians.

I imagine a type of hybrid car/rail system that are not owned by individuals.  A person would schedule a pickup to go to work and one home.  The cars would keep circulating picking up and dropping off people all day.  There would be much lesser need for personal parking as well.

I imagine a way to ride a school bus to various spots on its route. You would be pre-screened as an adult who could act as a school bus monitor and at the same time gain transportation to a location near the school. It would solve the problem of kids riding unsupervised and give another public transportation option in the neighborhood.

I imagine an electric trolley like those old school ones, but it would be a hybrid system instead and people could hang off the back and ride it. There would be electronic pass cards that everyone could swipe on and off and it would be subsidized so anyone could use it for super cheap.
I imagine hover bikes in the future, powered by solar energy.
I imagine people using hoverboards and personal flying vehicles for transportation in the future. Personal helicopters specifically and hoverboards similar to the ones in back to the future.
I imagine that instead of transporting with cars we could turn all the roads in our neighborhood into rivers and use boats to get to places.

I live in a chicago suburb and I believe that driverless cars are the future.  But what I actually prefer is everyone driving their own vehicle, what i actually hope happens in the future is that licenses are much harder to get...there are so many people out there with no clue of the rules of the road and it is hazardous to everyone around them.

I live in a fairly small town that has a decent amount of people but isn't very large in area. Solar powered railcars could be a viable option for this area. They would only have to travel short distances at once, and it could easily be utilized by everybody in town by having just a few stops. Think about the railcars in San Francisco and other major cities being completely solar powered. The electricity saving would be huge.

I live in a neighborhood near an excellent metro system, but not walkable to it. I would like a people-mover sort of system that travels through the neighborhood making the existing metro station more accessible. Perhaps small cars or pods at the end of each street that travel along an elevated rail directly to the metro station.

I live in a pretty population dense area where most things people need (like a hospital, a big job center, homes, grocery store) are pretty close to each other.  I think this set up begs for a monorail.  It would be elevated so wouldn't interfere with current traffic too much, but would provide a nice transportation system for people to take for short trips.

I live in a rural area and a lot of people have horses- so an uber or lyft but actually with horses! If you are a nw rider, you can be on a horse on a lead rope, and if you have experience, you can just rent the horse!
I live in a rural area so horseback travel, hay wagon travel and buckboard travel may well be decent substitutes for cars and buses presently being used.

I live in a rural area, it's pretty hilly but it runs along the length of a valley. It would be really nice to have a walking/bike path that connects the residential neighborhood to the commercial district without having the bike/walk on the road. Although it's generally slow traffic, walking on the road is never exactly safe. Especially in the winter. To be able to network together the few towns in the valley too would be very nice.

I live in a rural community about 1 hour from a city. I would like to see this area build a light rail commuter line that could link these isolated communities and boost the economy. Many people out here do not even have cars.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

I live in a small town so I think the future transportation system in my neighborhood will be to get rid of normal sized roads and create bike and walking paths all over town. I can see the current roads changing to smaller lanes made for electric vehicles while most of the transportation needs will be fulfilled with bike and walking paths and personal hoverboard type of transportation.

I live in a small village.  Everything is close together, so it might be possible to have a bicycle share program.  Bicycles could be borrowed and then returned to the same place or a different place.  This would allow people to get around without using cars.
I live in a snowy climate, so there are a lot of times that we can't drive our cars anywhere because of all the snow. So a snowmobile taxi might work.

i live in a somewhat smaller town in rural virginia. everything is super accessible and easy to get to. our town is gold cart friendly. my idea would be a cab service, but with golf carts. it would be a super fun way to help people get from point A to point B. it would also encourage safer driving.

I live in a town right on the ocean and there are many canals here. I think a canoe taxi service would be really convenient and fun. It wouldn't get people to their desired locations super fast but it would allow people to travel leisurely and enjoy the scenery along the way. It would also be really healthy for the people driving the canoes and help them to stay fit.

I live in a town with a lot of freight trains. A subway system would be nice because it would get us places faster (the town is large in size and spread out over several miles) and be able to bypass the trains, which stop constantly. The subway would run either over the existing trains or under them and run off of cards that were prepaid like the MTAs.

I live in a very hilly neighborhood. I suggest a funicular! A funicular is a railway built on a steep hill with tram cars for transport. Put it on one of the hills in the center of the neighborhood. People would be only a short walk (less than 10 minutes), hop on the funicular and it could take them to the church, the school and the neighborhood business district. Bam. No more worrying about going up and down the crazy hills, especially in the winter. Booyah!

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.
I live in an area where horses are abundant. It would be a trip if everyone started using their horse instead of a car or motorcycle.

I live in an area where there are a lot of senior citizens so driving can sometimes be scary, and I think this city would greatly benefit from public transportation. However, I think something that would benefit the environment would be the most helpful, so I think pushcarts would be a lot of fun, or even horse drawn carriages. Not only would these be better for the environment, but I think the older people would appreciate the old-fashioned nature of such public transport systems.
I live in las vegas and I think that the tram should go from the airport to the strip and all the way down to fremont street.

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

I live in the suburbs so all the rail lines converge on the central city. It would be nice if there was a light rail system that linked the different major suburbs together. You could connect it to the lines going to the city and across the country.

i live in twin falls idaho and we could use a bus line, i guess it isn't a new idea  but yeah this is a place where there is sharp economic divide and all the businesses are on the rich side of town, the original town or the poor side of town "old town" is roughly a mile from the main drag so buses would be great for people who cant afford cars and better for the environment in general

I live near the water, so water transportation would be nice to have. It could be a system of ferries that can go from port to port, carrying passengers like a bus system. This would reduce the amount of cars on the road and the amount of traffic.

I live on an army base. There are hundreds of vehicles that just sit around and collect rust, and it would be wonderful if the military could find some way to rent these vehicles out to the public. This would create income for individual units and help add to their budget, as well as providing vehicles to civilians who need them and even potentially drawing in interested persons who would otherwise never have driven a military vehicle.

I lived in Japan and really enjoyed their system of underground rail. I think most cities in the United States could benefit from such a system, which has the added benefit of cutting down on DUIs. There is no rail system in my town.

I often thought that a sort of ski lift-type system would work well to carry people from my neighborhood to downtown.  You would board a continuously running chair on wire, and then would be transported to a downtown station riding on the chair over the city. Would take ten minutes max to board and 10-15 minutes to go downtown.

I picture a brand new train system, going down the main street, with street cars going leading up to the main street.   I would love to see it being a high speed system, paying with your fingerprints.   It would be similar to a credit card.

I picture a streamlined 'box' like a cable car that is hanging from a line or track throughout the city. It would be shaped like a rectangle with smooth edges and very compact and sleak. It glides up to the booth where people may get on and each cable car 'box' can hold 6 people in 3 rows of 2 with a small walking aisle to the side.

I propose a motorcyle service that goes and fetches small items on demand (diapers, over the counter medicines, dinner supplies). I think this would be very useful for senior citizens and families with young children or single people who dont feel well.

I propose a truly revolutionary idea.  Personal sky paths.  It is about time we had highways in the sky to combat our now crowded roadways.  Added safety measures would be put in place like mandatory parachutes for civilian travel.

I propose an idea that would rely on strong wire much like telephone wire that would be used to support a small train carriage like car or pod.  I see this as being better than a railway as it would be not as expensive to implement.
I see a solar powered trolley going around the neighborhood.

I see a totally different way of transportation in the future. I see solar a powered tram replacing all the buses and since the cost is so much lower there will be many more of them so you can get anywhere you want to go anytime. In addition to the in city tram there will be a super high speed solar powered train that can go 150 mph or more! That will make it so what used to be a 2 hour drive or more will now be a short train ride away. For those who do not want to take the tram there will be an unmanned flying drone taxi. All you do it either tell it your destination or input the location yourself and it automatically takes you there.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I see the potential for self-driving cars to replace taxi services. People would call an automated line, or perhaps interact with a site/app on their computers/phones, to schedule to be picked up by the service. Meanwhile, a network that keeps track of all self-driving cars in its region would figure out which car was closest or would have to deviate the least to pick up the passenger within 5-10 minutes of being hailed. These cars could be compartmentalized to hold four or six passengers without individuals having to worry about undesired contact with the other passengers. The cars could run on electricity and the network would consider battery life with regards to planning routes and destinations.

I think a bullet train would be very useful. A train that can transport passengers fast in between the major areas in the neighborhood, for example to schools, the downtown area, the performing arts theater, shopping districts, the airport etc. It doesn't have to stop very often like a bus but an instead be used for getting between major areas and can be supported by the bus system.

I think a drone transport system that would carry people, good and other items would be a great service.  An even better idea is if was peer run, meaning run by people in your neighborhood, and all the profits would be split.

I think a form of public transportation could be an electric type of subway that runs on a non intrusive track layed into the pavment much like a train track. It could be shaped like a normal subway but on the roof space there would be solar panels to generate electricity needed to run. Any remaining power needed could be provided by the tracks.

I think a good idea will be to use electric cycles instead of a bike or a car in metros. They not only help in decreasing pollution as well as motivating people towards physical exercises.



A proper network of e cycles and connected to a main frame can be seen as a new transportation system emerging. Moreover this can also be used as a public transportation system by constructing cycle stands where they can be charged and the cost of public transport can be paid in the machine.

I think a good idea will be to use electric cycles instead of a bike or a car in metros. They not only help in decreasing pollution as well as motivating people towards physical exercises.



A proper network of e cycles and connected to a main frame can be seen as a new transportation system emerging. Moreover this can also be used as a public transportation system by constructing cycle stands where they can be charged and the cost of public transport can be paid in the machine.

I think a good idea will be to use electric cycles instead of a bike or a car in metros. They not only help in decreasing pollution as well as motivating people towards physical exercises.



A proper network of e cycles and connected to a main frame can be seen as a new transportation system emerging. Moreover this can also be used as a public transportation system by constructing cycle stands where they can be charged and the cost of public transport can be paid in the machine.

I think a great idea for a transportation system would be a neighborhood or city that bans cars and uses all bikes to get around. This would really help the environment and people in this town would also be in really good shape. It would have to be a town that doesn't get very cold in the winter, like where I live, where people could use their bikes comfortably year round. Each bike would have to have a small basket though for people to carry their stuff.

I think a great idea within my neighborhood would basically to have a moving sidewalk like you would find at an airport.  This would allow people to move about faster than maybe they would walking, so people wouldn't feel the need to get in the car to go down the block to the store.

I think a method that would improve the transportation system would be to change how turn lanes are handled in America. Overseas, to turn left, you veer off to a lane on the right that comes to a stop so that you don't block traffic waiting to turn and then when it is clear, you drive across the street onto the road you were going to turn onto.

I think a monorail system or cable cars like you see on ski lifts would be quite useful. moving walkways enclosed in a plastic tunnel to protect from elements that would have heat or a/c depending on the season would be really cool as well.

I think a new transportation that utilizes a type of rail system on the sidewalks that people can easily easily walk throughout the neighborhood - similar to the moving walkways at airports.  Sort of like a conveyor belt for people.

I think a private school bus would be a great idea. Maybe it could be the size of a SUV and fit maybe 4 to 6 kids in it comfortable. Some kids are not able to take a bus to school so parents have to take public transportation every morning to drop them off. It could be like a Uber school bus sort of, each SUV bus will have certain school on their route that they can drop kids off at.

I think a spiral starting from the center of the city going out to the edges of the city.  The spiral should be able to get all the areas if it's only 2-3 blocks wide.  It would have a dedicated lane so traffic wouldn't affect the bus and vice versa.  There would be a way to quickly have people enter and exit the bus and this would keep it on time.  Of course the bus is electric powered.
I think a trolley system would work really well here. I live in Fort Collins and the city is very centralized but the traffic is terrible - perfect for a trolley!

I think a van that picks people up when the driver knows that person needs a ride because it is dark or they don't have a vehicle would be nice. The van would be wide enough to hold at least twenty people. It would be low maintenance. It would get good gas mileage. It would be comfortable.

I think adding a rail system in my city would be a great idea. The only public transportation we have is buses and there are a lot of areas they don't even run to. So I think a rail system would do wonders in getting a lot of other people where they were going.
I think an automatic bus, possibly on a rail system so the times would be more predictable and rigorous.

I think automated cars that work like taxis would be great.  They would have short range ones and long ranges ones.  Also, larger ones that go on busy commute routes each day to and from work.  With them being automated everything would be faster and run more efficiently.
I think because my city isn't THAT big a place that takes us to all the the important parts is vital. You would think a bus would do that but not the ones in my city. It's just small stops.

I think driverless taxi services are going to be the dominant transportation systems in the future. Sort of like having a whole bunch of Uber drivers out there picking up whoever needs it. I don't think that vehicle ownership will be nearly as widespread as it is these days, as driverless cars will be far safer.

I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. The entire system could be above street level. The speed would be about 5 mph with platforms every block.

I think freelance carpooling would be a great idea. Vehicle owner can at any time turn themselves into a taxi service. The service can be run through a phone app, workers can set their own hours and rates. This would cut down on pollution, eliminate unnecessary vehicles on the road, and boost the economy overall.
I think having a streetcar system would be amazing, it could be automated to accept fares, and would provide safe transportation for all.

I think high-speed tube travel would be great in my city. The tubes could be a system of plastic or rubber tubes that were buried underground. There would be a lot of tube stations downtown, but they would branch off to the outer city and suburbs. These tubes would have pods in them that were propelled by high-pressured air. The pods could be designed to carry one or two people each, and would be shot through the tubes for quick travel to your destination.
I think if we had automatic cars that you could order from your smart phone when you wanted it.
I think it should be a tunnel that everyone gets in and you press a button to where you wanna go and it will take you there in a flash.

I think it would be cool if there were kisoks you could rent bicycles from.  Maybe put a gps tracker inside of them so people didn't try to steal them, or give people back part of their deposit when they returned the bike to another kisok.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.
I think my neighborhood and the surrounding city could use some sort of collection of energy efficient trams that can network passengers along the old railways that are no longer in use.
I think my neighborhood could benefit from ride-sharing bikes. We live in a suburb of Boston but technically a City. Not the easiest to get around and a lot to do.

I think my neighborhood would benefit from one of those pedal bike bars for the downtown area. There is a lot of history and what better way to enjoy it than while sipping a nice drink and getting some exercise

I think teleportation would be awesome. Wouldn't need cars anymore, save on oil and fumes in the environment. People would be happier because they wouldn't be stuck in traffic or have to drive hours to see long distance family members.

I think that a cool new transportation system would be a bike that we all pedal. It would be a long bike, maybe 5-8 seats long on each side. It would start with one rider who will then ride to other people's houses to pick others up. They would get on the bike and start peddling to pick the next person up.

I think that a new mod of transportation in my neighborhood would be a electric bike taxi system. It would be an electric bike pulling a carriage that hold up to 3 other people. The system will travel from people's houses to their work place, local shopping centers and local entertainment places.
I think that a trolly system would work well in phoenix.  They would run frequently, be smaller than a bus and go into more neighborhoods.

I think that an interesting mode of transport in my mountain town would be a ski lift type system that runs behind the businesses on main street and stops at every corner. The reason for this is our huge lack of parking and the congestion that cars cause in the shopping district. It would be unusual and fun and it could connect to the large parking area at the convention center.
I think that community cars that attribute to car pooling would be wonderful.

I think that one cool idea is to have personal transportation that allows you to connect with other people in your area so you can rideshare and also carpool or get a ride when needed. Instead of using like Craigslist to ask for rideshare or ask if people are willing to pick  them up, you use an app. People can sign into this app and then say which direction they are going. Along the way you can request that person pick you up to get you from A to B...kind of like hitchhiking through a mobile app.

I think that public buses should have some type of bike rack on the back of the bus. Some people want to take their bikes with them somewhere but the place is to far to bike the whole way.  The can chain their bike to the bike rack and remove it when they get off the bus. Of course space would be limited to about 2-3 bikes.

I think that some sort of charging commuter car should be parked in every neighborhood. People could coordinate commute times and use electric cars instead of gas, in exchange they pay $1 a day to drive the car per person.
I think that there could be a light rail system or electric buses. there is enough sunlight to make them 100% clean
I think that there should be a way to get bugs off a windshield without harming the paint job on a car.  It should be a spray while you are driving much like windshield wiper fluid
I think that there should be some way that all the christmas trees at the end of the season could be recycled into some sort of useful wood.
I think that we need a rail system for our city. Its a growing city with lost of bigger cities around it. A main rail system like a subway would make things much easier to get from place to place.

I think the idea of rickshaws are a good one.  But in most places, like cities or suburban areas with hills, a traditional rickshaw wouldn't be practical.  I think that a bike with an electric motor and a cab on the back would be a good solution.  It's nicer for the environment and a more personal connection than a taxi.  Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.
I think there should be bikes that you can easily rent. You can get them in the major shopping areas and drive them around town to get excercise as well as helping to use less gasoline.

I think there should be free neighborhood circulators that stop at significant shopping centers, landmarks, or services, that run throughout the day. I think they should be brightly colored bus-like vehicles.

I think there should be personal pods that can ride on train lines and trolley tracks.  These can be bought or rented.  They can follow the train or trolley and then be parked.  It could alleviate a congested train at rush hour.

I think we could bring back the streetcar in queens where the subway has low coverage. The streetcar would connect to the subway system which would be entirely rebuilt to accommodate new clean stations with solar panels and zero carbon foot print. This would connect with commuter and regional trains that would operate on an hourly scale.

I think we could have carpool vans that schedule drop offs for us in the city which could save gas and promote a green clean transportation system. Also, we could take turns as drivers, with GPS equipped and a convertible top for sunny days.

I think we need a greener alternative to the uber/lyft types of services. Perhaps an app that connects you to bike and rickshaw drivers. Like an uber or lyft for rickshaws. I took a cycle rickshaw after a music festival this summer and it was great. Took a while to get to the destination but it felt really cool to get a ride from a biker.

I think we need to tap into the power of magnets.  We can use solar panels all through the roads, then use them to power magnets on the road.  The vehicles will have oppositely polarized magnets that will be controllable in the car.  I guess it will work like those trains that use magnets, but someone smart will figure out a way to control the magnets independently.  The car battery will power the magnet on the car, and can be shut off immediately once the power is cut in case of emergency.

I think we should focus on making it easier for people to bike around the area. We need to widen sidewalks and/or have separate paths just for pedestrians and bikers. Oftentimes, the bike lanes are narrow or end abruptly.

I think we should have a system like Uber set up here. Allow individuals to "sign up" to be drivers at the town and people can book rides via the net, text messaging, or by calling. I think this should be tax-exempt income because then the town has no issue with gas or any other expenses because it makes this more profitable to retired people or others who can't work. With the way free market works we would almost always have enough drivers!
I think we should have more and cheaper car sharing.  And use electric cars.

I think we should incentivize walking. Tax breaks for people who walk to/from work. Discounts offered by businesses if you walk to their store. Municipalities will save by not needing to pave/upkeep roads. Less impermeable surfaces mean less runoff to deal with, etc etc. Sometimes the best innovation is redeploying the simplest of technologies...
I thinking of transportation that you can transport yourself through your mind.  It would be through dreams that are real.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.
I visualize a car ride sharing phone application in which people put in the destination that they want to go to and they can connect with people going that same direction for a ride.

I want a large, underground series of tunnels that offer a combination of walking paths, bike paths, and people movers so that people can easily move around the city during winter. As this would have a large number of entrances and exists, it would be more flexible (and cheaper) than the subway.

I want a monorail system to run above street level (may be 20 feet up or so).  I want it to connect the suburbs to downtown, and circle the city.  It would run on magnets so that it would be extremely quiet.  It would be extremely fast.  I want it to provide a bird's eye view for commuters.  It would be a very safe way to travel, crime and personal safety would not be an issue.
I want a way to fly by myself to where I want without having to control it

I want an elevated railway that preserves nature, resists going down during snow and bad weather, and reaches all areas of my city. It would be public transportation and have low-cost monthly passes. It would also run on renewable, clean energy.
I want one of those teletransporter things that zaps you from one spot to the next

I want to see the Chicagoland suburbs connected by a train. Most often if they are, it's because they're on the same line going to Chicago, but I'd like to see a system that moves between suburbs that aren't connected on the train line.

I was thinking of underground tunnels that you could access from certain points -- not for a subway. Instead, you get in the tunnels and you have the option to take various tunnels to certain destinations using your preferred mode of transportation: razor scooter, roller-blades, running/walking. You can check out a scooter at an entrance, drop it off at your destination. that way you never have to bring it with you, the entrances would have them on hand. or you can just run/walk if you want and it would be out of the cold/hot/rain/snow/sun, etc...

I was thinking that since the city I live in has a decently sized river, to save money, be cost effective, and lower power/energy usage, we can ferry people and personnel to central districts of the city and my neighborhood. Maybe the ferries/boat could be turbine powered to be more energy efficient.

I wish my neighborhood had a giant conveyor belt for going to all the main places downtown.  It would help the older people as well be convenient.  It would have to be waterproof and covered.  It could run all along the one side of the main intersections without ever having to cross.

I wish we could get treadmill bikes. I saw a quick video of one invented in the U.K. I think. You walk on it and that powers a motor so you can move quickly even if you are just walking. We have many runners and walkers in our city, but only on trails or parks. If you could use them on the streets to actually get places it would be wonderful. You would also have to add some sort of safe parking places so they don't get stolen as I'm not sure you can lock them up.

I wish we had a monorail between the airport and our city. We aren't connected to any public transportation system, but more than 70% of our residents travel by plane more than once a year. Many people travel for work, etc. Rather than each of us driving and paying to park our cars there, if we could stay in our suburb and take the monorail (or train) to and from it would save a great deal of money and time.

I wish we had separate bicycle highways that were enclosed spaces, both heated and cooled for summer/winter. It would be a cheaper mode of transportation. There would be protection to prevent car vs bicycle accident, a major problem in our area. It would also be healthier and exercise for the day during a commute. I picture it being a rounded space that is clear so you can see your surroundings outside.
I would create a bicycle rental system that was accessible to wheelchair. Pittsburgh created rental bicycles, but they left out disabled adults.
I would enjoy having a limousine service in the neighborhood. That would be a safe and comfortable mode of transportation.
i would enjoy seeing horses as a way of public transportation more often
I would go with a moped service.  There would just be mopeds position around town and you have to drop it off at your stop to check out.
I would have the Metro system extended further into Virginia to lessen the commute time.  I would also call for train stations that were more accessible and uses solar energy predominantly.

I would imagine a combination of Uber and self-driving cars. I can imagine a world where I don't own a car. Instead, I click a button on an app on my phone, and an automated car shows up shortly after, taking me wherever I need to go.

I would imagine a monorail type of situation.  With frequent stops around the neighborhood so everyone was able to get on relatively near their home.  It would move quickly and make stops at the nearby schools and stores.
I would imagine a street car type system that would connect each neighborhood.

I would imagine an electric scooter or hoverboard rental system.  You could use them when going to and from a train station stop and to your final destination.  I imagine a rental system so that you could pick one up at a train or bus station to go your extra distance and return it when you return.  Renting would be a good option if you did not have your own with you or only use it with other public transportation. Bad weather is always an issue using these devices.
I would l to see a system of transportation where the service would do home pickups,similar to a bus, only the stops would be made at your home regularly for a monthly or yearly fee.
I would like a car that can maneuver around slow people and even change shape when theres little room to maneuver, so I can get to work on time!

I would like a city trolley. The trolley would travel around the city several times a day, taking and picking up residents from the major shopping areas. The trolley stops should be no more than two blocks from any neighborhood.
I would like a free car sharing service.  So the city provides cars, but that can only be used if they are full, so that you have an incentive to carpool, and as long as you do, you get a free ride.
I would like a golf cart system that could get the kids to school on the paths, kind of like a bus system but on a much smaller scale.
I would like a non-gas mode of transportation to be created for our area such as a horse drawn carriage where the horses are treated really well but they also go fast and get us where we need to go.
I would like a taxi like system that doesn't charge so high.
I would like a teleporting system that can instantly take you from place to place

I would like an interchangeable form of light rail, in which the train would have several compartments that would be destined for multiple locations. That way you just get on the train, and the train goes to an interchange. At the interchange the compartments are separated (I imagine they are held together by magnets) and grouped together by location. Once all the compartments that are going to the same area are together, the train leaves. It would work like changing trains, except you wouldn't have to go outside.

I would like for a train to be in my neighborhood.   IT would go right down the sides of our main streets.   There is a train currently, but you have to drive far to it.   There should be more trains, not just one or two.
I would like for there to be a trolley/tram system through main street in my town. Main street goes straight through Beaver Dam and Hartford and passes by all the important stores/stops.
I would like it if the area I lived in used a bike sharing system like I have seen in some other major cities like Portland and Minneapolis.

I would like our city to have a railway system like downtown Miami. Its computer operated and is over ground. This means it wont impact traffic at all. Its a fast and easy service and its going to make things easier for all.

I would like some sort of conveyor belt system or moving walkway (possibly with seats) in my city. It seems like it would be really nice for people, since people walk a lot here. Also, if there was a way to sit while moving, people could get work done and other things, while taking a 'slow ride' down the street (slower than a train, etc, so people can get on/ off while it's moving).

I would like there to be a fast speed rail such as in Japan or Germany. I picture it being accurate time-wise and capable of transporting people over great distances. I would prefer it to a bus situation.

I would like to have a subterranean network of moving roller coaster type tracks that move people to any location in the city easily, and deliver them right to the door step of where they need to go. This could be done by having exit points from the underground network of tracks that bring you to specific address clusters.
I would like to have small trams throughout the county, making it more convenient for people to travel from city to city without stopping

I would like to imagine being able to create a app and that uses credit cards. and invent a motorcycle scooter that has a huge row of seats in the back and runs like a mini van and use it as a taxi service. for only the city that I live in and name it Go Scooter transportation.
I would like to see a  people mover like in Detroit or Miami.

I would like to see a bicycle highway.  It would go the length of regular highways, but be for bikes and pedestrians.  It should be wide enough for fast moving road cyclist, it should have passing lanes, and little road crossings.  There should be frequent on and off ramps.  There should also be many large parking areas.  Ideally it would even lead to public transportation areas with ample bike parking.

I would like to see a cable car that runs across the city.  It would take people across the busy streets.  It would be convenient for office workers. It would cut down on traffic in the downtown area.
I would like to see a commuter bus with complete wifi access, as well as office equipment available.

I would like to see a high speed train connect all the major cities in my state as well as the major cities bordering our state.  I envision this high speed train to have minimal stations.  This would eliminate the need for air travel and long road trips.
I would like to see a hover system that occupies the same route as roads and highways to bypass traffic.

I would like to see a modern underground railway system installed in my neighbourhood. It would be noiseless and very fast. The railway will connect all the neighbourhood together making it easier to move around. The train would be making stops every half hour  to pick up and drop passengers.

I would like to see a People Mover connecting Trenton, Southgate, Taylor and Wyandotte. There seems to be a lot of people walking down streets such as Trenton and Eureka, and especially so in the winter. I can envision a rail system supported by local tax dollars very similar to the one to the north in Detroit. People around here are constantly complaining about weather conditions and global warming and I think my method could bring a lot of people together and solve a lot of the commuting problems around here. There are just so many cars and it seems there is an average of just 1.5 people per vehicle. It is rather said. I really would want to push toward the people mover rail systems.

I would like to see a public transportation system, funded by the government and running non-stop.  Possibly employing people in an uber style privately owned vehicle service.  Or some car pool ideas.

I would like to see a short-term car rental service with semi-autonomous driving. For example, if I needed to go to the airport and didn't want to leave my current car in a parking lot their I could rent a car that I could summon with a smartphone app. The car would be able autonomously drive directly to me or a location I choose through the app. After I was at the location of my choosing and no longer needed the car, I could then use the app to send the car away.
I would like to see a solar powered train system

I would like to see a system built around "people movers" - similar to the ride that was once at Disneyland.  It would run underneath the ground - under the traffic.  Each car would hold one or two people with large reclining chairs and a docking station for your laptop so you can watch movies, play games or actually do work.

I would like to see a system of localized automated delivery. A system which is run as a utility for the town or city in which the focus is put on small businesses in the area. I think this could have hyper-local economic benefits, as it may help small businesses steal back sales from online marketplaces like Amazon. I see it being a motorized electric drone, that could use something like a bike lane to bring goods to local neighborhoods from small businesses in area.  it Could be coupled with a publicly run website for ordering and added revenues from ad placement on site and/or vehicles could help give money back to towns and cities.
I would like to see a system that would be quicker for pickups and drop offs. This would mean vehicles similar to busses but smaller and more efficient.
I would like to see a transportation system that can be used for professional reasons, or personal, but not both.

I would like to see all self driving cars, driving at top speeds because human error and crashes have been removed from the equation. So everyone can get to their destination five, maybe ten times as fast, without a significant infrastructure overhaul.

I would like to see an advanced transportation system that involved driverless cars.  The idea is the same as using a taxi but without a driver.  Like Uber, you would use your mobile device to order a car and control the experience.  The car shows up at your door, takes you to your destination and you are billed for the ride. It would save me thousands of dollars in the cost to own, maintain, insure and license my own personal car.
I would like to see an expanded light rail system with more of a neighborhood connection.  Right now our light rail pretty much just connects the Downtown core with the airport.

I would like to see jetpacks so people can go long distances in a short amount of time without relatively much traffic. The cost would hopefully be relatively cheap as well once they were mass produced.
I would like to see lightrail or street cars inbny neighbor hood.   Something that was powered in part by alternative energy.  Solar panels on the stations, perhaps on top of the light rail cars.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.
I would like to see my city connected via a light rail system which would greatly reduce traffic and emissions.  I envision the majority of neighborhoods in the Downtown core being connected.

I would like to see public transportation on buses expanded in my area, with a dedicated area for bicycles to also be transported on the buses.  This would help a lot with traffic, and still allow people to get to their destinations quickly.
I would like to see rocket skates as a transportation method. They might need something to help people keep balance but they would be fun to use and practical for some peoples lifestyle.
I would love a rail system to be installed in our city going north/south along the coast.

I would love for there to a more intergrated train system in my city (specifically my neighborhood.) I'd love to be able to hop on a train (or streetcar) and be able to transfer to a larger rail system that would take me to other cities, etc. Something like what european cities have.

I would love if my neighborhood had a rail system that worked from magnets and floated along the rail at high speeds.  I wish that the cars were individual and that I could get in and select from a list of destinations.  I would like my own car and to be able to bring my dogs with me.  It would be fast and smooth and work with minimal power.

I would love individual Segway transporters that would go from the house to the transit station.  They would just fit one person and keep them dry.  Only about 1 mile but just far enough in the rain not to walk.  Once at the transit station, the train takes you directly every 5 minutes into the city.

I would love it if the city made walking and riding a bike more user friendly. There are no areas that are safe for pedestrians or bikers. If there were a bike lane, more people could move independently and get to where they are going. Commuters using more than one mode of transportation would be able to get to their destinations more quickly and with greater safety.

I would love to see a light rail system in my community. I am thinking of above ground trains that would run to the various suburbs and take people to various local stops. These trains should run a regular schedule so people can use them to commute.

I would love to see a social network for people that work for a certain business. This social network would allow you to find rides from other employees that live in your area. Every business would have an account at this website, and employees who want to pick up other employees can volunteer. Maybe a $5 fee per person each week to account for gas money, but it could be like it would tell you who lives within 10 miles from you that works where you do, and you can ride share or carpool with them. It would be almost like a social network where you can talk to other employees you don't know and then you can ride together or take turns driving.

I would love to see an Uber type of program but for doctor appointments. Where the doctor's office has drivers who are willing to pick up patients and drop them back off at home. Maybe like 1 person driving in a city and just bringing the patients to the doctor so that people won't have to drive to the doctor, especially older people.
I would love to see heated sidewalks, so that everyone can walk safely in downtown Pittsburgh safely.
I would love to see more light rail transit added to Pittsburgh to alleviate some of the traffic congestion under ground
I would love to see Pittsburgh, PA use some of unused railroads for light rail service. Many of our existing routes were cut, unfortuantely.

I would love to see some kind of computer-operated taxi service in my city. The roads would be a lot safer of cars weren't being driven by humans, and I feel like people would be a lot more productive. I would love if I could just sit in the backseat and read or do work on my way to work, instead of having to pay attention to the road every second. It would also save money from having to buy a car if I could jsut call one of these taxis whenever I need to go somewhere.

I would love to see the use of self propelled equipment like hover boards and such used to help decrease emissions from cars. Highways and roads could be established just for such travelors. and we would also save money on gas
I would really like to see separate lanes for scooters in my area.  A lot more people are commuting this way, and it would be good if it was a safer way to drive.
I would rent golf carts in the summer to the elderly without cars so they could shop.

I would say the biggest way to improve innovating is to have all new construction be made in regards to current public transporation hub and those that cnanot be require them to build a public transportation hub. So all new communities have bus access or train access.
I would suggest public car rentals funded monthly, with constant access.
I would suggest that there would be bullet train/subway that would rely on solar power/cooking oil/grease. It would connect to all parts of the continent. It would be energy efficient.
I would think a fleet of hovercraft would be amazing.  They wouldnt damage roads like cars and would allow people to get around with a minimum usage of energy.
I wrote a screenplay about bullying and I'm going to have in turn into a comic book and a film.

I'd like to see a subway that has assigned seating.  It'd be nice that you could preorder a seat on the subway for a nominal fee - that seat is yours 100% of the time.   You never have to worry about it being taken.  Other than that, it remains completely the same..just reserved seats.

I'd like to see shuttle trams in my area. It's a small section based urban area that has about four different areas all residents will have to visit at some point in time. If we had a shuttle system that specifically transported people from a central point to the four primary destinations it would incredibly reduce the use of fossil fuels, traffic, and accidents in the area.

I'd like to see some kind of motorcycle rental system in my neighborhood. This would be really convienant and I imagine quite affordable as well. There tends to be a lot of traffic in my area too so this would prevent the roads from becoming too congested. I live in a high tourism area as well and I think this would be more fun for people to explore the city than renting traditional cars.

I'd like to see some sort of autonomous shared fleet of cars that are fueled in some sort of environmentally friendly way. Solar panels on the roof? Maybe bike pedaling inside if you want to exercise and provide a small amount of power? I feel like autonomous cars alone will save a ton of energy just by eliminating traffic jams. And cut down on wind resistance since you wouldn't need to keep the traditional design necessarily.

I'd like to see the combination of a food truck and a taxi. This way you could grab a fresh made bite to eat while on your way to the destination. There would be a seating area in the front and a small kitchen with a service window in the back. This bus could serve hot and cold sandwiches and maybe drinkable soup in cups with lids to prevent spills. Now all you have to do is hail a cab. Forget finding something to eat then looking for the cab. The food can be prepared for you onboard.

I'd like to see the railroad tracks by our house be repurposed as a walking and biking route for the neighborhood.  It would be really sweet if they could use that and carry the corridor all the way to the nearest town and shopping area.

I'd like to see underground travel possible through out the city.   Some massive tunnels, where you would have to take side tunnels to exits, but there would be major arteries.  It would replace a lot of above ground roads.

I'd like to see vehicles that will fly, take up little space on the ground, go up and down more like a helicopter so large parking runways are not needed. These cars would almost fly themselves and need little direction other than where they're going.

I'd love a system that is like Uber but just for cheap, shared rides home from the train. It'd cost less than a buck for everyone and operate as a shuttle for people that live within 5 mins of the train.
I'd love for some sort of shuttle system that worked at late hours between major points in town

I'd love to see a crowdsourced method of alternate transportation in my city, where people could request rides from others who happen to be in the area and going the direction you need to with a minimal cost. There are so many people who have cars and it would be a great option for people who don't have reliable access to one. It could use cell phone apps and perhaps even have a traditional component using telephone for people who are less technologically inclined. The biggest challenge would be safety/security, and I'm honestly not sure how to overcome that aspect. There could be specific stops, almost like bus stops, where people could gather and wait for rides, or schedule rides to pick them up at certain times.

I'd love to see an all-electric option for carpooling at the school where I work. There are 5 families whose children/adults work or attend school at the same place, and we live on the same street. We are about 10 miles from school. We could all ride to school together, charge the vehicle while we are at school, and ride home together.

I'd really like to see a little pod that you could get into.  It has a minor sedative so you can relax on your commute.  A bus or something of the sort would come by and pick up pods which are locked and only you can open.  You hang a sign or type in your wanted destination, and a bus that goes roughly to the area scoops you up.  



Upon getting to your destination, the bus drops you off at a stop, and the sedative wears off with an alarm to wake you up.

I'd use apps and social media so I know the times of all transport.  If it's late, I don't want to hang out too long. An app would pick up my location and show the times of the buses or street car. I could set it to warn me too.

I'm envisioning a system of small feet-sized platforms, along with a handle at arm-height, running on street-level light rail tracks throughout the city. Like an escalator, these continuously run in a loop around the city/neighborhood, and passengers can jump on and off at will. (Access would be prepaid and mediated by a RFID chip card and scanner on the devices.) These would probably move at about 5-10 miles per hour - faster than regular walking, but slower than other forms of transport that require more infrastructure and potential for danger. It'd kinda be like, Razor scooters but built into the city landscape and available at-will. Like a bike-share system, but always there and with no energy or exercise expended. This would be a great way for tired people to avoid walking, and would speed up trips to the closest subway station/bus stop.

I'm imagining a car sharing service with locations throughout the city where you can go pick up a car without having to reserve one in advance. Nor would you have to interact with any people at the pickup/dropoff location. It would be somehow automated. Perhaps you would subscribe to the service an at annual or monthly rate and be given a special kind of 'key' that would give access to any of the cars currently at the pick up location. It would be first come first serve, and there would be smart technology embedded in both the cars and the keys. Your universal key would be linked to your account, and the car you used would transmit all relevant information to the system. Such as , time of pick up. number of miles drive. amount of gas used. Then the fees would be adjusted accordingly based on the type of car you used, miles driven, gas consumed etc. all of this without any human employees and all the fuss that comes with tradiional car rental. Things like insurance and billing info would all be done upfront when a patron sets up an account. This is genius, the more i think about it!

Idea 1 . Semi conductor can be design in such a way that it can be RE-USED.

Idea 2 . Renewable energy - the cost of the solar cells has been going down a lot, the labor to install them hasn't, and that's an area where innovation can help.
If it's a neighboorhood idea, maybe a coordination of volunteers via an app for either ridesharing or being the driver for a day.
If we could all just travel through human sized and safe pods that take us from place to place like the banks vacuum system that would probably be the fastest, safest way.

If we could be so technologically advanced to create giant versions of the airport conveyor belts where humans are carried across, that would be my new method of transportation. Since people are mostly lazy and want something to do the work for them (hence the upcoming popularity of the hands-free segway), this would be perfect to eliminate at least a fourth of the traffic on the street from cars.
If we had taxis in our neighborhood had a rewards card program where you can earn free rides.

Im from Seattle and it is mostly built over the top of the old city that burned down. I would think that they'd be able to build subways here at least through the downtown area where they have underground tours of the city.
Imagine streets that are great for bicycling, walking, taking transit and just for enjoying in our neighborhood
Imagine thousands of public bikes for you to use for short trips around town. Now imagine tens of thousands of people riding these bikes every day
Imagine your favorite night spot looking like First Fridays in Uptownbikes everywhere
Improve the bike lanes while simultaneously passing legislation to give huge tax breaks to people who ride bikes. More people will ride bikes, save more money, burn less fuel, and be more in shape.

In dense urban areas have a series of high tension wires between buildings. Have a  mechanized seat something like a zipline  that people would ride on. This would need a seatbelt or maybe an enclosed capsule for safety but the idea is making the seat as compact as possible .
In many neighborhoods, stop signs are ignored. I believe switching to yield signs, where ideally suitable, is needed and adding 'bus stops' for local schools that do not hinder traffic.

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town. 



One thing that may be neat would be large sidewalks where people could ride bikes/scooters/walk and avoid using a vehicle. The main road is fairly busy, and there are quite a few shops around that would be more accessible if we had better transportation than just getting in a car! (Boardman, OH). Little scooters with solar power charging stations would be neat.

My idea for a new transportation system in my neighborhood is a series of really big tubes, with padding, and occasionally air holes, with mesh filters to prevent bugs and large debris from getting in.  The tubes would be places alongside all the streets, and be at a constant forward vacuum, with enough lessening of suction to allow people to grasp a handle at their stop and get out.   (If you miss your stop, you just ride around until it comes up again, pushing yourself towards the right tube as it comes towards you.)



Collision between travelers would need to be solved, as well as how to clean up any errant body fluids left by travelers; perhaps a daily purge at midnight, where the suction could be increased exponentially and all materials dumped in a pile, on a rotating schedule, on different people's lawns.   



This system has the benefit of a very low carbon footprint, and lends itself well to spontaneous exclamations of 'cowabunga'.  



Implementation note: This idea may require anti-gravity research, in addition to a lot of suction.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

Our society's population is expanding at a rapid rate. The typical modern day modes of transportation, while convenient, have a few downsides.  Every mean of transportation, with the exception of walking, has costs that come with it.  This ranges from having to pay for the cost of gas to paying the physical price of not getting the proper amount of exercise our bodies where meant to have via walking to our destinations. There is one option that could solve these issues.  Imagine a small grass field, similar to the ones you find at playgrounds, with a small parking lot.  Within this parking lot would be a couple of electric powered cars attached to power stations. These setups would be available every few blocks (about as frequent as modern bus-stops). Within the field beside the cars stations would be stationary work out equipment. These would be modeled after the free-to-use exercise stations in places like China. They would have equipment such as: bench presses, ellipticals, bikes, etc.  All of these would be wired underground to the charging station attached to the cars. The energy created from the movement of each device will directly charge the cars in the station.  Off to the side of each piece of equipment would be a touchscreen. A person can set up an account at their local government buildings, providing a valid driver's license,e-mail address, and credit or debit card number. When signed in, each account can track how much a person exercised and convert it to an 'available miles for usage' number.  This means that the more a person uses this equipment, creating more energy for the cars, the more miles the person would be allowed to use the car for.  This however also means, that prior to using the car they would have to deduct the amount of miles they plan to use from their account.  If the person should go over their allotted miles, they will then be subsequently charged on their provided credit card.  This encourages people to work-out more at these stations, so they can avoid the fees for using the car. This set-up would immensely help those who financially can't afford their own form of transportation, while promoting a healthier lifestyle in a way that could easily fit into our society's demanding everyday regime.

Some sort of free bicycle rides.  It would work by having you use a credit card (so people cannot steal bicycles) as a deposit.   Here's how it would work.  You would walk/visit some sort of kiosk, swipe your card and it would unlock a bicycle from a rack.  You are then free to ride it.  You can then return it to the same kiosk, or perhaps to one further away/new destination and as long as you swipe the credit card again upon returning the bike -- it would clear your deposit.   If you don't return the bike within a reasonable amount of time (say 2 days or so), you could charge the person the price of the bike plus some penalty.   This method won't make much money if free, but you could also setup a rental type system.   Just imagine lots of kiosks around a city, with say 12 or so bikes are each one, and people could rent/ride as needed.  Like a Uhaul type service for bikes.   From a network perspective, I guess it would be like sending a packet to a new location downstream, and the returning of the bike would be the acknowledgment.    If you don't return the bike, it would charge your card aka ask for a retransmission of said packet.  That's all I have for now.
