As the car takes a passenger to desired location within that particular area, if another person flags that same colored car, that person can hop in and share the ride. After all, the drop off points will be in the same general area and the rate is flat.

I don't anticipate the transportation system changing too much in my area no matter the time frame. I think the car will rule for the next several decades, but I would like the cars to change. They need not be so huge, and would be powered by plug-in type electrical engines. Each home would have a solar array and this would power your home, and your car. A back-up natural gas power plant would help out if it's cloudy for weeks. Cars would be there for longer trips, but I would also like to see normal bicycle travel increase in the small city I live in. People are fat, lazy, and gross. We don't need anymore technology to go 100 yards, just less lazy people.
I feel the best is a transportation tunnel.  It should run around 150 miles per hour and provide food accommodations as well as sleeping areas!
I imagine a train line that rings the entire city, with interstitial lines to service the downtown areas.

I live in a fairly small town that has a decent amount of people but isn't very large in area. Solar powered railcars could be a viable option for this area. They would only have to travel short distances at once, and it could easily be utilized by everybody in town by having just a few stops. Think about the railcars in San Francisco and other major cities being completely solar powered. The electricity saving would be huge.

I live in a pretty population dense area where most things people need (like a hospital, a big job center, homes, grocery store) are pretty close to each other.  I think this set up begs for a monorail.  It would be elevated so wouldn't interfere with current traffic too much, but would provide a nice transportation system for people to take for short trips.

I live in a rural area and a lot of people have horses- so an uber or lyft but actually with horses! If you are a nw rider, you can be on a horse on a lead rope, and if you have experience, you can just rent the horse!
I live in a rural area so horseback travel, hay wagon travel and buckboard travel may well be decent substitutes for cars and buses presently being used.

I live in a rural area, it's pretty hilly but it runs along the length of a valley. It would be really nice to have a walking/bike path that connects the residential neighborhood to the commercial district without having the bike/walk on the road. Although it's generally slow traffic, walking on the road is never exactly safe. Especially in the winter. To be able to network together the few towns in the valley too would be very nice.

I live in a rural community about 1 hour from a city. I would like to see this area build a light rail commuter line that could link these isolated communities and boost the economy. Many people out here do not even have cars.

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.
I live in an area where horses are abundant. It would be a trip if everyone started using their horse instead of a car or motorcycle.

I live in an area where there are a lot of senior citizens so driving can sometimes be scary, and I think this city would greatly benefit from public transportation. However, I think something that would benefit the environment would be the most helpful, so I think pushcarts would be a lot of fun, or even horse drawn carriages. Not only would these be better for the environment, but I think the older people would appreciate the old-fashioned nature of such public transport systems.

I think a bullet train would be very useful. A train that can transport passengers fast in between the major areas in the neighborhood, for example to schools, the downtown area, the performing arts theater, shopping districts, the airport etc. It doesn't have to stop very often like a bus but an instead be used for getting between major areas and can be supported by the bus system.

I think a spiral starting from the center of the city going out to the edges of the city.  The spiral should be able to get all the areas if it's only 2-3 blocks wide.  It would have a dedicated lane so traffic wouldn't affect the bus and vice versa.  There would be a way to quickly have people enter and exit the bus and this would keep it on time.  Of course the bus is electric powered.

I think adding a rail system in my city would be a great idea. The only public transportation we have is buses and there are a lot of areas they don't even run to. So I think a rail system would do wonders in getting a lot of other people where they were going.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

I think my neighborhood would benefit from one of those pedal bike bars for the downtown area. There is a lot of history and what better way to enjoy it than while sipping a nice drink and getting some exercise

I think that an interesting mode of transport in my mountain town would be a ski lift type system that runs behind the businesses on main street and stops at every corner. The reason for this is our huge lack of parking and the congestion that cars cause in the shopping district. It would be unusual and fun and it could connect to the large parking area at the convention center.

I think that one cool idea is to have personal transportation that allows you to connect with other people in your area so you can rideshare and also carpool or get a ride when needed. Instead of using like Craigslist to ask for rideshare or ask if people are willing to pick  them up, you use an app. People can sign into this app and then say which direction they are going. Along the way you can request that person pick you up to get you from A to B...kind of like hitchhiking through a mobile app.

I think the idea of rickshaws are a good one.  But in most places, like cities or suburban areas with hills, a traditional rickshaw wouldn't be practical.  I think that a bike with an electric motor and a cab on the back would be a good solution.  It's nicer for the environment and a more personal connection than a taxi.  Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.
I think there should be bikes that you can easily rent. You can get them in the major shopping areas and drive them around town to get excercise as well as helping to use less gasoline.

I think we should focus on making it easier for people to bike around the area. We need to widen sidewalks and/or have separate paths just for pedestrians and bikers. Oftentimes, the bike lanes are narrow or end abruptly.

I want an elevated railway that preserves nature, resists going down during snow and bad weather, and reaches all areas of my city. It would be public transportation and have low-cost monthly passes. It would also run on renewable, clean energy.

I wish we had separate bicycle highways that were enclosed spaces, both heated and cooled for summer/winter. It would be a cheaper mode of transportation. There would be protection to prevent car vs bicycle accident, a major problem in our area. It would also be healthier and exercise for the day during a commute. I picture it being a rounded space that is clear so you can see your surroundings outside.

I would like a city trolley. The trolley would travel around the city several times a day, taking and picking up residents from the major shopping areas. The trolley stops should be no more than two blocks from any neighborhood.
I would like a non-gas mode of transportation to be created for our area such as a horse drawn carriage where the horses are treated really well but they also go fast and get us where we need to go.

I would like an interchangeable form of light rail, in which the train would have several compartments that would be destined for multiple locations. That way you just get on the train, and the train goes to an interchange. At the interchange the compartments are separated (I imagine they are held together by magnets) and grouped together by location. Once all the compartments that are going to the same area are together, the train leaves. It would work like changing trains, except you wouldn't have to go outside.
I would like it if the area I lived in used a bike sharing system like I have seen in some other major cities like Portland and Minneapolis.

I would like to see a bicycle highway.  It would go the length of regular highways, but be for bikes and pedestrians.  It should be wide enough for fast moving road cyclist, it should have passing lanes, and little road crossings.  There should be frequent on and off ramps.  There should also be many large parking areas.  Ideally it would even lead to public transportation areas with ample bike parking.

I would like to see a cable car that runs across the city.  It would take people across the busy streets.  It would be convenient for office workers. It would cut down on traffic in the downtown area.

I would like to see a system of localized automated delivery. A system which is run as a utility for the town or city in which the focus is put on small businesses in the area. I think this could have hyper-local economic benefits, as it may help small businesses steal back sales from online marketplaces like Amazon. I see it being a motorized electric drone, that could use something like a bike lane to bring goods to local neighborhoods from small businesses in area.  it Could be coupled with a publicly run website for ordering and added revenues from ad placement on site and/or vehicles could help give money back to towns and cities.

I would like to see public transportation on buses expanded in my area, with a dedicated area for bicycles to also be transported on the buses.  This would help a lot with traffic, and still allow people to get to their destinations quickly.

I would love it if the city made walking and riding a bike more user friendly. There are no areas that are safe for pedestrians or bikers. If there were a bike lane, more people could move independently and get to where they are going. Commuters using more than one mode of transportation would be able to get to their destinations more quickly and with greater safety.

I would love to see a social network for people that work for a certain business. This social network would allow you to find rides from other employees that live in your area. Every business would have an account at this website, and employees who want to pick up other employees can volunteer. Maybe a $5 fee per person each week to account for gas money, but it could be like it would tell you who lives within 10 miles from you that works where you do, and you can ride share or carpool with them. It would be almost like a social network where you can talk to other employees you don't know and then you can ride together or take turns driving.
I would really like to see separate lanes for scooters in my area.  A lot more people are commuting this way, and it would be good if it was a safer way to drive.

I'd like to see shuttle trams in my area. It's a small section based urban area that has about four different areas all residents will have to visit at some point in time. If we had a shuttle system that specifically transported people from a central point to the four primary destinations it would incredibly reduce the use of fossil fuels, traffic, and accidents in the area.

I'd like to see some kind of motorcycle rental system in my neighborhood. This would be really convienant and I imagine quite affordable as well. There tends to be a lot of traffic in my area too so this would prevent the roads from becoming too congested. I live in a high tourism area as well and I think this would be more fun for people to explore the city than renting traditional cars.

I'd like to see the combination of a food truck and a taxi. This way you could grab a fresh made bite to eat while on your way to the destination. There would be a seating area in the front and a small kitchen with a service window in the back. This bus could serve hot and cold sandwiches and maybe drinkable soup in cups with lids to prevent spills. Now all you have to do is hail a cab. Forget finding something to eat then looking for the cab. The food can be prepared for you onboard.

I'd like to see the railroad tracks by our house be repurposed as a walking and biking route for the neighborhood.  It would be really sweet if they could use that and carry the corridor all the way to the nearest town and shopping area.

I'd love to see a crowdsourced method of alternate transportation in my city, where people could request rides from others who happen to be in the area and going the direction you need to with a minimal cost. There are so many people who have cars and it would be a great option for people who don't have reliable access to one. It could use cell phone apps and perhaps even have a traditional component using telephone for people who are less technologically inclined. The biggest challenge would be safety/security, and I'm honestly not sure how to overcome that aspect. There could be specific stops, almost like bus stops, where people could gather and wait for rides, or schedule rides to pick them up at certain times.

I'd really like to see a little pod that you could get into.  It has a minor sedative so you can relax on your commute.  A bus or something of the sort would come by and pick up pods which are locked and only you can open.  You hang a sign or type in your wanted destination, and a bus that goes roughly to the area scoops you up.  



Upon getting to your destination, the bus drops you off at a stop, and the sedative wears off with an alarm to wake you up.

Idea 1 . Semi conductor can be design in such a way that it can be RE-USED.

Idea 2 . Renewable energy - the cost of the solar cells has been going down a lot, the labor to install them hasn't, and that's an area where innovation can help.

Im from Seattle and it is mostly built over the top of the old city that burned down. I would think that they'd be able to build subways here at least through the downtown area where they have underground tours of the city.

In dense urban areas have a series of high tension wires between buildings. Have a  mechanized seat something like a zipline  that people would ride on. This would need a seatbelt or maybe an enclosed capsule for safety but the idea is making the seat as compact as possible .

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town. 



One thing that may be neat would be large sidewalks where people could ride bikes/scooters/walk and avoid using a vehicle. The main road is fairly busy, and there are quite a few shops around that would be more accessible if we had better transportation than just getting in a car! (Boardman, OH). Little scooters with solar power charging stations would be neat.

In the downtown area, stations to rent bicycles or even mopeds. Maybe you could have a really cheap membership and present your card at the check out station. Then you would return it at another check out station. It would cut down on how much people use cars. The key would be having enough stations to actually get the bike or moped to make the idea viable.

In the interest of reducing traffic and accidents, a new series of self-driving only roads and lanes are opened.  On these roads, ONLY self driving cars are authorized to drive, and on them there are no speed limits (not that the self-driving cars would be going that much faster than normal). Unfettered by the chaos of common roads and the limitations of human judgement, these exclusively self-driving vehicle areas allow the navigational AIs to coordinate for an optimally fast and efficient journey.

It is not innovative in terms of the whole world, but would be very innovative in my community - bike shares. The area where I live is suburban, so difficult to get enough riders for frequent mass transit. And it's too spread out for just walking. Bike share stands, where subscribers had a code to access bikes from a bike locker, would allow people to commute from place to place (even just to nearby main bus routes) with relative ease.

It would be a very good idea to come up with some kind of effective carpooling system in my area. I live in a rural place, but there could be a central park-and-ride lot built along the major thoroughfare to make carpooling simpler. Perhaps an app could be developed to run the carpooling system so that everyone is on the same page.
It would be cool it we had a monorail type system throughout the neighborhood that does a simple circle and takes kids or adults from the neighboorhood into the town/school area.

It would be hard to have a viable system in my neighborhood, because this area is so scattered. I think the best idea would be a bikeshare; inexpensive access to bikes would be a great idea! The bigger issue would be making our area bike-friendly. That's the part the requires creativity. We could add extra lanes and then add over/underpasses at intersections to make bikes not just inexpensive, but even more time-effective than driving.

It would be small individual electric golf cart-like cars that run along the edge of the sidewalks every couple of minutes that people can hop into to go to the grocery store, pharmacy, post office, etc.  they operate from out of a common neighborhood "hub" so each system covers a small area.  People can just call one from an app on their smart phone, they are charged a small fee, then after the trip, the cart remains in one area until it is called again or it returns to the hub to be charged.

It's a small town. In and near the town center there will be bike lanes and you will be able to access all neighborhoods in an easy and safe manner. There will be bike rental kiosks throughout the area. For areas outside town there could be a service with electric vehicles that you can book ahead of time and you can catch a ride to select locations around town.

Larger Vehicles for apps like Uber that set up car pool for large amounts of people that are going to the same area. For example in Austin, Texas many people enjoy 6th straight but struggle to find parking. If apps like uber could set up their own busses or larger vehicles for transportation to places like 6th street or concerts/ sports arenas it would be much more efficient than a bus that makes regular stops.
Mini bus services around the neighborhood covering the residential area so that single rides can be reduced
Monorail type cart that takes you to high populated areas/

Monorails really can be implemented between high occupancy areas..  There can be direct routes to places such as grocery stores or department stores that people frequent a lot.  This will also boost business and sales if people can access these places quicker.

Moving platforms that function like traincars and moving sidewalks put together. They would go above roads, have railings on each side and be like busses with bus stops. You could buy a thing like a bus pass that allows you x number of rides, so that you don't have to have cash on your person to be able to get on it. It would run from neighborhoods to main city areas and only be running when people call for it/use it to save money on electricity/gas/whatever

My idea for public transportation would include an underground rail system powered by magnets. Because of the varied climate as well as prevalence natural disasters in my area, having the system underground seems like the best idea. The train would stop a lot more often than normal trains; At the end of every street at least. It would have a separate exit system in order to not lose quite as much time loading and unloading passengers.

My idea is to build an app for uber drivers that show all the short cuts to a location. Even if they have to drive through residential areas. The app will calculate the shortest distance and time depending on traffic.

My idea is to use special parking lots for energy efficient vehicles in order to give incentive to the use of cleaner energy. These parking lots could be in the more crowded city areas and you'd need a special pass or something after having your vehicle cleared.
My neighborhood will continue to use mainly personal vehicles as a mode of transportation, though the downtown area is working on an underground rail system.
Off the ground magnetic rails have high speed autonomous trains that anyone can use, and it gets you to areas much faster than can now be done.
One thing I would love to see in my local area is rent able electric scooters. They would be good for the environment, easy to maintain, and reduce traffic in terms of larger vehicles on the road.

Our new transportation system would involve golf carts.  Several roads would be designated as golf-cart-only areas and include parking.  New paths could be created because they take up less space than normal roads and even designated lanes on existing roads could be defined to use existing infrastructure.  The environment would be healthier with less pollutants, crowding would be less due to smaller size vehicles, and it would even encourage healthier lifestyles out in the air and sunshine.

Perhaps a system where you can rent out bicycles or motorbikes to get to where you need to go. You could hold a lot of them in one area and make it easy to check out the bike and then return it later. It would help getting around for people who can't afford a car service to take them around the city but also for people who prefer to be health conscious and also want to save money by biking around the city.

Picture a vehicle of transport that almost resembles a giant scooter. But the thing is that more than a few people can ride it at a time and it can be programmed to go to the destination that you need. There is also the option of seatbelts or straps that can prevent the riders from falling out or off. In the back of the scooter object would be a large area where personal baggage and things can be kept and it automatically locks once enough passengers are aboard. This area is kept locked by the operator of the scooter ride. On each side of the edges of the scooter ride are places for phones and other devices to be plugged in. The scooter ride would be plugged in to keep it charged up and there would be solar panels on the back to make sure that the ride can be energized and charged for a moment's notice.

Pollution is becoming a real problem in my area. The local government should provide tax incentives for people who adopt clean energy vehicles. The high upfront cost of these vehicles make the cost prohibitive to many, but by creating tax incentives, the local government would be able to offset some of that cost.

Public, foot-based transportation. Something like the automatic walkways in airports, but for long stretches of large cities, particularly between common high-traffic areas. It would probably be best if the walkways were raised, to avoid conflict with other ground traffic. It must also include access for the disabled, be easy enough for even tech-fearful users, and extremely safe (with monitored auto-shutoff where applicable).

Railway tunnels off of the highways (outdoor subways) to provide a fast paced mode of transportation on busy streets that work with a system like uber that will have drivers readily available at each location. More for suburban areas, not large city areas that have subway/rail systems.
Roller coasters to get from one critical area to another critical area.
Scooter sharing, where they are parked in small areas and like the shared cars. Except scooters for single people.

Scooters or bikes for rent put in areas that are too far to walk but for people who can't afford a car, uber, or taxi. You could rent them for a day and return them to the area that evening or keep them for another day's charge like a Redbox sort of system.
Skyline car- Have pods that move above the buildings and are connected to main areas of interest. People can pay a toll to use them and be transported around the city
Some type of underground or above-ground monorail system to help with the massive traffic problem in my area. With stations in key locations that are unobtrusive to the overall community.

Taken from the idea of bike rentals, there should also be motorized scooters available for rental, where you can rent any motorized scooter from a "station" and return it to another "station" around your area when you are done.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.

Taxi-style self-driving cars which can be summoned via app and hired for longer journeys, or which would at least serve rural areas. Cars would probably have to be stationed at depots on the outskirts of town, activating and driving off when pinged.

The area is very car-dependent, but a train or monorail going down the middle or above the main highways would be a great way to travel down the expressways and parkways without having to depend on a car.

The last new type of teleportation that I can think of would be tubes that connected to certain places and people could get in them to be pushed through to the other end of the tube to another area. They would be large and everywhere so it would only take up space in the air and there would be lots of places to go to.

There are a lot of fairly narrow paths in between buildings in my area. It would be good if they could be paved smoother to be used by bicyclists. It would make their travel more efficient and would also increase their safety as they wouldn't have to spend as much time on roads meant for cars.

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

There is no bus system so my idea is for a bus system in my area.  I live in a suburbs of a small town and there is no bus out here.  It would be nice to have one.  Sometimes I don't have access to a car and maybe this bus could help me get to the store or church.  I would also like the bus system to be able to take me to the small town to go shopping and stuff.

There should be a completely separate bike lane that runs throughout the city, and is plowed even during the winter.  Currently the biking situation isn't too bad, but there are areas where it is hard to feel safe with cars passing by too closely.  During the winter, it is impossible to bike due to snow in the bike lanes

There should be paid service for a bus route to pick up people who live right outside a city. I will use my self as an example for my idea. I live about 20 miles for a major city . If I didn't have a automobile I would not be able to get anywhere important. Now the nearest cilty has a bus route only for those in the city. But there are plenty of people who would use a rural bus . A bus could pick up multiple people in the rural area. The school bus service already does this , I don't know why the city could come up with a plan to offer public transportation for adults living in rural areas. It's just very stupid that this is not a thing in Houston .
This area could really use a super speed train that goes much faster than traffic. It could travel above the road system and would save tons of time for many people.

This idea would have to be built in a city near a river, or attached to a solar farm because it relies on using naturally produced hydroelectric or solar power. Basically, it's a train on an electrified track, that moves slowly and stops at intervals in a big loop throughout a city. It would make stops the same way buses make stops. If you rode it long enough, you'd wind up at the same stop you got on at.  It relies completely on green energy, no exhaust just some electric motors driving the cars. People would be able to get on and just ride to where they needed to get off, leaving their personal vehicle in a parking area. It could be configured to have small, individual cars maybe fitted with a GPS system so you could tell it where you needed to go and it would get you as close as possible. The main idea is it would be free and the city could tax businesses a small amount for serving their parts of town, just to help pay maintenance costs.

This might be only useful for some places, but it's better than none.  I think there should be a moving walkway for the most common areas of a town or city.  This way foot traffic can be consistent and the flow high.  Since it's fairly low speed there shouldn't be any injury issues and transferring is as easy as getting off the one walkway and on to another.

To help cover a lot of area of a city, the could be a central hub where all the trains, busses, etc start.  Then from that one spot, all the route lines shoot out, like a star.  That way all the people can be at one spot and make it to where they want to go easily since there are no transfers or any other confusing things.

Uber is not currently available in my area, because it is not seen as a large enough "metro" area. I believe that if several of the small communities pooled together, there would be enough available and willing drivers to start a less urban and more suburban/rural version of a paid ridesharing service. Since the communities would be pooled, there would likely be drivers from many different areas of the community, so a larger geographic area could be served.

uber lyft or any taxi cabs we are a rural area very large and towns near or past 30 min away from eachother. having a taxi service would be very appreciative and would also bring more jobs locally throughout the whole southern part of this state really/

Ultimate monkey bars.  People are too fat in my area, forcing them to travel via monkey bars across the neighborhood should help not only with emission decrease, but weight decrease as well!  There will just be an overhead system running the lengths of the sidewalks at 7 foot high so no one gets hurt if they fall.

Using autonomous cars/vehicles as taxis that you can rent and have escort you anywhere you would like to go in your area. Cars will be equipped with GPS so customers can log where their destinations, etc.
We will have cars that can lift off the ground and "fly" with a air propel system. This would be fast enough for them to travel in that city area without hitting any others.

What we need is a better public transportation system that services the East end of the city.  Perhaps a bullet shuttle that will pick up in certain areas of the East End, and shuttle t predetermined locations within the city such as the downtown area, in addition to other areas.

A way to connect your car with a mobile phone app - you would broadcast your intended route (such as commuting home from work) and share this route with people in your local area. For a small fee (under $5) - someone could ask to "Ride Along" with you along your route - but with no deviations - they would be allowed to get out along the way, but not change your intended path of travel.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.
A both walking and bike lane that provides safety from traffic, is well lit, and connects key locations around the neighborhood.

A bus that has a design similar to a hydrofoil boat. The bus would run on special tracks that would be parallel to each other on opposite sides of a street. This passenger compartment would be on top, with the "foils" connecting to the two tracks. There would be open space underneath the passenger compartment where the road is. This way, the bus could move unimpeded by traffic, while also not disrupting traffic itself. Also, passengers would not even see the traffic below them, making the ride smooth, comfortable, and consistent.
A disaster movie about a blimp that gets a slow leak.  Most of the movie will take place in the cockpit.  It will be conversational based between the pilots and air traffic control.
a flying car to dodge traffic
A flying car would be a good innovation. We would free up the roads making less traffic jams and it'd give people new experiences.

A form of transportation similar to an airlift, only the seats are at terminals on the ground. You board and they take you to predesignated stops in a direct line, free of traffic. Like a shuttle or train, only on a smaller scale, and ideally seats come in much more frequently, every 30 seconds or so.

A great mode of transportation in my neighborhood could be a bus or tram that runs along the local parkway (a road that basically goes across the whole town) people would be able to hop on it and ride it to their destination and be there within walking distance when getting off the bus/tram. Could be relatively cheap, clear up traffic with less people having to drive around, and is highly economical.

A human carrying drone. This would require it to be build and withstand certain weight thresholds, such as up to 200 pounds. You would call a drone in and let it know where you want to go. It would pick you up and fly you there at a decent rate of speed and without having to sit in traffic.

A magnetic roadway system, where people move in modular pods that are controlled by a central operating system (COS). Magnets underneath the street guide your pod along, and every movement of all of the pods is controlled perfectly by the computerized system, it is completely autonomous. If your whole family wants to go into town, you assemble your four-pod system and take off, where traffic is optimized perfectly by the COS. If just you are on your way to work, you hop in your single passenger pod, and take off!

A moving sidewalk - like the ones you would see in an airport to help expedite movement between terminals.  Around my area there are a lot of close shops, so people could walk, but getting loads of bags home would be difficult.  Having mechanical walkways would enable people to do their shopping but reduce their need to use cars, and at the same time set all their bags down so they don't have to figure out how to lug them home, especially if they've purchased something heavy.  It could also allow people to get where they need to go faster, if they continue to walk along the moving sidewalk.  They could sit alongside regular sidewalks, so people who still wanted to go out for a walk and get some fresh air could do so.  The mechanical/moving sidewalks would be made out of metal, look like a flat escalator, have hand railings, and each side of the road would have a sidewalk that goes the same way as traffic.

A network of quadcopters (drones) large enough to transport humans. Let's say you need to get to the other side of town quickly, and want to avoid traffic -- get in a drone and have it deliver you by air!

A new form of transportation that could be well used in my community would be a large seating vehicle that took people on and off the local military bases. There are 5 bases here and in the morning and evening commute there are traffic issues around those bases. A way to remove at least half the vehicles could cut down on pollution and traffic around the base for people off the base as well as on. This would be a military carpool of sorts to also eliminate parking issues.
A new transportation system  can be something somewhat like a train, but a small train like shuttle, which can take others around the neighborhood, easy, fast and no traffic.

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.
A online map real time of the buses and trains the area. Buses and trains aren't usually on time and having real on time traffic will show if its a bad bad to drive.

A person's place of employment, such as a hospital could conceivably shuttle employees from home to work via a small bus. The city or county could be divided into quadrants to further facilitate timely pickups. This would definitely free up traffic if the workplace had 9000+ employees.

A sort of rail line, but it's a single rail and has many hanging carts. The carts hold maybe 4 people at a time, like a taxi. The price would be cheaper than a bus and they would arrive quickly when you need them. You could push a button on poles that are located around the city, far more often than bus stops, and the cart will come to you quickly and take you directly to your destination. No need for bus drivers or waiting for traffic!
A subway system in my city is badly needed. We have terrible traffic and everything in the city is built in a grid system. It would save time, money and gas consumption for millions.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

A train to the beach.  The beach is about an hour from our town (or three hours with summer traffic), and all traffic to the beach comes through our town due to an important bridge.  We could have a train that leaves from our town, or other stops nearby, and then expresses to the beach.  People would need extra room for luggage - or you could couple it with a luggage delivery system.  It would cut down on time to the beach and the number of cars on the road.

A train would be useful in my city. It would be most useful to travel out to other nearby cities. Traffic is extremely bad on the interstate where I live, and a train would be incredibly useful for traveling to the popular cities surrounding my city.

A zip line from the place where I take the bus to the subway would be great. It would cut out all the traffic and possibly be much faster than taking the bus to the subway. Also, there would be multiple pods that would lock in the destination and go non-stop so it wouldn't be stopping every few minutes to pick up passengers.
An AI that tells certain buses or train to slow down at a certain rate to decrease accidents making traffic more efficient.

an app that takes into account both traffic and train congestion, as well as the speeds to walk or bike, to tell you the fastest mode of transport to a destination. For example, train  might typically be quicker to get from A to B, but when trains are spaced 20 minutes apart late at night and there is no traffic, driving/taxi would be faster.

An expansion of the skyrail or a similar system with connection to the skyrail could be added to the surrounding cities of Seattle. The addition of public transportation would cut pollution and reduce traffic congestion with the plus side of convenience. It would be a good idea to implement this idea while we still have space available, rather than wait until the problem is a burden.

An overhead puppy cart system, the same concept as in skii resorts. I live in NYC, and outside of traveling by train, there are no other practicals transportation which avoids traffic. Unlike the the train system, you would be able to make direct routes, with a bonus of great views around the city
An underground rail system would be great. That way you could get around without having to get stuck in traffic.  There are so many cars in this area that we are known for our traffic.

An underground Seqway track which will take a while to build but will be extremely beneficial. There are no turns as underground paths are completely straight. Recharger stations are at every mile or two. There are practically no intersections or traffic lights except at major hubs, which are few and far between. Delivery services such as mail and UPS are a major component of this transportation system, which will make them faster and clear up traffic on major roads.
An underground walkway would be useful in my neighbourhood because you would not need to stop traffic to cross the street.
Any type of hoover mode of transportation allowing driver to avoid accidents and hoover past slow moving traffic.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.

autonomous vehicles abound. there are shared autonomous vehicles that can be called by neighborhood members. you may travel to destinations within your town only. the cost is shared by real estate tax. the benefit is a drastic reduction in traffic congestion, as much fewer cars are needed.
Autonomous vehicles will take over 75% of the local traffic. Autonomous public transport will handle the inter-city traffic.

Chicago - Chicago has a great system and phenomenal public transport. As far as transportation though I wish the highways in the city acted like slotted cars, similar to trains in which in every highway entrance there would be a dedicated lane/railway for vehicles to travel at fast speeds like trains. This would reduce traffic and travel times.
Close some roads to motorized traffic and allow only bicycles. offering a local tax incentive for bicycling

Create a taxpayer-funded service like Uber, but dedicated to carpooling people. Since people are already paying for it there would be an incentive to using it. This would ease traffic and reduce pollution.
Drones that carry people - flying cars if you will.  Lucky owners will fly over traffic jams with ease and get to work in record time.

Due to the amount of traffic around Tampa and surrounding towns, there is much congestion during rush hours. To help alleviate some of this, I suggest uni-directional bridge to be built that reduce traffic during rush hours. In the morning, the bridge would allow traffic going west towards the base. In the evening, traffic would flow to the east.
electronic billboards that tell which routes to take that currently have less traffic
Encourage biking by providing dedicated bike lanes that are safe from vehicular traffic.

Firefighters are using jet-packs in Dubai to combat fires in skyscrapers. I propose we use jet-packs for personal transport. It's hard enough to travel in big cities like Miami with all the traffic. Having your own jet pack allows you to literally fly away from a stressful situation such as sitting in traffic or waiting for public transportation. It will save time and is fun. This futuristic technology is here and it works.

For transportation in my neighborhood we have cars, and buses. The most popular mode of transportation being the four door family sedan type car. Following that it's the minivan and then the four-door trucks. They can be seen whizzing back and forth on the roads causing many traffic jams during peak morning hours.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

Future transportation is the Shower transporter. You get ready for where you want to go and then simply hop in the shower and press a button to be teleported to your pre-progammed destination. E.g. you will have regular places like your work and supermarket already programmed in with addresses. The shower will pop out through your roof and drop you off at your destination by taking the sky-way and then return home. Just remember to take your shower calling watch with you to buzz your shower teleport back when you want to return home. No more traffic no more waiting no more parking just flying showers :)
Have a system of skylift that can transport people within the city. This could really reduce traffic congestion. This network goes above the ground traffic and moves quickly.
Have scooters that people can rent, this would reduce pollution and traffic.
helicopter rides when lots of traffic
Human Tubes where people slide through interconnected tubes throughout the city in order to bypass traffic.

I am thinking about a flying transport system. It should fly with balloon or air system. It should not need engine or fuel. So expence would be cheap. It should occupy 15-25 people at a time. It moves with air adjustment, drag, thrust, pressure etc. The flyer lands every important point in a city. So people can travel across the city with less time and money. No traffic block, signals, air pollution etc.

I am visually a bus like transportation system that travels on something like rails which are suspended from above.  The rails are not supported by concrete systems from below.  Specialized buses will travel on these rails without causing disruption of regular road traffic.  When it nears a bus stop, the bus will stop and drop itself down to the level of the regular roads, open the door and let the passengers in and out.  Once the door closes it will climb up to the to the level of the suspended rails and travel forward on the rails.

I can imagine my neighborhood having a high speed maglev train. It will levitate on top of a rail that will span around the entire city to avoid traffic. It will be fast and efficient to provide good transportation services.

I could imagine single rider tram cars. The cars would be tethered to cables above the streets. Something akin to ski lift carriage, but completely enclosed in glass. Advantage would be thy could run off electric current and would reduce ground street traffic

I get out of my house and before I leave my apartment on my 12th floor I just press a button on my app on my phone to type a location of the place i need to go.This would in turn contact all local data base systems of GPS based transport systems irrespective of the vendors available or government supported transport systems which include Cabs,Buses,Trains,Subway,3 Wheelers and most importantly assuming the people of the future will care a lot more about the environment and all the people who are going alone in a 5 seater car would have a option of sharing there carbon footprint left by the vehicle.And if the co-ordinates of the person with the car and the co-ordinates of the Person who is using the app matches then a Random Unique (one time use)Number or Picture or Anything which would be visible from atleast 10 feet away on a Min 6 inch screen.However this interface can be avoided by tracking the dots on the GPS system or by sending a snap shot of the car number or a photo of the person himself which will be destroyed automatically by the system once the person is down from the Vehicle.Punch Line Before I get to the main gates of the apartment.I should have the list of Vehicles available to me and the time it would take the vehicle to reach my place based on GPS and traffic conditions and also how much time would it take to reach my destination again based on real time traffic conditions and also most importantly.if i take  the public transport system.How much time would it take to reach the same destination and also how much Carbon foot print would i save from doing it.And also the time required by the vehicle to reach the local transport systems if it is not a walkable distance.There are many more ,But i think that is enough for the day.

GIVE THE CUSTOMER ALL THE POSSIBLE OPTIONS OF COMMUTING WITH THE CARBON FOOTPRINT AND THE COST AND THE TIME INVOLVED IRRESPECTIVE OF THE VENDOR OR GOVERNMENT SYSTEMS...

I imagine a loop in my city where anyone would be able to have a short walk to the 'main artery' and be able to get anywhere at a major point within minutes; perhaps this would be a rail suspended above the city, or otherwise away from other major traffic; it would really help in efficiency of moving people around.

I imagine a taxi speed boat that could take you downtown in a matter of minutes. It will help skip all the traffic on the street and cut your time in half. Perfect for people who live by bodies of water and are in a rush like NYC.

I imagine a type of highway for bicycles where people can use on and off ramps easily to reach their destination. They wont have to worry about cars since its a bike only highway system. it will get people to their destination quicker since they dont have to stop at traffic lights and watch out for pedestrians.

I live in a pretty population dense area where most things people need (like a hospital, a big job center, homes, grocery store) are pretty close to each other.  I think this set up begs for a monorail.  It would be elevated so wouldn't interfere with current traffic too much, but would provide a nice transportation system for people to take for short trips.

I live in a rural area, it's pretty hilly but it runs along the length of a valley. It would be really nice to have a walking/bike path that connects the residential neighborhood to the commercial district without having the bike/walk on the road. Although it's generally slow traffic, walking on the road is never exactly safe. Especially in the winter. To be able to network together the few towns in the valley too would be very nice.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

I live near the water, so water transportation would be nice to have. It could be a system of ferries that can go from port to port, carrying passengers like a bus system. This would reduce the amount of cars on the road and the amount of traffic.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I think a method that would improve the transportation system would be to change how turn lanes are handled in America. Overseas, to turn left, you veer off to a lane on the right that comes to a stop so that you don't block traffic waiting to turn and then when it is clear, you drive across the street onto the road you were going to turn onto.

I think a spiral starting from the center of the city going out to the edges of the city.  The spiral should be able to get all the areas if it's only 2-3 blocks wide.  It would have a dedicated lane so traffic wouldn't affect the bus and vice versa.  There would be a way to quickly have people enter and exit the bus and this would keep it on time.  Of course the bus is electric powered.
I think a trolley system would work really well here. I live in Fort Collins and the city is very centralized but the traffic is terrible - perfect for a trolley!

I think teleportation would be awesome. Wouldn't need cars anymore, save on oil and fumes in the environment. People would be happier because they wouldn't be stuck in traffic or have to drive hours to see long distance family members.

I think the idea of rickshaws are a good one.  But in most places, like cities or suburban areas with hills, a traditional rickshaw wouldn't be practical.  I think that a bike with an electric motor and a cab on the back would be a good solution.  It's nicer for the environment and a more personal connection than a taxi.  Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.

I would like our city to have a railway system like downtown Miami. Its computer operated and is over ground. This means it wont impact traffic at all. Its a fast and easy service and its going to make things easier for all.

I would like to see a cable car that runs across the city.  It would take people across the busy streets.  It would be convenient for office workers. It would cut down on traffic in the downtown area.
I would like to see a hover system that occupies the same route as roads and highways to bypass traffic.

I would like to see a system built around "people movers" - similar to the ride that was once at Disneyland.  It would run underneath the ground - under the traffic.  Each car would hold one or two people with large reclining chairs and a docking station for your laptop so you can watch movies, play games or actually do work.

I would like to see jetpacks so people can go long distances in a short amount of time without relatively much traffic. The cost would hopefully be relatively cheap as well once they were mass produced.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.
I would like to see my city connected via a light rail system which would greatly reduce traffic and emissions.  I envision the majority of neighborhoods in the Downtown core being connected.

I would like to see public transportation on buses expanded in my area, with a dedicated area for bicycles to also be transported on the buses.  This would help a lot with traffic, and still allow people to get to their destinations quickly.
I would love to see more light rail transit added to Pittsburgh to alleviate some of the traffic congestion under ground

I'd like to see shuttle trams in my area. It's a small section based urban area that has about four different areas all residents will have to visit at some point in time. If we had a shuttle system that specifically transported people from a central point to the four primary destinations it would incredibly reduce the use of fossil fuels, traffic, and accidents in the area.

I'd like to see some kind of motorcycle rental system in my neighborhood. This would be really convienant and I imagine quite affordable as well. There tends to be a lot of traffic in my area too so this would prevent the roads from becoming too congested. I live in a high tourism area as well and I think this would be more fun for people to explore the city than renting traditional cars.

I'd like to see some sort of autonomous shared fleet of cars that are fueled in some sort of environmentally friendly way. Solar panels on the roof? Maybe bike pedaling inside if you want to exercise and provide a small amount of power? I feel like autonomous cars alone will save a ton of energy just by eliminating traffic jams. And cut down on wind resistance since you wouldn't need to keep the traditional design necessarily.

If we could be so technologically advanced to create giant versions of the airport conveyor belts where humans are carried across, that would be my new method of transportation. Since people are mostly lazy and want something to do the work for them (hence the upcoming popularity of the hands-free segway), this would be perfect to eliminate at least a fourth of the traffic on the street from cars.
In many neighborhoods, stop signs are ignored. I believe switching to yield signs, where ideally suitable, is needed and adding 'bus stops' for local schools that do not hinder traffic.

In the interest of reducing traffic and accidents, a new series of self-driving only roads and lanes are opened.  On these roads, ONLY self driving cars are authorized to drive, and on them there are no speed limits (not that the self-driving cars would be going that much faster than normal). Unfettered by the chaos of common roads and the limitations of human judgement, these exclusively self-driving vehicle areas allow the navigational AIs to coordinate for an optimally fast and efficient journey.

Invest in personal helicopters, these would be like the size of a small above ground pool. They won't take up much space and they'll allow people to get around faster since they won't be stuck in traffic.

It would be cool (although pretty difficult to actually create) to have a gondola lift public transportation system that had cars that could travel over the streets and take people places avoiding traffic! There'd be stops that had elevators and stairs to get up to them and basically they'd just be suspended a bit above the streets and you could travel nicely between them over all the traffic below.

It would be effective to create a bike club in my neighborhood.  We would choose at least 1 day a week to ride our bikes to work decreasing neighborhood traffic and air pollution.  This bike club would host meetings once a month and reward people who rode the most days to work that month incentivizing people to ride more often.
maybe a flying car to avoid traffic

Monorail through the city! Just like Disneyland, this city-wide system allows you to see the city from a bird's eye! Simply get on at one of the many stations around town and enjoy your ride without stops, traffic or bad weather. The rails above the city means growth can continue without getting in the way of transport, and means you can watch the world below!
More bike lanes, or a sky tram to get around, traffic around here is weird.

most of the people are going office by car . In rainy season if you go by car that is not problem.but scooter using people and children are affected by rain . for that if we fix wind resistant ,water resistant umbrella in the bike . In the handle bar that will be very useful for two wheelers .If we make that kind of vehicle that will become very successful .because of rain only most of the people will go by car . or else they will go by scooter. that will reduce the traffic jam.
my city needs a subway system badly. A subway system would run in a star shaped pattern through the city and eliminate the terrible traffic in my city

My city would benefit from an elevated and enclosed train line. Regional rail is the preferred choice for many commuters but is unreliable and frustrating due to weather and traffic related delays. Though the infrastructure investment would be great, we are in need of an overhaul anyway and should improve the current system.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

My idea is to build an app for uber drivers that show all the short cuts to a location. Even if they have to drive through residential areas. The app will calculate the shortest distance and time depending on traffic.

My Idea would be to make the alleyways in my city a lot more bike friendly.  Honestly they are very rarely ever used by the city or homeowners so to make them this way would be beneficial for so many others. This would I believe encourage more people to use bicycles since I know I am terrified when riding my bicycle next to extremely lage and fast moving automobile traffic on my cities roads and highways.

My mom had this silly idea the other day when we were sitting in traffic. Cars that change shape depending on however many people were in it. Say, two people? It'd transform into a smartcar size. One person? Tiny one-person cubicle machine. Sure, it's not really feasible - but it's interesting. It'd make traffic feel less terrible if we could see how many people are in said car and how fast they'd be crossing streets and so on. Maybe have a designated lane for however many people?

my neighborhood future transportation system will be made up of flying cars. This cars will be able to take off and land like helicopters. There will be no more traffic jams, traffic light, annoying speed limits and harassing cops. People will be able to travel to any part of the world without going through airports and flight connections. There will be new telecommunication and navigation technology that will help the drivers navigate safely without having mid air collisions and also mid air gas stations to refuel the cars.

One day per month (at least) cars should be banned from the roads. Some buses could be allowed to allow for transportation of people who can't walk or bike, but this would be a great way to encourage human-powered transport and allow people to see the fun in this activity without increased danger from car traffic.  This would also be great for the environment.
One thing I would love to see in my local area is rent able electric scooters. They would be good for the environment, easy to maintain, and reduce traffic in terms of larger vehicles on the road.

our city is metro .population is a big problem there and traffic too .large no of people use public transport like trains and buses but also use scooter in large nos as its easy to go to places when there is lot of traffic on rads to avoid jams.

Public, foot-based transportation. Something like the automatic walkways in airports, but for long stretches of large cities, particularly between common high-traffic areas. It would probably be best if the walkways were raised, to avoid conflict with other ground traffic. It must also include access for the disabled, be easy enough for even tech-fearful users, and extremely safe (with monitored auto-shutoff where applicable).
remove all non commercial traffic.  have extensive light rail connected to robust subway system.  have storage containers deliver large goods.

Segways!  Segway sidewalks that go over streets and above the normal sidewalks people walk on so you can ride your segway without stopping for traffic or having to worry about a pedestrian taking up space to get by. Segway sidewalks can even run on the edge of a major highway in bigger cities like mine to keep routes short and simple. We can even make the segways charge on solar power so they will never go dead while you're out running about.
Self-driving vehicles will be linked into a computerized grid that will adjust traffic flow and density to most efficiently transport people from point A to B.

Since rail is very expensive, I'd like to see more express bus routes, hopefully with their own lanes to keep them flowing faster than traffic and give an incentive to use them.  Make the buses as comfortable as possible, again as an incentive for use.
Smarter stop lights that are better at managing traffic congestion

Some kind of public transportation like light rail that goes nearby would be ideal. If we could have a light rail or subway system that connects the city to the suburbs that would greatly improve the traffic situation.
Some type of underground or above-ground monorail system to help with the massive traffic problem in my area. With stations in key locations that are unobtrusive to the overall community.
Something above the streets, an elevated form of public transportation, would be cool. That way it would be out of the traffic.
Something like Uber but with people on motorbikes than can weave in and out of deadlocked traffic during rush hour

Subway that takes you straight to downtown. It would be the best transportation to get to downtown without any traffic to watch football games get to work and other activities. I think a lot more people would be traveling this way.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.

The future of transport in my city is likely a self driving car service system. There will be kiosks with cars waiting and you simply go into the car, put your destination into a computer and pay. It is as simple as that. The self driving cars will know how to avoid traffic and accidents and will automatically take the shortest and most sensible route to any destination. The self driving car will allow for multiple passengers and the cars will vary in size.
The future of transportation in my city is by having self-automated driverless cars. They would reduce the amount of traffic congestion and reduce the number of car accidents.

The future transportation system in my neighborhood would possibly incorporate traffic light systems that would detect the amount of traffic and flow to better keep traffic moving and prevent long lines and wait times at intersections therefor reducing trip times and automobile emissions.

The system will be based off cable cars.  It's cheaper and easier to put up than bridges or building tunnels.  They will have their own traffic free paths.  The paths can even intersect by having the cables much higher than the other line's.  There can be platforms every so often so people can get on and off but not too many as to keep cost and commute time down.

The transportation system would be a combination of roads with cars and a railroad track. All of the cars would be connected and be able to drive themselves. Cars would all be on tracks and controlled by the car itself. This would lower accidents and allow for better traffic. Cars would be able to accelerate much faster as there is no driver intervention and you don't have to wait for other cars to accelerate or worry about where other cars are going.

The transportation would be efficient; it would be green and rely on newer energies that are not dependent upon fossil fuels. It also would be future-proof, such that it would reduce and combat the issues of traffic jams and collisions. We still would have private and public transportation, allowing people to make the choice of which is better for their needs. There also would be strict requirements for those who choose to drive; thus reducing the amount of likely collisions. It would be affordable and allow society to continue to grow and prosper.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

There could be a really good motorcycle driver that would drive fast and come pick you up. He would know back roads and side allys very well. He could weve in and out of traffic and get you somewhere really fast.

There would be a pay-to-use bicycle system similar to the Citi bicycles in New York City. It would allow people to exercise while getting to their location quickly. It would also relieve traffic congestion.
This area could really use a super speed train that goes much faster than traffic. It could travel above the road system and would save tons of time for many people.
This idea is about cable bus. Bus moving through cable in air. The cables are places all across the city in air. The bus moves across the cable without any traffic block. There will be stops.

This might be only useful for some places, but it's better than none.  I think there should be a moving walkway for the most common areas of a town or city.  This way foot traffic can be consistent and the flow high.  Since it's fairly low speed there shouldn't be any injury issues and transferring is as easy as getting off the one walkway and on to another.

To reduce gridlock and rush hour traffic governments should offer tax incentives for employers offering a staggered work day. I.e. Employees scheduled to be gin work at different times rather than the 7-10 o'clock  morning hour.

Using boats to travel in Miami to beat the rush hour traffic. It's quite simple to travel anywhere in Miami by using the canals and various waterways. Boats or ferries should be used not just for sight seeing but for public transportation.
vehicles that life themselves to allow "stacking" of cars, this would reduce traffic by half.
Walking tunnels that are elevated, so you are safer from traffic, and enclosed in plexiglass so it is weather-proof but also safe because people can see you.

we need dedicated motorcycle streets, preferably underground, i live in a very populated city (not LA status but still very urban) and ive often thought that a small underground road system built primarily for two wheeled street vehicles would not only cut down on traffic but the pollotuion created could them be trapped and prevented from being released into the atmosphere... it would cause motorcycle sales to skyrocket and there by provide another added economic benefit.

We ought to revisit the trolley system because the buses in New York City are plagued by heavy traffic. We should have electric trolleys on main thoroughfares. It worked in the old days. Sometimes old ideas mixed with new technology is GENIUS!

These cars can have a pod design, though larger vehicles are available for people who need to transport larger items or many items. They accept voice commands, so programming is easy, and the cars can take you to almost any destination. Links to other transportation hubs, like trains and buses, are also available. The car doesn't need to be returned to its original location, just to another station. The vehicles are always well maintained and reliable, plus the service is affordable to most.
