Our society's population is expanding at a rapid rate. The typical modern day modes of transportation, while convenient, have a few downsides.  Every mean of transportation, with the exception of walking, has costs that come with it.  This ranges from having to pay for the cost of gas to paying the physical price of not getting the proper amount of exercise our bodies where meant to have via walking to our destinations. There is one option that could solve these issues.  Imagine a small grass field, similar to the ones you find at playgrounds, with a small parking lot.  Within this parking lot would be a couple of electric powered cars attached to power stations. These setups would be available every few blocks (about as frequent as modern bus-stops). Within the field beside the cars stations would be stationary work out equipment. These would be modeled after the free-to-use exercise stations in places like China. They would have equipment such as: bench presses, ellipticals, bikes, etc.  All of these would be wired underground to the charging station attached to the cars. The energy created from the movement of each device will directly charge the cars in the station.  Off to the side of each piece of equipment would be a touchscreen. A person can set up an account at their local government buildings, providing a valid driver's license,e-mail address, and credit or debit card number. When signed in, each account can track how much a person exercised and convert it to an 'available miles for usage' number.  This means that the more a person uses this equipment, creating more energy for the cars, the more miles the person would be allowed to use the car for.  This however also means, that prior to using the car they would have to deduct the amount of miles they plan to use from their account.  If the person should go over their allotted miles, they will then be subsequently charged on their provided credit card.  This encourages people to work-out more at these stations, so they can avoid the fees for using the car. This set-up would immensely help those who financially can't afford their own form of transportation, while promoting a healthier lifestyle in a way that could easily fit into our society's demanding everyday regime.
Paying a fee for a bike that could be used monthly. There would be multiple stations set up where you could place the bike and switch out for others.

Perhaps a system where you can rent out bicycles or motorbikes to get to where you need to go. Public transportation that may have a few bikes on the front that you can borrow/rent. Having the bikes attached to public transportation could help you to go further and maybe get around another city that has other things to offer, other than your own, where you may use the bikes at hand.

Rent a cycle, a set of motorcycles that you can pay for per hour to take and go to the store or rent for the day for work on warm days. they'd have a wheel lock like the citi bikes in New york so you put your card in and go
Rent a scooter in the summer. These would be like the automatic bike rental stations in many cities, only you'd rent rechargable electric scooters. Station would charge them

Rentable bicycles.  Two or three locations where individuals can rent and return bicycles for a small fee.  The locations probably don't even need someone to watched the bikes if there is some kind of gps locater built in and a cash/credit operated locking mechanism.
Rental electrical bike stations near the bus stops.  You can check out a bike like you were at a library.

Scooters or bikes for rent put in areas that are too far to walk but for people who can't afford a car, uber, or taxi. You could rent them for a day and return them to the area that evening or keep them for another day's charge like a Redbox sort of system.
Segway automated rentals. Like the bike racks in large public cities. You put down a deposit with a credit card and when you return it you get most of the deposit back.

Shared bike system - everyone has access to a system of bicycles that are evenly distributed throughout the city via "bike parking lots." Punch in a code, get a bike for the day, return it to another station later.

Similar to the idea of car ride sharing, there could be bike sharing. This already exists on some level, but those bikes are terrible and slow. This way, people would be more inclined to use them because it would be really easy to get up the hills around here.

Since where I live gets cold, my idea is to have something like the NYC bike share, but with covered and heated cabs.  Our town isn't too big so you can pick up and drop off like a ZipCar.  The bikes would be electric so you can make it up the hills and to provide heat.  There would be an app to tell you where the nearest bike is and to report anything about it, like it being broken.
Solar powered golf carts. You could have stations kind of like bikes and check them out and return them.

Some sort of free bicycle rides.  It would work by having you use a credit card (so people cannot steal bicycles) as a deposit.   Here's how it would work.  You would walk/visit some sort of kiosk, swipe your card and it would unlock a bicycle from a rack.  You are then free to ride it.  You can then return it to the same kiosk, or perhaps to one further away/new destination and as long as you swipe the credit card again upon returning the bike -- it would clear your deposit.   If you don't return the bike within a reasonable amount of time (say 2 days or so), you could charge the person the price of the bike plus some penalty.   This method won't make much money if free, but you could also setup a rental type system.   Just imagine lots of kiosks around a city, with say 12 or so bikes are each one, and people could rent/ride as needed.  Like a Uhaul type service for bikes.   From a network perspective, I guess it would be like sending a packet to a new location downstream, and the returning of the bike would be the acknowledgment.    If you don't return the bike, it would charge your card aka ask for a retransmission of said packet.  That's all I have for now.
Stalls that allow people to rent and drop off bicycles so they can get around the city without wasting gas and causing pollution. Implant GPS devices inside the bikes so they can't be stolen.

Subways with shorter runs. NYC is filled with unused tunnels and stations. Get them up and running. Also, allow people who use any sort of wheel-based transport, that's not a bus or car, to use the bike lanes.

Take the train  to its nearest destination  to your destination.  Get off the train, and rent a bike or scooter to take you to your exact location. There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

This is about a single user system. It is similar to a bicycle. But it's does not run on road. It has specific path made only for this vehicle like a railway track. The track has frictionless surface. The bottom of the vehicle is also frictionless. The vehicle does not have round wheels. But instead flat frictionless bottom (but also can be frictionless wheel). Vehicle does not need fuel. First we clips the vehicle to the track manually. We sit and unclip the vehicle from the track and apply some mechanical force just like in the bicycle to move forward. After that the vehicle moves without any force. Because there is no friction.We just sit and relax. When we apply brake, clips is attached the bottom of track and it stops. The track should be spread all across the city. Vehicle is portable. We take it from home or rent from government.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I see the potential for self-driving cars to replace taxi services. People would call an automated line, or perhaps interact with a site/app on their computers/phones, to schedule to be picked up by the service. Meanwhile, a network that keeps track of all self-driving cars in its region would figure out which car was closest or would have to deviate the least to pick up the passenger within 5-10 minutes of being hailed. These cars could be compartmentalized to hold four or six passengers without individuals having to worry about undesired contact with the other passengers. The cars could run on electricity and the network would consider battery life with regards to planning routes and destinations.

I'm imagining a car sharing service with locations throughout the city where you can go pick up a car without having to reserve one in advance. Nor would you have to interact with any people at the pickup/dropoff location. It would be somehow automated. Perhaps you would subscribe to the service an at annual or monthly rate and be given a special kind of 'key' that would give access to any of the cars currently at the pick up location. It would be first come first serve, and there would be smart technology embedded in both the cars and the keys. Your universal key would be linked to your account, and the car you used would transmit all relevant information to the system. Such as , time of pick up. number of miles drive. amount of gas used. Then the fees would be adjusted accordingly based on the type of car you used, miles driven, gas consumed etc. all of this without any human employees and all the fuss that comes with tradiional car rental. Some sort of free bicycle rides.  It would work by having you use a credit card (so people cannot steal bicycles) as a deposit.   Here's how it would work.  You would walk/visit some sort of kiosk, swipe your card and it would unlock a bicycle from a rack.  You are then free to ride it.  You can then return it to the same kiosk, or perhaps to one further away/new destination and as long as you swipe the credit card again upon returning the bike -- it would clear your deposit.   If you don't return the bike within a reasonable amount of time (say 2 days or so), you could charge the person the price of the bike plus some penalty.   This method won't make much money if free, but you could also setup a rental type system.   Just imagine lots of kiosks around a city, with say 12 or so bikes are each one, and people could rent/ride as needed.  Like a Uhaul type service for bikes.   From a network perspective, I guess it would be like sending a packet to a new location downstream, and the returning of the bike would be the acknowledgment.    If you don't return the bike, it would charge your card aka ask for a retransmission of said packet.  That's all I have for now.

I'm imagining a car sharing service with locations throughout the city where you can go pick up a car without having to reserve one in advance. Perhaps you would subscribe to the service an at annual or monthly rate and be given a special kind of 'key' that would give access to any of the cars currently at the pick up location. It would be first come first serve, and there would be smart technology embedded in both the cars and the keys. Your universal key would be linked to your account, and the car you used would transmit all relevant information to the system. Such as , time of pick up. number of miles drive. amount of gas used. Then the fees would be adjusted accordingly based on the type of car you used, miles driven, gas consumed etc. all of this without any human employees and all the fuss that comes with tradiional car rental. Things like insurance and billing info would all be done upfront when a patron sets up an account. This is genius, the more i think about it!

A bus that has a design similar to a hydrofoil boat. The bus would run on special tracks that would be parallel to each other on opposite sides of a street. A light rail from city center to neighboring suburbs that would replace thousands of commuters and make rush hours less crowded and stressful. This could be as simple as one station in each suburb (thus 10-15 total stations), or a more complex system with multiple stations in each suburb.
A light rail that goes around town quickly and efficiently with routes that will help the people who use it most.

A monorail system that is above everyone.  There would be rail cars on it that go in a multitude of directions.  People can still use the other forms of transportation, but this form would be strictly for people looking to get around in the city.  They would park their cars before entering the city, and use this quick system for getting around.  No more crowded, expensive parking in the city.

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.
a new type of rail system with certain drop off points, but the rail system is above the road so it doesnt interfere with people driving cars.

A rail cart, that is powered by friction and capturing the head it produces while being driven down the rail, it starts with a simple pedal of a bike to create enough momentum and friction to start the process going and then as soon as you produce enough energy to get it moving, it will continue to produce and move forward till you press the brakes. BAM!
A rail system that goes from the outlying suburbs to the big city.
A rail system that hangs over the road where trains are suspeended from above and can carry hundreds of people
A rail system that is build from the ground up. This would be capable of high speeds typically not able to travel when driving or on another train. This would make work transit much faster.

A rail that goes back and forth from campus with known arrival times would be ideal for students to travel from campus to their homes and neighborhoods. This would be like a miniature above ground subway.

A sort of rail line, but it's a single rail and has many hanging carts. The carts hold maybe 4 people at a time, like a taxi. The price would be cheaper than a bus and they would arrive quickly when you need them. You could push a button on poles that are located around the city, far more often than bus stops, and the cart will come to you quickly and take you directly to your destination. No need for bus drivers or waiting for traffic!

A subway system where you sit in a seat that attaches to a rail as soon as you are seated. You are then transported to your destination. This removes the need to wait for trains like a regular subway.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

A system where there are rails above you and nothing underneath you.

You sit in a cart of sorts and you are guided along near the streets, maybe above the streets or sidewalk.

The railings connect overhead and end at each sidewalk and gives you a nice view of the neighborhood, kind of like a ski-lift.
Adding a light rail system to support the university and the surrounding apartments.

An electric monorail with a few cars that travel between the shopping center about a mile a way from us through the little downtown and stopping at the regional rail station a mile the other direction from us. It would have 2 or 3 trains that run back and forth all day and night transporting people between those two major zones in our neighborhood, eliminating the need for cars to travel nearby.

An elevated wagon wheel shaped, high speed rail system would be excellent. The outer ring would be bi-directional allowing quick transport around the city. The spokes would be bi-directional and allow quick transport from inner and outer within the quadrants.
An overhead rail system.
An underground rail system would be great. That way you could get around without having to get stuck in traffic.  There are so many cars in this area that we are known for our traffic.

Another idea for a new transportation system would be a magnetic bullet train system, similar to the one they have in Japan. It would be a national rail system built over the old railroads we have now. It would go to every major city in America and would take half the time to do so.
Automated bus lines that run to every street in America. Something similar to a trolley system, without the rails.

Bicycles with wheels like trains are placed on rails and whoever is going to the market takes this bsicycle and with little bit of paddling the bicycle can reach the destination. There should be distance system where two bicycles should be impossible to collide.
chairs on rails, slow moving chairs down main streets that you can just hop on and ride to where you want to go
Create an underground rail system that allows people to travel to all major hubs of the city. This would save gas and ease pollution.
Driverless cars, it's the only thing I can imagine being different in my neighborhood.  We do not have room for new rail systems.
Electric rail transports. They existed in Detroit before GM had them eliminated. Essentially bicycle lanes with individual vehicles instead that run on electric wires.
extremely light rail. People hop into 1 person rail cars that take up less room than a bike lane. There would be no waiting at the rail station because it leaves as soon as you get in.

From small towns to big cities, public transportation is helping to generate new vitality like never

before. Beautiful, walkable town squares combine residential, retail, office, recreation and public

transportation features to make community living easy. New bus services and light rail extensions

improve mobility and ease congestion. Even the smallest adjustments, like widening sidewalks and

adding bikeways, can provide dramatic impact and value.

Have a system of sidewalk rail cars that attaches to the sidewalks of a city. Each rail car can carry passenger anywhere in the city to any destination and stop at any time on its route. This system of transportation will greatly reduce city congestion while doesn't interfere with any of the vehicles that are already on the road.
High speed rail
High speed rail train
Human sized drones. Highspeed rail like Japan has.Self driveable cars with an uber type interface. (cab drivers r terrible people)

I am visually a bus like transportation system that travels on something like rails which are suspended from above.  The rails are not supported by concrete systems from below.  Specialized buses will travel on these rails without causing disruption of regular road traffic.  When it nears a bus stop, the bus will stop and drop itself down to the level of the regular roads, open the door and let the passengers in and out.  Once the door closes it will climb up to the to the level of the suspended rails and travel forward on the rails.

I believe that we should have personalized rail system fro our neighborhood. The whole nei8ghborhhod should have a few of them available to different destinations. When someone wants to go there they hit a button and it sends it to them.

I can imagine my neighborhood having a high speed maglev train. It will levitate on top of a rail that will span around the entire city to avoid traffic. It will be fast and efficient to provide good transportation services.

I imagine a loop in my city where anyone would be able to have a short walk to the 'main artery' and be able to get anywhere at a major point within minutes; perhaps this would be a rail suspended above the city, or otherwise away from other major traffic; it would really help in efficiency of moving people around.

I live in a neighborhood near an excellent metro system, but not walkable to it. I would like a people-mover sort of system that travels through the neighborhood making the existing metro station more accessible. Perhaps small cars or pods at the end of each street that travel along an elevated rail directly to the metro station.

I live in a rural community about 1 hour from a city. I would like to see this area build a light rail commuter line that could link these isolated communities and boost the economy. Many people out here do not even have cars.

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

I live in the suburbs so all the rail lines converge on the central city. It would be nice if there was a light rail system that linked the different major suburbs together. You could connect it to the lines going to the city and across the country.

I lived in Japan and really enjoyed their system of underground rail. I think most cities in the United States could benefit from such a system, which has the added benefit of cutting down on DUIs. There is no rail system in my town.

I think a new transportation that utilizes a type of rail system on the sidewalks that people can easily easily walk throughout the neighborhood - similar to the moving walkways at airports.  Sort of like a conveyor belt for people.

I think adding a rail system in my city would be a great idea. The only public transportation we have is buses and there are a lot of areas they don't even run to. So I think a rail system would do wonders in getting a lot of other people where they were going.
I think an automatic bus, possibly on a rail system so the times would be more predictable and rigorous.

I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. The entire system could be above street level. The speed would be about 5 mph with platforms every block.
I think that there could be a light rail system or electric buses. there is enough sunlight to make them 100% clean
I think that we need a rail system for our city. Its a growing city with lost of bigger cities around it. A main rail system like a subway would make things much easier to get from place to place.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.

I would like an interchangeable form of light rail, in which the train would have several compartments that would be destined for multiple locations. That way you just get on the train, and the train goes to an interchange. At the interchange the compartments are separated (I imagine they are held together by magnets) and grouped together by location. Once all the compartments that are going to the same area are together, the train leaves. It would work like changing trains, except you wouldn't have to go outside.

I would like there to be a fast speed rail such as in Japan or Germany. I picture it being accurate time-wise and capable of transporting people over great distances. I would prefer it to a bus situation.

I would like to see a People Mover connecting Trenton, Southgate, Taylor and Wyandotte. There seems to be a lot of people walking down streets such as Trenton and Eureka, and especially so in the winter. I can envision a rail system supported by local tax dollars very similar to the one to the north in Detroit. People around here are constantly complaining about weather conditions and global warming and I think my method could bring a lot of people together and solve a lot of the commuting problems around here. There are just so many cars and it seems there is an average of just 1.5 people per vehicle. It is rather said. I really would want to push toward the people mover rail systems.
I would like to see an expanded light rail system with more of a neighborhood connection.  Right now our light rail pretty much just connects the Downtown core with the airport.
I would like to see lightrail or street cars inbny neighbor hood.   Something that was powered in part by alternative energy.  Solar panels on the stations, perhaps on top of the light rail cars.
I would like to see my city connected via a light rail system which would greatly reduce traffic and emissions.  I envision the majority of neighborhoods in the Downtown core being connected.
I would love a rail system to be installed in our city going north/south along the coast.

I would love for there to a more intergrated train system in my city (specifically my neighborhood.) I'd love to be able to hop on a train (or streetcar) and be able to transfer to a larger rail system that would take me to other cities, etc. Something like what european cities have.

I would love if my neighborhood had a rail system that worked from magnets and floated along the rail at high speeds.  I wish that the cars were individual and that I could get in and select from a list of destinations.  I would like my own car and to be able to bring my dogs with me.  It would be fast and smooth and work with minimal power.

I would love to see a light rail system in my community. I am thinking of above ground trains that would run to the various suburbs and take people to various local stops. These trains should run a regular schedule so people can use them to commute.
I would love to see more light rail transit added to Pittsburgh to alleviate some of the traffic congestion under ground
I would love to see Pittsburgh, PA use some of unused railroads for light rail service. Many of our existing routes were cut, unfortuantely.

I'm envisioning a system of small feet-sized platforms, along with a handle at arm-height, running on street-level light rail tracks throughout the city. Like an escalator, these continuously run in a loop around the city/neighborhood, and passengers can jump on and off at will. (Access would be prepaid and mediated by a RFID chip card and scanner on the devices.) These would probably move at about 5-10 miles per hour - faster than regular walking, but slower than other forms of transport that require more infrastructure and potential for danger. It'd kinda be like, Razor scooters but built into the city landscape and available at-will. Like a bike-share system, but always there and with no energy or exercise expended. This would be a great way for tired people to avoid walking, and would speed up trips to the closest subway station/bus stop.
In the city i live in there is no public transportation. If some rails or buses could be brought in it could help a lot of people here.

It is similar to the monorail at Wald Disney world. It goes all around the town and stops when people use an app and state they need a pickup. It can go to individual streets and addresses because it needs no rails, but can use multiple-line systems to navigate the town. It makes scheduled stops, but can also be called by the app. It is free, paid for by local and state taxes, and very clean and quick. People use it for a wide variety of uses, from nights on the town, to grocery shopping, to work commute. It is very safe, clean and fun.

It would be great for our city to offer more access to the rails.  We could use an updated rail system that would make traveling to our larger cities in the state faster, more available, and yet still affordable.  It could bring more people to live in our city if they could travel fast to the big city and help grow our town here.  Our town is terribly depressed and I think that having a high-speed train or just general more options to travel through it would bring a massive amount of revenue into the city.
Just a more streamlined bus and rail service. I'd make buses easier to track.
light rail
Light rail around the city.
Light rail connecting outer neighborhoods to the city would be good for everyone for jobs and business.
Light rail system that reaches even the furthest suburbs.

Light rail. Basically, street card running between the most popular stops. They don't have to run everywhere, but on their routes they'd be more efficient than buses. You count put the rails on the side of the streets, near the sidewalks.
monorail loop from college to mall to hospital to rail line

Monorail through the city! Just like Disneyland, this city-wide system allows you to see the city from a bird's eye! Simply get on at one of the many stations around town and enjoy your ride without stops, traffic or bad weather. The rails above the city means growth can continue without getting in the way of transport, and means you can watch the world below!

My city would benefit from an elevated and enclosed train line. Regional rail is the preferred choice for many commuters but is unreliable and frustrating due to weather and traffic related delays. Though the infrastructure investment would be great, we are in need of an overhaul anyway and should improve the current system.

My idea for public transportation would include an underground rail system powered by magnets. Because of the varied climate as well as prevalence natural disasters in my area, having the system underground seems like the best idea. The train would stop a lot more often than normal trains; At the end of every street at least. It would have a separate exit system in order to not lose quite as much time loading and unloading passengers.
My neighborhood will continue to use mainly personal vehicles as a mode of transportation, though the downtown area is working on an underground rail system.

My neighborhood/city/state is ultra conservative- so having bike lanes would be an improvement. Since it's such a tech town with so many engineers though...it would have to be something very advanced to get these engineers on board. Like some sort of train driven by magnetic rails.

My transportation suggestion (in my town) would be to avoid the freeways and allow me to get to work using a rail way-type system.  This would be either underground or overground.  This is not an something that we see on the west coast a lot, so it would be very helpful to many commuters in the town I live.
Off the ground magnetic rails have high speed autonomous trains that anyone can use, and it gets you to areas much faster than can now be done.

One Idea I've always had was sky trams. It would operate just like your traditional tram system but instead of a point A to point B ride. You would have an additional 5 to 10 stops on a linear path, to support the stops I would use a magnetic rail system, instead of the old wire cable system. This would cut down on over crowding in terms of public and private transportation.
One on rails , but it has seats inside a bubble that hangs below the rails.

Our City has no nearby neighbors. Any future ideas are going to require a rail system, preferably something fast like japanese trains. Maglev technology which will allow faster travel from coastal towns and cities to the capital.
public rail
remove all non commercial traffic.  have extensive light rail connected to robust subway system.  have storage containers deliver large goods.
Since I live in the country it would be an rail service that goes through and above the trees to go to town. It would stop at certain places but would go through the pretty parts of the country

Since rail is very expensive, I'd like to see more express bus routes, hopefully with their own lanes to keep them flowing faster than traffic and give an incentive to use them.  Make the buses as comfortable as possible, again as an incentive for use.

Some kind of public transportation like light rail that goes nearby would be ideal. If we could have a light rail or subway system that connects the city to the suburbs that would greatly improve the traffic situation.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.
The neighborhood needs a rail system that runs adjacent to the highway. This would go from major city to major city with the same stops as for those that drive.

The new transportation is a light rail that also includes trolley service for my neighborhood and city. For $1.00 each way, the light rail runs from east to west and from north to south. In addition, the light rail runs until midnight Monday through Friday and 24 hours a day on weekends. The light rail takes you to all major events in the city and portion of all fares go to pay for school resources in the community.
The subway station can be replaced with magnetic levitation train. The subway train use electrically charged magnets to lift and move above the rail tracks.

The terrain where I live can make public transportation hard to develop. It is very hilly. There is a main highway/route that runs straight enough that a rail system could work. It would be good to get people to the more populated section that could then hook up easily with other modes of public transportation (which do not exist right now but it could be done). It would not be high speed as there would need to be several stops along the way. It could be done with an electric source that would not be harmful for pollution.
There could be some kind of light rail system for the people.  It would make stops at malls, universities, grocery stores, and various event centers.

There was an idea to get a high speed rail in my town. It never happened but it would have been cool. It would have taken half an hour to get to a town 2 hours way. It would have been innovative! But the government shut down the idea. For what reason? Who knows.
there will be driver-less cars and a lite rail system. There will still be some (free) bus transportation to fill in the gaps and help negate the need for new roads

There would be a four inch tall metal rail running between the sidewalk and curb, up and down every street. There would be small carts powered with gravity batteries that would run on the rails. This would help people stop relying on fossil fuel transportation

This new transportation system is a bullet train in the sky, able to span around the neighborhood with up to 700 passengers in under two minutes. It's sleek silver coat is never late, and always early to make sure everyone gets where they need to go. The rails float there in the sky, ready to carry this majestic beauty to the ends of the neighborhood making sure everyone is early
Use a sky rail train to transport people.  Similar to a subway, but rather than below ground, it would be above ground.

We could have helicopters that move from certain places in the city to farther ones.  Somewhat like a light rail system but from different ends of the city.  It could make jumps to each different port that would be faster than any other travel.
We have no light rail

A bike path that has a divider between the road and the bike path. A dedicated bike path that has a sense of security could encourage more people to bike around town since they wouldn't need to share the road with cars.

A Bus system, within the metro area that was funded by a tax on gas purchased by individual commuters. In otherwords, free to the people who use the bus, and costs the people who don't. have the busses rinning from a set time like 6am to 9 pm  and pickups are every 15 min, so you never need to bother with knowing the bus schedule. Also, have all busses make a stop in the center of town so if you need to get across town, take a bus from you house to the center, and from there to your final destination. There should be a bus passing every school, hospital, shopping center, library ect. Simply run smaller buses on less popular routes, use smaller buses in general. make one special route for city to city transfers. The system needs to be free or very affordable, fast and convenient. No need to waste resources and infrastructure on schedules, call centers, web pages, just keep it simple and convenient.
A car pool van that does loops around our town picking up kids and dropping them off at various activities. There can be an app that works to hail the van and parents can track where its going

A central hub for a ridesharing service that provides cars for small groups to take to neighboring towns. I live in a rural area, a few minutes from a very small village. The nearest SMALL city is about 30 minutes away, and the nearest decent sized city is almost an hour away. A ridesharing service would make accessing these places much easier, and if the company provided the car (for a fee, of course), those without vehicles could be serviced.
A electric scooter sharing program for getting around town without having to drive a car and use too much gas or take up too much space.

A going to town app. In a rural area like where I live sometimes you avoid going to town because you don't have a ride or you just don't feel you can justify driving all that way just to run a quick errand. Enter an app that connects you to people along your travel rout who also need to go into town. You could flag yourself as offering a ride or needing a ride.
A golf cart-like train that circles the small town I live in on a regular basis.

A great mode of transportation in my neighborhood could be a bus or tram that runs along the local parkway (a road that basically goes across the whole town) people would be able to hop on it and ride it to their destination and be there within walking distance when getting off the bus/tram. Could be relatively cheap, clear up traffic with less people having to drive around, and is highly economical.

A jitney that makes local stops within a few miles of a small town.  My town would be perfect as an example.  Most errands can be run in a 10 mile radius.  This includes, post office, shopping centers, DMV, library, etc.  there could be a call in to meet at nearest cross stop.  We have 2 main roads that run through town so this would be very easy to implement.
A light rail that goes around town quickly and efficiently with routes that will help the people who use it most.

A magnetic roadway system, where people move in modular pods that are controlled by a central operating system (COS). Magnets underneath the street guide your pod along, and every movement of all of the pods is controlled perfectly by the computerized system, it is completely autonomous. If your whole family wants to go into town, you assemble your four-pod system and take off, where traffic is optimized perfectly by the COS. If just you are on your way to work, you hop in your single passenger pod, and take off!

A network of quadcopters (drones) large enough to transport humans. Let's say you need to get to the other side of town quickly, and want to avoid traffic -- get in a drone and have it deliver you by air!
A new bus route that could go through my town. It would have a different route than the buses we currently have.

A new transportation idea would be to have bikes that can be rented.  I have seen this in some towns such as Austin, Texas.  Where you can find a bank of rental bikes every couple of blocks.  How awesome would it be if this was more normal and people could choose to ride a bike to the store to grab a loaf of bread or something, rather than getting in the car and wasting gas and adding to pollution.

A new transportation system in my neighborhood could be the use of drones to fly individuals in and around town, or to far off destinations. The drones would fly like helicopters, but can  can also be controlled using a remote control. Unlike a car which can transport several passengers, the drone would be only be able to transport one person.
A overhanging monorail. There are a lot of key locations close together, this would be great for my town.
A ship that takes you around town within minutes and costs less than other methods of transportation.

A train to the beach.  The beach is about an hour from our town (or three hours with summer traffic), and all traffic to the beach comes through our town due to an important bridge.  We could have a train that leaves from our town, or other stops nearby, and then expresses to the beach.  People would need extra room for luggage - or you could couple it with a luggage delivery system.  It would cut down on time to the beach and the number of cars on the road.
a trolley system that goes through the main line of town. hop on/hop off style so that people can use it to get to work

An underground system in my small town like a subway. But instead of a subway underground, it would be those moving sidewalks you see in the airports that you could walk or glide quickly from place to place.

autonomous vehicles abound. there are shared autonomous vehicles that can be called by neighborhood members. you may travel to destinations within your town only. the cost is shared by real estate tax. the benefit is a drastic reduction in traffic congestion, as much fewer cars are needed.

City buses that actually go downtown and to the places that people need to go, instead of just around the edges of town. Also, have a fleet of bikes that people could rent for $1/hr to ride the distances downtown like some other cities.

Currently, I live in a small town that has a public transportation system. However, you have to call and wait for the bus to pick you up, instead of waiting at a pre-determined stop, and it can take forever to get where you're going. I propose a busing system that's like the one in bigger cities for my neighborhood. People could still call and wait for a bus, but buses should also stop and pick people up at predetermined stops at regular intervals.

Due to the amount of traffic around Tampa and surrounding towns, there is much congestion during rush hours. To help alleviate some of this, I suggest uni-directional bridge to be built that reduce traffic during rush hours. In the morning, the bridge would allow traffic going west towards the base. In the evening, traffic would flow to the east.

From small towns to big cities, public transportation is helping to generate new vitality like never

transportation features to make community living easy. New bus services and light rail extensions

Have a monorail system around town. It'll reduce pollution because people will have fun using it instead of driving their cars.
Horse drawn carriage would rock here in this southwestern mountain town. People would really love it and it would be more reasonable for my area than just your average bus or taxi.

How about a rent-a-Segway system?  Kind of like Zipcars or the bicycle rentals in big cities - you could pick up a Segway at a docking station in one part of town and then drop it off at one in another part of town.  You would probably need some sort of point of sale system for a deposit on the Segway, but otherwise the city could price it however they wanted.
Huge people can carry smaller people "piggy back" style to their destinations.  My town is small so it wouldn't be very long.

I can see a transport type system where someone steps on a pad and it transport them digitally over to where they want to go within a town. kinda like the thing they had in willy wonkas chocolate factory but without the death ray pointer thing it would be just a pad like a dance dance revolution pad.
I can use the battery bike to avoid the air pollution in my home town

I have seen a lot on the news lately about 'self-driving' cars, and I think it would be neat if this technology could someday be applied to public transportation. I think 'self driving' buses would be an excellent mode of transportation. I think this would be particularly useful for smaller cities or towns that can't afford to have subway systems. Self driving buses could be programmed to stop at every stop timely and efficiently and could save the city money by eliminating the need to hire drivers and would cut out the issue of human error when it comes to being on time, not showing up for work, or causing accidents.
I imagine a railway system that goes through my town and all around the united states. It would be a bullet train like they have in europe that hovers and goes fast. It would be affordable too.

I imagine a transportation system in which we all use underground super chutes. They move us from place to place within our town super fast. It would have to be set up so everything is safe of course. I imagine a network of these chutes spreading throughout the city and they pop you up wherever you want to go. Wouldn't that be amazing?

I live in a fairly small town that has a decent amount of people but isn't very large in area. Solar powered railcars could be a viable option for this area. They would only have to travel short distances at once, and it could easily be utilized by everybody in town by having just a few stops. Think about the railcars in San Francisco and other major cities being completely solar powered. The electricity saving would be huge.

I live in a rural area, it's pretty hilly but it runs along the length of a valley. It would be really nice to have a walking/bike path that connects the residential neighborhood to the commercial district without having the bike/walk on the road. Although it's generally slow traffic, walking on the road is never exactly safe. Especially in the winter. To be able to network together the few towns in the valley too would be very nice.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

I live in a small town so I think the future transportation system in my neighborhood will be to get rid of normal sized roads and create bike and walking paths all over town. I can see the current roads changing to smaller lanes made for electric vehicles while most of the transportation needs will be fulfilled with bike and walking paths and personal hoverboard type of transportation.

i live in a somewhat smaller town in rural virginia. everything is super accessible and easy to get to. our town is gold cart friendly. my idea would be a cab service, but with golf carts. it would be a super fun way to help people get from point A to point B. it would also encourage safer driving.

I live in a town right on the ocean and there are many canals here. I think a canoe taxi service would be really convenient and fun. It wouldn't get people to their desired locations super fast but it would allow people to travel leisurely and enjoy the scenery along the way. It would also be really healthy for the people driving the canoes and help them to stay fit.

I live in a town with a lot of freight trains. A subway system would be nice because it would get us places faster (the town is large in size and spread out over several miles) and be able to bypass the trains, which stop constantly. The subway would run either over the existing trains or under them and run off of cards that were prepaid like the MTAs.

i live in twin falls idaho and we could use a bus line, i guess it isn't a new idea  but yeah this is a place where there is sharp economic divide and all the businesses are on the rich side of town, the original town or the poor side of town "old town" is roughly a mile from the main drag so buses would be great for people who cant afford cars and better for the environment in general

I lived in Japan and really enjoyed their system of underground rail. I think most cities in the United States could benefit from such a system, which has the added benefit of cutting down on DUIs. There is no rail system in my town.

I think a great idea for a transportation system would be a neighborhood or city that bans cars and uses all bikes to get around. This would really help the environment and people in this town would also be in really good shape. It would have to be a town that doesn't get very cold in the winter, like where I live, where people could use their bikes comfortably year round. Each bike would have to have a small basket though for people to carry their stuff.

I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. The entire system could be above street level. The speed would be about 5 mph with platforms every block.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

I think that an interesting mode of transport in my mountain town would be a ski lift type system that runs behind the businesses on main street and stops at every corner. The reason for this is our huge lack of parking and the congestion that cars cause in the shopping district. It would be unusual and fun and it could connect to the large parking area at the convention center.
I think there should be bikes that you can easily rent. You can get them in the major shopping areas and drive them around town to get excercise as well as helping to use less gasoline.

I think we should have a system like Uber set up here. Allow individuals to "sign up" to be drivers at the town and people can book rides via the net, text messaging, or by calling. I think this should be tax-exempt income because then the town has no issue with gas or any other expenses because it makes this more profitable to retired people or others who can't work. With the way free market works we would almost always have enough drivers!
I would go with a moped service.  There would just be mopeds position around town and you have to drop it off at your stop to check out.

It is similar to the monorail at Wald Disney world. It goes all around the town and stops when people use an app and state they need a pickup. People use it for a wide variety of uses, from nights on the town, to grocery shopping, to work commute. It is very safe, clean and fun.

It would be an underground bullet train system that connected major hubs around the city. It would take only minutes to get from one station to the other across town. Some sort of free bicycle rides.  It would work by having you use a credit card (so people cannot steal bicycles) as a deposit.   Here's how it would work.  You would walk/visit some sort of kiosk, swipe your card and it would unlock a bicycle from a rack.  You are then free to ride it.  You can then return it to the same kiosk, or perhaps to one further away/new destination and as long as you swipe the credit card again upon returning the bike -- it would clear your deposit.   If you don't return the bike within a reasonable amount of time (say 2 days or so), you could charge the person the price of the bike plus some penalty.   This method won't make much money if free, but you could also setup a rental type system.   Just imagine lots of kiosks around a city, with say 12 or so bikes are each one, and people could rent/ride as needed.  Like a Uhaul type service for bikes.   From a network perspective, I guess it would be like sending a packet to a new location downstream, and the returning of the bike would be the acknowledgment.    If you don't return the bike, it would charge your card aka ask for a retransmission of said packet.  That's all I have for now.
Stalls that allow people to rent and drop off bicycles so they can get around the city without wasting gas and causing pollution. Implant GPS devices inside the bikes so they can't be stolen.

The idea is that free long term parking is offered at multiple nodes throughout the outskirts of the city. Within the city there are three primary modes of transport: public bicycles (if needed) for short distances between bus stops for medium distances and at key points throughout the city train stations for the longest stretches for cross city travel.
the sidewalks should move, and there should be bicycle lanes that move as well so that you can move on the double via the moving roads' motion and the bicycles' motion

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

There should be a place to rent bicycles for a nominal fee for a day like they do in the big cities. You can rent a bicycle and return it to any place that also rents the same bicycles. You could also rent scooters to be able to do small errands around town.
There should be government funding to give everyone bicycles.

There would be a pay-to-use bicycle system similar to the Citi bicycles in New York City. It would allow people to exercise while getting to their location quickly. It would also relieve traffic congestion.

This is a transportation system that delivers food directly to people's houses. It exists in a large city and people will use an App on their phones to get food delivered to their house. They can enter the restaurant, find out what they want, and someone will deliver the food item by any mean they choose whether it be car or bicycle or walking. The app will also store people's favorite orders at their restaurants so they don't have to think about what to order.

This is about a single user system. It is similar to a bicycle. But it's does not run on road. It has specific path made only for this vehicle like a railway track. The track has frictionless surface. The bottom of the vehicle is also frictionless. The vehicle does not have round wheels. But instead flat frictionless bottom (but also can be frictionless wheel). Vehicle does not need fuel. First we clips the vehicle to the track manually. We sit and unclip the vehicle from the track and apply some mechanical force just like in the bicycle to move forward. After that the vehicle moves without any force. Because there is no friction.We just sit and relax. When we apply brake, clips is attached the bottom of track and it stops. The track should be spread all across the city. Vehicle is portable. We take it from home or rent from government.

This would be a bike lane that would be protected from other vehicles. It would make biking more safe and efficient. Bicycles would move in one road and cars would be on a different one. Cars would have to give the right of way to bicycles.
Tracks built into the bicycle lanes on roadways that you can click a seat into and "ride" to your destination
Use bicycles as the exclusive form of transportation. Get rid of all cars.
We have to introduce the use of bicycles in our locality
ROAD TRANSPORT - BICYCLE (GOOD EXERCISE FOR OUR WHOLE BODY, LOW COST AND NO POLLUTION.

There should be a place to rent bicycles for a nominal fee for a day like they do in the big cities. You can rent a bicycle and return it to any place that also rents the same bicycles. You could also rent scooters to be able to do small errands around town.

A bus that is programed to do the fastest route possible for what people need. There is a station where they push their destination, and a program figurs out who needs to go where and the best way to do it. Reduces wait time and makes more people want to use it.
A large network of rails traveling from downtown to every other part part of the surrounding area featuring energy efficient, sleek that arrive every ten to twenty minutes at each station

A light rail from city center to neighboring suburbs that would replace thousands of commuters and make rush hours less crowded and stressful. This could be as simple as one station in each suburb (thus 10-15 total stations), or a more complex system with multiple stations in each suburb.
A motorized scooter program where  you can rent them from stations throughout the city.

A new transportation system for my neighborhood would be a uber-like bus service. Buses have specific routes, and can stop at any point on that route if you use the service. That way you can have one pick you up close to your house instead of having to drop your car off at a bus station.

A new transportation system in my neighborhood would be rentable bicycle stations! They would be scattered all over the city.  You would simply put change into a machine or swipe a credit card and a bike would unlock.  You could then use it to ride all over the city.  You could return it to any other rental rack.  The racks would also have hand sanitizers and wipes so you could wipe down the public bikes before using them.  This would greatly reduce gas and emissions in the city and people would get good exercise biking around!

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.
A rent a bike system. Solar powered bikes could be rented for 1$ and returned at different stations for a refund of 1$.

A station with a tube in the ground with a high speed pod that would shoot me at a quick speed across the city or across the country in a couple hours. It would be faster than an airplane and safer too.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.
A system of mopeds that you leave at different stations and ride around on only paying to rent them
A tram system that is operated by a robot where you can stop as you please and not at stations

A trolley system would be a great source of transportation, using small trolleys instead of buses.  Another Idea would be a mini bus system that primarily transported people to key areas like the train station or the airport.  A shuttle system.

Although nationwide there has been a rise in alternative fuel sources, there is absolutely no support for that in my city. I think there should be an alternative fueling station installed to get people interested in adopting these technologies, and to show local support for the progressive idea.

An electric monorail with a few cars that travel between the shopping center about a mile a way from us through the little downtown and stopping at the regional rail station a mile the other direction from us. It would have 2 or 3 trains that run back and forth all day and night transporting people between those two major zones in our neighborhood, eliminating the need for cars to travel nearby.

An idea for getting around my city would be public Segways or other riding devices that you could take from station to station and plug back into a machine to charge up.  Obviously, anti-theft measures would have to be in place, but this could be really great in helping people get around.

An underground Seqway track which will take a while to build but will be extremely beneficial. There are no turns as underground paths are completely straight. Recharger stations are at every mile or two. There are practically no intersections or traffic lights except at major hubs, which are few and far between. Delivery services such as mail and UPS are a major component of this transportation system, which will make them faster and clear up traffic on major roads.

As a former city dweller who is now car-less in suburbia, I dream of a system of autonomous cars. The cars are available at convenient stations, much like bike rental stalls in cities. They are non-polluting. Anyone with a smart phone and account can book a ride at any time. Ride sharing is also available. These cars can have a pod design, though larger vehicles are available for people who need to transport larger items or many items. They accept voice commands, so programming is easy, and the cars can take you to almost any destination. Links to other transportation hubs, like trains and buses, are also available. The car doesn't need to be returned to its original location, just to another station. The vehicles are always well maintained and reliable, plus the service is affordable to most.
Automated Bicycle Rental Station. When i was visiting colorado i was so fascinated to see that they had Bicycle Rental Station nearly everywhere.  That be so cool to have in my city!

Automated taxi service. Would have several dispatch stations in key areas of city. Person could call for a ride from an app on their phone and it would send a car to them. The software could calculate rate for the trip and make you pay before as a confirmation before sending a car out. Car could then drive customer to said destination.  Self driveable cars that could provide a much better service than the often RUDE cab drivers could provide. Plus, I trust a robot way more than some of these morons driving!
biking system, where people can rent bikes and use them and drop them off at other stations.

Buses that have the ability to carry bikes for their customers.

Many people don't live next to a bus station and ride their bikes there so if the bus had a place for the bikes it would really help the customers out.
Charging station for electric cars that also has lots of electronic device chargeers.

Express subway lines would be nice.  WMATA is a terrible system.  But I'd be happy if we could get some sidewalks and bike lanes in our neighborhood.  A real help would be a circulator bus system for the neighborhoods surrounding our subway station.  The current system runs point to point and doesn't reduce car trips to the grocery store and local mall.
extremely light rail. People hop into 1 person rail cars that take up less room than a bike lane. There would be no waiting at the rail station because it leaves as soon as you get in.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.
High speed trains to commute into Chicago from various cities throughout northwest Indiana, with sleek train stations that include lots of amenities (coffee shops, dry cleaning, etc.)

Hoverboard/Segway share: have stations located around the neighborhood where a hoverboard or a segway can be left to charge and then someone else can use it, leaving it at another station for someone else to use.

How about a rent-a-Segway system?  Kind of like Zipcars or the bicycle rentals in big cities - you could pick up a Segway at a docking station in one part of town and then drop it off at one in another part of town.  You would probably need some sort of point of sale system for a deposit on the Segway, but otherwise the city could price it however they wanted.

I live in a neighborhood near an excellent metro system, but not walkable to it. I would like a people-mover sort of system that travels through the neighborhood making the existing metro station more accessible. Perhaps small cars or pods at the end of each street that travel along an elevated rail directly to the metro station.

I often thought that a sort of ski lift-type system would work well to carry people from my neighborhood to downtown.  You would board a continuously running chair on wire, and then would be transported to a downtown station riding on the chair over the city. Would take ten minutes max to board and 10-15 minutes to go downtown.

I think high-speed tube travel would be great in my city. The tubes could be a system of plastic or rubber tubes that were buried underground. There would be a lot of tube stations downtown, but they would branch off to the outer city and suburbs. These tubes would have pods in them that were propelled by high-pressured air. The pods could be designed to carry one or two people each, and would be shot through the tubes for quick travel to your destination.

I think we could bring back the streetcar in queens where the subway has low coverage. The streetcar would connect to the subway system which would be entirely rebuilt to accommodate new clean stations with solar panels and zero carbon foot print. This would connect with commuter and regional trains that would operate on an hourly scale.
I would have the Metro system extended further into Virginia to lessen the commute time.  I would also call for train stations that were more accessible and uses solar energy predominantly.

I would imagine an electric scooter or hoverboard rental system.  You could use them when going to and from a train station stop and to your final destination.  I imagine a rental system so that you could pick one up at a train or bus station to go your extra distance and return it when you return.  Renting would be a good option if you did not have your own with you or only use it with other public transportation. Bad weather is always an issue using these devices.

I would like to see a high speed train connect all the major cities in my state as well as the major cities bordering our state.  I envision this high speed train to have minimal stations.  This would eliminate the need for air travel and long road trips.

I would like to see a system built around "people movers" - similar to the ride that was once at Disneyland.  It would run underneath the ground - under the traffic.  Each car would hold one or two people with large reclining chairs and a docking station for your laptop so you can watch movies, play games or actually do work.
I would like to see lightrail or street cars inbny neighbor hood.   Something that was powered in part by alternative energy.  Solar panels on the stations, perhaps on top of the light rail cars.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

I would love individual Segway transporters that would go from the house to the transit station.  They would just fit one person and keep them dry.  Only about 1 mile but just far enough in the rain not to walk.  Once at the transit station, the train takes you directly every 5 minutes into the city.

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town. 



One thing that may be neat would be large sidewalks where people could ride bikes/scooters/walk and avoid using a vehicle.
