I'm imagining a car sharing service with locations throughout the city where you can go pick up a car without having to reserve one in advance. Nor would you have to interact with any people at the pickup/dropoff location. It would be somehow automated. Perhaps you would subscribe to the service an at annual or monthly rate and be given a special kind of 'key' that would give access to any of the cars currently at the pick up location. It would be first come first serve, and there would be smart technology embedded in both the cars and the keys. Your universal key would be linked to your account, and the car you used would transmit all relevant information to the system. Such as , time of pick up. number of miles drive. amount of gas used. Then the fees would be adjusted accordingly based on the type of car you used, miles driven, gas consumed etc. all of this without any human employees and all the fuss that comes with tradiional car rental. Things like insurance and billing info would all be done upfront when a patron sets up an account. This is genius, the more i think about it!

Then the fees would be adjusted accordingly based on the type of car you used, miles driven, gas consumed etc. all of this without any human employees and all the fuss that comes with tradiional car rental. Things like insurance and billing info would all be done upfront when a patron sets up an account. This is genius, the more i think about it!

A moving sidewalk - like the ones you would see in an airport to help expedite movement between terminals.  Around my area there are a lot of close shops, so people could walk, but getting loads of bags home would be difficult.  Having mechanical walkways would enable people to do their shopping but reduce their need to use cars, and at the same time set all their bags down so they don't have to figure out how to lug them home, especially if they've purchased something heavy.  It could also allow people to get where they need to go faster, if they continue to walk along the moving sidewalk.  They could sit alongside regular sidewalks, so people who still wanted to go out for a walk and get some fresh air could do so.  The mechanical/moving sidewalks would be made out of metal, look like a flat escalator, have hand railings, and each side of the road would have a sidewalk that goes the same way as traffic.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

I think a great idea within my neighborhood would basically to have a moving sidewalk like you would find at an airport.  This would allow people to move about faster than maybe they would walking, so people wouldn't feel the need to get in the car to go down the block to the store.

I wish we had a monorail between the airport and our city. We aren't connected to any public transportation system, but more than 70% of our residents travel by plane more than once a year. Many people travel for work, etc. Rather than each of us driving and paying to park our cars there, if we could stay in our suburb and take the monorail (or train) to and from it would save a great deal of money and time.

I would like to see a short-term car rental service with semi-autonomous driving. For example, if I needed to go to the airport and didn't want to leave my current car in a parking lot their I could rent a car that I could summon with a smartphone app. The car would be able autonomously drive directly to me or a location I choose through the app. After I was at the location of my choosing and no longer needed the car, I could then use the app to send the car away.

If we could be so technologically advanced to create giant versions of the airport conveyor belts where humans are carried across, that would be my new method of transportation. Since people are mostly lazy and want something to do the work for them (hence the upcoming popularity of the hands-free segway), this would be perfect to eliminate at least a fourth of the traffic on the street from cars.

my neighborhood future transportation system will be made up of flying cars. This cars will be able to take off and land like helicopters. There will be no more traffic jams, traffic light, annoying speed limits and harassing cops. People will be able to travel to any part of the world without going through airports and flight connections. There will be new telecommunication and navigation technology that will help the drivers navigate safely without having mid air collisions and also mid air gas stations to refuel the cars.

A car that woeks with the magnetic forces of earth, applying a system that can take advantage of all the force that can be generated. It can also work with other alternative energies such as solar power or wind power. All of these energies mixed in one idea and also fossil fuels but to a minimum scale.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

An automated system of cabs. Not cars though, more like carriages driven by AI "Horses" (Imagine that new Harley electric motorcycle engine, in a short, small, bullet shaped car like you used to see on the SIDE of a motorcycle, pulling a carriage, with an AI brain controlling it). A system like this would have the novelty and functionality of pulling people when you wanted to, or you could just use the AI 'sidecar' to run courier errands on the ground for companies that wanted fast delivery. Think like Amazon drones without the flying, the noise or the whole 'being small enough to get shot down by a .22 and stolen' thing. It keeps the battery away from the passengers if there is ever a crash, too. Which is good because those things can explode sometimes. The best thing about it, though? When it's just moving small items around for parcel delivery, it's not wasting fuel hauling an empty cab around with it. I can't stand seeing people waste so much energy driving a giant SUV around with no passengers or cargo. That act alone should be a top priority for politicians pushing for environmental reform to be talking about.
Future transportation will be cleaner and more environmentally freindly. Cars will run on less fuel and will have better emissions

I feel that in the future there will be futuristic cars that will slowly evolve away from gasoline use more natural resources for fuel.  I think that the cars will continue to evolve into more sustainable, aerodynamic shapes and designs.

I'd like to see some sort of autonomous shared fleet of cars that are fueled in some sort of environmentally friendly way. Solar panels on the roof? Maybe bike pedaling inside if you want to exercise and provide a small amount of power? I feel like autonomous cars alone will save a ton of energy just by eliminating traffic jams. And cut down on wind resistance since you wouldn't need to keep the traditional design necessarily.

My mode of alternative transportation would include cars, buses, and trams running on solar energy in roadways. I'm unsure how it would work exactly, but if we could harness the power of the sun and build vehicles that have the panels either on them or in the tires it could remove the use of fossil fuels.

A monorail system that is above everyone.  There would be rail cars on it that go in a multitude of directions.  People can still use the other forms of transportation, but this form would be strictly for people looking to get around in the city.  They would park their cars before entering the city, and use this quick system for getting around.  No more crowded, expensive parking in the city.

An alternative transport that would be excellent would be a monorail in my city.  It could be run with electricity, with many train cars, and go along the main north south route.  You could get almost anywhere in quickly and easily if it went along that route.

An electric monorail with a few cars that travel between the shopping center about a mile a way from us through the little downtown and stopping at the regional rail station a mile the other direction from us. It would have 2 or 3 trains that run back and forth all day and night transporting people between those two major zones in our neighborhood, eliminating the need for cars to travel nearby.
Have a monorail system around town. It'll reduce pollution because people will have fun using it instead of driving their cars.

I think a monorail system or cable cars like you see on ski lifts would be quite useful. moving walkways enclosed in a plastic tunnel to protect from elements that would have heat or a/c depending on the season would be really cool as well.

I wish we had a monorail between the airport and our city. We aren't connected to any public transportation system, but more than 70% of our residents travel by plane more than once a year. Many people travel for work, etc. Rather than each of us driving and paying to park our cars there, if we could stay in our suburb and take the monorail (or train) to and from it would save a great deal of money and time.

The area is very car-dependent, but a train or monorail going down the middle or above the main highways would be a great way to travel down the expressways and parkways without having to depend on a car.

An underground tunnel system just for people, bikes and mopeds.  The idea is that all the cars and congestion can stay up above and people can safely walk or transport themselves around without worrying about cars and busses getting in the way or being run over by them.  Every so often there is a ramp that allows you to exit, as well as natural light through grates and proper ventilation.  It would also be a great way to get around when it snows.

autonomous vehicles abound. there are shared autonomous vehicles that can be called by neighborhood members. you may travel to destinations within your town only. the cost is shared by real estate tax. the benefit is a drastic reduction in traffic congestion, as much fewer cars are needed.

Have a system of sidewalk rail cars that attaches to the sidewalks of a city. Each rail car can carry passenger anywhere in the city to any destination and stop at any time on its route. This system of transportation will greatly reduce city congestion while doesn't interfere with any of the vehicles that are already on the road.
Helicopter based taxi that can be taken anywhere.  The roof tops will now be loading and unloading areas and it will free up car congestion.

I think that an interesting mode of transport in my mountain town would be a ski lift type system that runs behind the businesses on main street and stops at every corner. The reason for this is our huge lack of parking and the congestion that cars cause in the shopping district. It would be unusual and fun and it could connect to the large parking area at the convention center.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.
The future of transportation in my city is by having self-automated driverless cars. They would reduce the amount of traffic congestion and reduce the number of car accidents.

Have a business where drivers rent cars, for hours and not days. The cars can be electric cars. Make them the cheapest cars possible. Make it for around the metro area only - and have the credit card swiper built into the car itself. In other words If you rent three hours with the car, it goes dead until you pay for more time. If someone takes it out of the pre-defined boundaries  of the city the car goes dead. You would have these little rental kiosks set up all over the city.

I live in a neighborhood near an excellent metro system, but not walkable to it. I would like a people-mover sort of system that travels through the neighborhood making the existing metro station more accessible. Perhaps small cars or pods at the end of each street that travel along an elevated rail directly to the metro station.

I think a good idea will be to use electric cycles instead of a bike or a car in metros. They not only help in decreasing pollution as well as motivating people towards physical exercises.



A proper network of e cycles and connected to a main frame can be seen as a new transportation system emerging. Moreover this can also be used as a public transportation system by constructing cycle stands where they can be charged and the cost of public transport can be paid in the machine.

Chicago - Chicago has a great system and phenomenal public transport. As far as transportation though I wish the highways in the city acted like slotted cars, similar to trains in which in every highway entrance there would be a dedicated lane/railway for vehicles to travel at fast speeds like trains. This would reduce traffic and travel times.

I imagine a type of highway for bicycles where people can use on and off ramps easily to reach their destination. They wont have to worry about cars since its a bike only highway system. it will get people to their destination quicker since they dont have to stop at traffic lights and watch out for pedestrians.

I wish we had separate bicycle highways that were enclosed spaces, both heated and cooled for summer/winter. It would be a cheaper mode of transportation. There would be protection to prevent car vs bicycle accident, a major problem in our area. It would also be healthier and exercise for the day during a commute. I picture it being a rounded space that is clear so you can see your surroundings outside.

I would love to see the use of self propelled equipment like hover boards and such used to help decrease emissions from cars. Highways and roads could be established just for such travelors. and we would also save money on gas

The area is very car-dependent, but a train or monorail going down the middle or above the main highways would be a great way to travel down the expressways and parkways without having to depend on a car.
A high speed conveyor belt that travels through peoples' houses that can take people to city centers.

A high speed monorail system that winds its way through all the important points of interest in the city. It would look futuristic and high tech with a sophisticated level of design along with being reliable.
A high speed train/subway that links all the cities in the Detroit metro area.

A new system of transporation in my neighborhood that I would really enjoy is high speed trains that could get you from one part of the city to  another in 5 minutes. The transportation would have ample amount seating for the fast trip and great views of the city. I would want for this train to run above the streets and not over the streets so some kind of over ground railway would have to be created.

A station with a tube in the ground with a high speed pod that would shoot me at a quick speed across the city or across the country in a couple hours. It would be faster than an airplane and safer too.

An elevated wagon wheel shaped, high speed rail system would be excellent. The outer ring would be bi-directional allowing quick transport around the city. The spokes would be bi-directional and allow quick transport from inner and outer within the quadrants.

Elon Musk's Hyperloop, Hi speed trains traveling in tubes above the city.
High speed trains to commute into Chicago from various cities throughout northwest Indiana, with sleek train stations that include lots of amenities (coffee shops, dry cleaning, etc.)

I can imagine my neighborhood having a high speed maglev train. It will levitate on top of a rail that will span around the entire city to avoid traffic. It will be fast and efficient to provide good transportation services.

I see a totally different way of transportation in the future. I see solar a powered tram replacing all the buses and since the cost is so much lower there will be many more of them so you can get anywhere you want to go anytime. In addition to the in city tram there will be a super high speed solar powered train that can go 150 mph or more! That will make it so what used to be a 2 hour drive or more will now be a short train ride away. For those who do not want to take the tram there will be an unmanned flying drone taxi. All you do it either tell it your destination or input the location yourself and it automatically takes you there.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

I would like to see a high speed train connect all the major cities in my state as well as the major cities bordering our state.  I envision this high speed train to have minimal stations.  This would eliminate the need for air travel and long road trips.

I'm envisioning a system of small feet-sized platforms, along with a handle at arm-height, running on street-level light rail tracks throughout the city. Like an escalator, these continuously run in a loop around the city/neighborhood, and passengers can jump on and off at will. (Access would be prepaid and mediated by a RFID chip card and scanner on the devices.) These would probably move at about 5-10 miles per hour - faster than regular walking, but slower than other forms of transport that require more infrastructure and potential for danger. It'd kinda be like, Razor scooters but built into the city landscape and available at-will. Like a bike-share system, but always there and with no energy or exercise expended. This would be a great way for tired people to avoid walking, and would speed up trips to the closest subway station/bus stop.

My city is currently looking at High Occupancy Travel toll lanes.  I've thought that a dedicated lane for buses or van pools would be an alternative that could let the car commuters see the speed at which these other options can get to work.  This would encourage the use of the bus / van pool options.

My neighborhood has little walk-ability due to poor road quality and an abundance of speed bumps. My Idea is simple in that they can add multiple lanes above the street for bikes and people walking. This would be on par with what cities have over major crossings but will cost relatively little money compared with adding a train or increasing the once daily buses. This would also allow any expansion of the roads under the walkways and reduce the 10 or so deaths a year from cars hitting people when they are just walking on the side of the road.

This idea is called 'Rolling taxi'. The system is a large ball. single large ball. Inside the ball, people can sit . People sit or stand at the centre of the ball. As ball rolls on specially made road the centre region doesn't move. The centre region where people sit is attached to the  inner surface of the ball in a special manner so that people do not move. The speed and direction of the ball can control using technology. The ball roll all across the city with people inside on a special track. Speed is high and expense is less. Also it is fun.

This might be only useful for some places, but it's better than none.  I think there should be a moving walkway for the most common areas of a town or city.  This way foot traffic can be consistent and the flow high.  Since it's fairly low speed there shouldn't be any injury issues and transferring is as easy as getting off the one walkway and on to another.

Tubes that are linked together and are wide enough to fit a person laying down. People get in a capsule and are delivered in great speeds to their destination by using compressed air or other methods. You can have tube terminals all over the city.

A Bus system, within the metro area that was funded by a tax on gas purchased by individual commuters. In otherwords, free to the people who use the bus, and costs the people who don't. have the busses rinning from a set time like 6am to 9 pm  and pickups are every 15 min, so you never need to bother with knowing the bus schedule. Also, have all busses make a stop in the center of town so if you need to get across town, take a bus from you house to the center, and from there to your final destination. There should be a bus passing every school, hospital, shopping center, library ect. Simply run smaller buses on less popular routes, use smaller buses in general. make one special route for city to city transfers. The system needs to be free or very affordable, fast and convenient. No need to waste resources and infrastructure on schedules, call centers, web pages, just keep it simple and convenient.

A circulatory bus system consisting of two vehicle traveling in opposite directions on a set route but with no designated stops. The route in my small district of the city takes approximately 20 minutes to to circumnavigate and consists of goth commercial districts. One would never be more than 10 minutes fro being able to hail the "jitney" bus. This alleviates the use of regular bus system which is much more focused on funneling clientele to central city and runs more or less eradicately.It envisions using current tech and is human centered. It is innovative in it's goals not hardware.

a subway type system that would have personal cars for people.  after typing in your destination, the car you were in would choose the quickest route within the city system of tracks permitted to get you to your destination. futuristic.

An alternative transport that would be excellent would be a monorail in my city.  It could be run with electricity, with many train cars, and go along the main north south route.  You could get almost anywhere in quickly and easily if it went along that route.

An overhead puppy cart system, the same concept as in skii resorts. I live in NYC, and outside of traveling by train, there are no other practicals transportation which avoids traffic. Unlike the the train system, you would be able to make direct routes, with a bonus of great views around the city

AutoTram - The network of AutoTram tracks criss-cross major streets and also cut across the city in subterranean tunnels. Instead of larger vehicles that carry many people, but have rigid, pre-defined routes, the AutoTram is reserved through the internet, and will pick up and drop off several small groups of passengers who have stops along an arithmetically chosen route.

Have a system of sidewalk rail cars that attaches to the sidewalks of a city. Each rail car can carry passenger anywhere in the city to any destination and stop at any time on its route. This system of transportation will greatly reduce city congestion while doesn't interfere with any of the vehicles that are already on the road.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.
More bike routes around the city for better and eco-friendly travel.
pod like stock cars for city that run on electric. They can be in routes and be like taxis but driverless.

Segways!  Segway sidewalks that go over streets and above the normal sidewalks people walk on so you can ride your segway without stopping for traffic or having to worry about a pedestrian taking up space to get by. Segway sidewalks can even run on the edge of a major highway in bigger cities like mine to keep routes short and simple. We can even make the segways charge on solar power so they will never go dead while you're out running about.

The future of transport in my city is likely a self driving car service system. There will be kiosks with cars waiting and you simply go into the car, put your destination into a computer and pay. It is as simple as that. The self driving cars will know how to avoid traffic and accidents and will automatically take the shortest and most sensible route to any destination. The self driving car will allow for multiple passengers and the cars will vary in size.

There should be paid service for a bus route to pick up people who live right outside a city. I will use my self as an example for my idea. I live about 20 miles for a major city . But there are plenty of people who would use a rural bus . A bus could pick up multiple people in the rural area. It's just very stupid that this is not a thing in Houston .

we need individual stand up scooters for citys almost like the 2 wheeled ones we have now but run on electric under the road, or even like personal unicycles that take people around. totally different topic how about Walmart allows you to make your shopping list online and they drop it off at your house on routes city distribution

Im from Seattle and it is mostly built over the top of the old city that burned down. I would think that they'd be able to build subways here at least through the downtown area where they have underground tours of the city.

It would be amazing if we had a subway in my city. It would go to good use and people would use cars less. Everyone drives around here because the bus system is lacking and public transport is difficult. We would benefit from a subway system.
my city needs a subway system badly. A subway system would run in a star shaped pattern through the city and eliminate the terrible traffic in my city

Railway tunnels off of the highways (outdoor subways) to provide a fast paced mode of transportation on busy streets that work with a system like uber that will have drivers readily available at each location. More for suburban areas, not large city areas that have subway/rail systems.

Some kind of public transportation like light rail that goes nearby would be ideal. If we could have a light rail or subway system that connects the city to the suburbs that would greatly improve the traffic situation.

We should have an underground subway system. For a city as large as the one I live in it would make sense. It would be faster for everyone and clear the roads of buses that clog up traffic during rush hour.
A motorized scooter program where  you can rent them from stations throughout the city.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

I would like to imagine being able to create a app and that uses credit cards. and invent a motorcycle scooter that has a huge row of seats in the back and runs like a mini van and use it as a taxi service. for only the city that I live in and name it Go Scooter transportation.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

A high speed monorail system that winds its way through all the important points of interest in the city. It would look futuristic and high tech with a sophisticated level of design along with being reliable.

A monorail system that is above everyone.  There would be rail cars on it that go in a multitude of directions.  People can still use the other forms of transportation, but this form would be strictly for people looking to get around in the city.  They would park their cars before entering the city, and use this quick system for getting around.  No more crowded, expensive parking in the city.

A mutli-layed monorail system that is solar and wind powered. I leave in las vegas, which has a centralized population. It would go up and down the strip and between the strip and downtown and around the city.

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.

An alternative transport that would be excellent would be a monorail in my city.  It could be run with electricity, with many train cars, and go along the main north south route.  You could get almost anywhere in quickly and easily if it went along that route.

I want a monorail system to run above street level (may be 20 feet up or so).  I want it to connect the suburbs to downtown, and circle the city.  It would run on magnets so that it would be extremely quiet.  It would be extremely fast.  I want it to provide a bird's eye view for commuters.  It would be a very safe way to travel, crime and personal safety would not be an issue.

I wish we had a monorail between the airport and our city. We aren't connected to any public transportation system, but more than 70% of our residents travel by plane more than once a year. Many people travel for work, etc. Rather than each of us driving and paying to park our cars there, if we could stay in our suburb and take the monorail (or train) to and from it would save a great deal of money and time.

Monorail through the city! Just like Disneyland, this city-wide system allows you to see the city from a bird's eye! Simply get on at one of the many stations around town and enjoy your ride without stops, traffic or bad weather. The rails above the city means growth can continue without getting in the way of transport, and means you can watch the world below!
My city needs a monorail that transports people from the suburbs to downtown and vice versa. the highways are not very good at providing an efficient way. A monorail would be fast and perfect

A sort of rail line, but it's a single rail and has many hanging carts. The carts hold maybe 4 people at a time, like a taxi. The price would be cheaper than a bus and they would arrive quickly when you need them. You could push a button on poles that are located around the city, far more often than bus stops, and the cart will come to you quickly and take you directly to your destination. No need for bus drivers or waiting for traffic!

A walking pathway across every rooftop in the city.   It would cut down on danger from cars, and it'd be fun to see the scenery.  This could easily be constructed with some good, sturdy planks.  Line them up on the roof, screw them in or hammer them in.  Every building would have a fire escape on it for easy access back to the street.  This would save much time as you could go "as the eagle flies." straight across the roofs.
Electric skate line that is powered throughout the whole city.
I imagine a train line that rings the entire city, with interstitial lines to service the downtown areas.

I live in a rural community about 1 hour from a city. I would like to see this area build a light rail commuter line that could link these isolated communities and boost the economy. Many people out here do not even have cars.

I live in the suburbs so all the rail lines converge on the central city. It would be nice if there was a light rail system that linked the different major suburbs together. You could connect it to the lines going to the city and across the country.

I picture a streamlined 'box' like a cable car that is hanging from a line or track throughout the city. It would be shaped like a rectangle with smooth edges and very compact and sleak. It glides up to the booth where people may get on and each cable car 'box' can hold 6 people in 3 rows of 2 with a small walking aisle to the side.

My city would benefit from an elevated and enclosed train line. Regional rail is the preferred choice for many commuters but is unreliable and frustrating due to weather and traffic related delays. Though the infrastructure investment would be great, we are in need of an overhaul anyway and should improve the current system.

To help cover a lot of area of a city, the could be a central hub where all the trains, busses, etc start.  Then from that one spot, all the route lines shoot out, like a star.  That way all the people can be at one spot and make it to where they want to go easily since there are no transfers or any other confusing things.

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.

Hoverboards that really move along and can occupy the bike lanes in some major cities would help unclog pedestrian side walks. Lnaes for Elf cars and Fred Flintstone type vehicles. More companies should be like Google and provide transportation for their employees. Hoover boats that glide across bays 10 times faster that farries plowing throw the water.

I imagine a series of widening arches or loops of roadway and of several different sizes to accompany different types of pubic transport. Cars wouldn't be allowed in the city but stored at various exit point garages which would be provided by the city. Small roads would have small shuttles, large roads would have large fast moving shuttles that span the city. Independently, smaller walkways would be used for pedestrians and cyclists (and other man powered or tiny engine machines.) Larger walkways could become festival street fair type roads that are common in places like Greece.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

I would love it if the city made walking and riding a bike more user friendly. There are no areas that are safe for pedestrians or bikers. If there were a bike lane, more people could move independently and get to where they are going. Commuters using more than one mode of transportation would be able to get to their destinations more quickly and with greater safety.

Segways!  Segway sidewalks that go over streets and above the normal sidewalks people walk on so you can ride your segway without stopping for traffic or having to worry about a pedestrian taking up space to get by. Segway sidewalks can even run on the edge of a major highway in bigger cities like mine to keep routes short and simple. We can even make the segways charge on solar power so they will never go dead while you're out running about.
There is no public transportation in my neighborhood. We do not even have sidewalks for pedestrians. It is a major problem that I wish could be fixed, but no one cares about rural cities.

Have the streets be less wide, in order to have small row gardens on the sides on the sidewalks. This interactive, edible walkway would promote and provide sidewalk snacks and usability. Easy fresh pick veggetables and fruits, less flooding and more city beauty!

I imagine a kind of moving walkway in the sky.  The moving walkway would be built on stilts above the ground. An individual can hop on the moving walkway and can walk to another part of the city, but at a faster rate than normal walking. This would encourage taking our own two feet as transportation.

I imagine a series of widening arches or loops of roadway and of several different sizes to accompany different types of pubic transport. Cars wouldn't be allowed in the city but stored at various exit point garages which would be provided by the city. Small roads would have small shuttles, large roads would have large fast moving shuttles that span the city. Independently, smaller walkways would be used for pedestrians and cyclists (and other man powered or tiny engine machines.) Larger walkways could become festival street fair type roads that are common in places like Greece.

I would like some sort of conveyor belt system or moving walkway (possibly with seats) in my city. It seems like it would be really nice for people, since people walk a lot here. Also, if there was a way to sit while moving, people could get work done and other things, while taking a 'slow ride' down the street (slower than a train, etc, so people can get on/ off while it's moving).

My neighborhood has little walk-ability due to poor road quality and an abundance of speed bumps. My Idea is simple in that they can add multiple lanes above the street for bikes and people walking. This would be on par with what cities have over major crossings but will cost relatively little money compared with adding a train or increasing the once daily buses. This would also allow any expansion of the roads under the walkways and reduce the 10 or so deaths a year from cars hitting people when they are just walking on the side of the road.

Public, foot-based transportation. Something like the automatic walkways in airports, but for long stretches of large cities, particularly between common high-traffic areas. It would probably be best if the walkways were raised, to avoid conflict with other ground traffic. It must also include access for the disabled, be easy enough for even tech-fearful users, and extremely safe (with monitored auto-shutoff where applicable).

This might be only useful for some places, but it's better than none.  I think there should be a moving walkway for the most common areas of a town or city.  This way foot traffic can be consistent and the flow high.  Since it's fairly low speed there shouldn't be any injury issues and transferring is as easy as getting off the one walkway and on to another.

A new transportation system in my neighborhood would be a railway system available to rural and outlying areas.  It would stretch along the roadway and connect to different cities and stops much like a trolley system or train system.  People could get on and off at different points.  They could schedule to be picked up at different times during the day.
A smart electric trolley hybrid system that is integrated with the current roadway network. The electric power for the network is generated by turbines in the city water supply.
I think a trolley system would work really well here. I live in Fort Collins and the city is very centralized but the traffic is terrible - perfect for a trolley!

I would like a city trolley. The trolley would travel around the city several times a day, taking and picking up residents from the major shopping areas. The trolley stops should be no more than two blocks from any neighborhood.
Something akin to a streetcar or trolley bus system could be very useful in my city.  It would have its own designated lane and be a useful public transportation alternative.

The new transportation is a light rail that also includes trolley service for my neighborhood and city. For $1.00 each way, the light rail runs from east to west and from north to south. In addition, the light rail runs until midnight Monday through Friday and 24 hours a day on weekends. The light rail takes you to all major events in the city and portion of all fares go to pay for school resources in the community.

We ought to revisit the trolley system because the buses in New York City are plagued by heavy traffic. We should have electric trolleys on main thoroughfares. It worked in the old days. Sometimes old ideas mixed with new technology is GENIUS!

An app based method of ride sharing public transit. City drivers in fuel efficient vans would respond to requested pick ups. The pick up requested by a rider would be assigned a pick up time within a short variable of the requested pick up (say 30 minutes), the van will pick up multiple parties near each other and drop them off at their destinations similar to the shared airport shuttles.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.
I always thought they should incorporate moving sidewalks into the city. Just like the airport. This would allow people to scoot around faster without putting more people on the road.

I wish we had a monorail between the airport and our city. We aren't connected to any public transportation system, but more than 70% of our residents travel by plane more than once a year. Many people travel for work, etc. Rather than each of us driving and paying to park our cars there, if we could stay in our suburb and take the monorail (or train) to and from it would save a great deal of money and time.

Moving sidewalks all over the city would be amazing. People could hop on and even sit and get to their destination.  They'd be like the ones in airports, but they would go faster.  Some could even run into and through tubes so people would be protected in bad weather.  Something like a gerbil habitat would be amazing.  I think it would promote people walking instead of driving.  Or, just standing on the moving sidewalks.  It would reduce pollution if people took things like this around the city.

Public, foot-based transportation. Something like the automatic walkways in airports, but for long stretches of large cities, particularly between common high-traffic areas. It would probably be best if the walkways were raised, to avoid conflict with other ground traffic. It must also include access for the disabled, be easy enough for even tech-fearful users, and extremely safe (with monitored auto-shutoff where applicable).

This is a hybrid airship. Technology has developed that allows these vehicles to be more compact and use hydrogen lift cells safely. There are dozens of air ferries lifting people quietly into the air and to major cities all across America. The carbon footprint of the consumer aviation industry is drastically reduced. The noise pollution of traditional airports is all but gone. The hybrid airship is the vehicle of choice in terms of transportation.
A public taxi system dedicated to public transportation.  Standard operating hours and funded through taxes.  On demand pick up via city based app.  Essentially eliminating everyday drivers.

An alternative transportation system in my neighborhood could involve something such as a taxi like service but one that ran kind of like a bus, involving general cars. These services could flow around the city and offer rides to people who may not be able to afford any other type of transportation.
Future transportation system in my neighborhood could be a electric bicycle taxi system where neighborhood resents can take shorts trips like the grocery store or sending kids off to school.

Handicapped taxi. Public transportation is awful in my area, so if you are in a wheelchair then you need an expensive handicapped van just to be able to get around. Some taxi wheelchair van options would be great for people who can't afford a $30,000 wheelchair van and might otherwise have a hard time getting around.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

I see a totally different way of transportation in the future. I see solar a powered tram replacing all the buses and since the cost is so much lower there will be many more of them so you can get anywhere you want to go anytime. In addition to the in city tram there will be a super high speed solar powered train that can go 150 mph or more! That will make it so what used to be a 2 hour drive or more will now be a short train ride away. For those who do not want to take the tram there will be an unmanned flying drone taxi. All you do it either tell it your destination or input the location yourself and it automatically takes you there.

I think driverless taxi services are going to be the dominant transportation systems in the future. Sort of like having a whole bunch of Uber drivers out there picking up whoever needs it. I don't think that vehicle ownership will be nearly as widespread as it is these days, as driverless cars will be far safer.

I think that a new mod of transportation in my neighborhood would be a electric bike taxi system. It would be an electric bike pulling a carriage that hold up to 3 other people. The system will travel from people's houses to their work place, local shopping centers and local entertainment places.

I would like to imagine being able to create a app and that uses credit cards. and invent a motorcycle scooter that has a huge row of seats in the back and runs like a mini van and use it as a taxi service. for only the city that I live in and name it Go Scooter transportation.

I would like to see an advanced transportation system that involved driverless cars.  The idea is the same as using a taxi but without a driver.  Like Uber, you would use your mobile device to order a car and control the experience.  The car shows up at your door, takes you to your destination and you are billed for the ride. It would save me thousands of dollars in the cost to own, maintain, insure and license my own personal car.

My city is right on the ocean and there are many canals within the city as well, so I think a kind of transportation system with water taxis or some kind of water buses would be really useful. In a lot of cases I think this kind of transportation would be faster and more accessible to people, especially if it was willing to pick people up at designated locations or even right off their own docks for those who have them.

School Bus taxi. School buses rumble down our street every day, often not every seat is taken. If you knew the route, and had been vetted through security, you could pay a small fare to hop on and ride along the route, even connecting to other school buses. It would be an energy-efficient mode of transportation. Also, more adults on the bus would probably reduce bullying among the kids.
Transportation by shopping cart taxis. It's fun, it's cheap, and it'll certainly get the kids on board.

Transportation that would allow people to rent out electric self driving cars. This would let people have cars pick them up at whatever location they want and have the car autonomously drive to their destination. Similar to a fleet of self driving electric taxis. This would greatly reduce the cost of transportation in my opinion because people would not have to buy cars but could rather rent or lease them.

A new transportation system for my neighborhood would be a uber-like bus service. Buses have specific routes, and can stop at any point on that route if you use the service. That way you can have one pick you up close to your house instead of having to drop your car off at a bus station.

An app that worked somewhat like Uber, but is for ride-sharing/car pooling.  You put in your destination, whether you can drive or not, what time you need to be to your destination, and an acceptable range for the location.  The app would look for others with similar destinations or destinations en-route for others as well as the best route to minimize drive time, but maximize people getting to their destination.  Then the app would calculate a fair percentage of the ride cost for each person based on their destination, travel distance, etc.  Public transportation here isn't great because we are so spread out.  After each ride you could rate other passengers and the driver and those ratings could be used to filter out bad users entirely or just below a certain rating level.

An overhead puppy cart system, the same concept as in skii resorts. I live in NYC, and outside of traveling by train, there are no other practicals transportation which avoids traffic. Unlike the the train system, you would be able to make direct routes, with a bonus of great views around the city

Companies should use some of their advertising budget to provide rides to certain places.  This would double as advertising for that company, so they would not lose out on money and we could get unique transportation for several untapped routes, especially if it is discovered that a lot of people are traveling outside of their usual living area, like for a special event.  The companies could create specialized buses so that several people can ride, and can put their logo on the outside of the bus and could name the transportation something catchy using the company name so that word-of-mouth provides extra advertising.

Have a system of sidewalk rail cars that attaches to the sidewalks of a city. Each rail car can carry passenger anywhere in the city to any destination and stop at any time on its route. This system of transportation will greatly reduce city congestion while doesn't interfere with any of the vehicles that are already on the road.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

I imagine a way to ride a school bus to various spots on its route. You would be pre-screened as an adult who could act as a school bus monitor and at the same time gain transportation to a location near the school. It would solve the problem of kids riding unsupervised and give another public transportation option in the neighborhood.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I think a private school bus would be a great idea. Maybe it could be the size of a SUV and fit maybe 4 to 6 kids in it comfortable. Some kids are not able to take a bus to school so parents have to take public transportation every morning to drop them off. It could be like a Uber school bus sort of, each SUV bus will have certain school on their route that they can drop kids off at.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town. 



One thing that may be neat would be large sidewalks where people could ride bikes/scooters/walk and avoid using a vehicle. The main road is fairly busy, and there are quite a few shops around that would be more accessible if we had better transportation than just getting in a car! (Boardman, OH). Little scooters with solar power charging stations would be neat.

My town is in desparate need of a form of public transportation. Everyone is reliant on a car or scooter. I think they don't have enough need to  warrant a bus route, but I'm in favor of widening the tiny bicycle lanes they have.

School Bus taxi. School buses rumble down our street every day, often not every seat is taken. If you knew the route, and had been vetted through security, you could pay a small fare to hop on and ride along the route, even connecting to other school buses. It would be an energy-efficient mode of transportation. Also, more adults on the bus would probably reduce bullying among the kids.

There should be paid service for a bus route to pick up people who live right outside a city. I will use my self as an example for my idea. I live about 20 miles for a major city . If I didn't have a automobile I would not be able to get anywhere important. Now the nearest cilty has a bus route only for those in the city. But there are plenty of people who would use a rural bus . A bus could pick up multiple people in the rural area. The school bus service already does this , I don't know why the city could come up with a plan to offer public transportation for adults living in rural areas. It's just very stupid that this is not a thing in Houston .

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

A network of green transportation for rent. You insert coins and it releases a bike, a skateboard, a scooter or some other form of efficient transportation. You drive it to your destination and once you deliver it to the hotpspot you can get your money back, if it is in good condition.

A new transportation system for our neighborhood could be shared scooters.  The scooters would be open for all to use and stocked at locations around the neighborhood.  You could check them out and return them for less money than the cost of a scooter.

I was thinking of underground tunnels that you could access from certain points -- not for a subway. Instead, you get in the tunnels and you have the option to take various tunnels to certain destinations using your preferred mode of transportation: razor scooter, roller-blades, running/walking. You can check out a scooter at an entrance, drop it off at your destination. that way you never have to bring it with you, the entrances would have them on hand. or you can just run/walk if you want and it would be out of the cold/hot/rain/snow/sun, etc...

I would imagine an electric scooter or hoverboard rental system.  You could use them when going to and from a train station stop and to your final destination.  I imagine a rental system so that you could pick one up at a train or bus station to go your extra distance and return it when you return.  Renting would be a good option if you did not have your own with you or only use it with other public transportation. Bad weather is always an issue using these devices.

I would like to imagine being able to create a app and that uses credit cards. and invent a motorcycle scooter that has a huge row of seats in the back and runs like a mini van and use it as a taxi service. for only the city that I live in and name it Go Scooter transportation.

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town. 



One thing that may be neat would be large sidewalks where people could ride bikes/scooters/walk and avoid using a vehicle. The main road is fairly busy, and there are quite a few shops around that would be more accessible if we had better transportation than just getting in a car! (Boardman, OH). Little scooters with solar power charging stations would be neat.

In the future, there will be electric powered vehicle system. There will be transportation centers with different sized vehicles for rent for a small fee. The vehicles will range in size from one person scooters to six person vehicles. They will be rented on an hourly basis.

it'd be cool to have a rent a shop throughout the city for people who aren't able to afford bicycles or scooters, or any other sort of transportations. the can rent an item, and return it at the other part of town.

My town is in desparate need of a form of public transportation. Everyone is reliant on a car or scooter. I think they don't have enough need to  warrant a bus route, but I'm in favor of widening the tiny bicycle lanes they have.
Scooter would be great transportation for college kids and busy cities.

Take the train  to its nearest destination  to your destination.  Get off the train, and rent a bike or scooter to take you to your exact location.  Drop off the bike there, and it's waiting for you for your return trip to the train.  Monthly passes cover all types of transportation and cards are used for bus, train, bike and scooter use.
A well established public transport system, like subway, will ease the transportation problem. It will save energy and make fewer cars on the road.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.

Having some sort of electric train that runs underground, just like the subway system in New York. The city that I currently live in doesn't have that option so having some sort of underground transportation system that runs all around the city constantly would make commuting much better for everyone.

I am from Cincinnati, and one new mode of transportation that would be great here is a subway system. Tunnels already exist from a failed project decades ago, but with the growth the city has seen, it could be a viable option.

I have seen a lot on the news lately about 'self-driving' cars, and I think it would be neat if this technology could someday be applied to public transportation. I think 'self driving' buses would be an excellent mode of transportation. I think this would be particularly useful for smaller cities or towns that can't afford to have subway systems. Self driving buses could be programmed to stop at every stop timely and efficiently and could save the city money by eliminating the need to hire drivers and would cut out the issue of human error when it comes to being on time, not showing up for work, or causing accidents.

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

I think a form of public transportation could be an electric type of subway that runs on a non intrusive track layed into the pavment much like a train track. It could be shaped like a normal subway but on the roof space there would be solar panels to generate electricity needed to run. Any remaining power needed could be provided by the tracks.

I was thinking of underground tunnels that you could access from certain points -- not for a subway. Instead, you get in the tunnels and you have the option to take various tunnels to certain destinations using your preferred mode of transportation: razor scooter, roller-blades, running/walking. You can check out a scooter at an entrance, drop it off at your destination. that way you never have to bring it with you, the entrances would have them on hand. or you can just run/walk if you want and it would be out of the cold/hot/rain/snow/sun, etc...

Railway tunnels off of the highways (outdoor subways) to provide a fast paced mode of transportation on busy streets that work with a system like uber that will have drivers readily available at each location. More for suburban areas, not large city areas that have subway/rail systems.

Some kind of public transportation like light rail that goes nearby would be ideal. If we could have a light rail or subway system that connects the city to the suburbs that would greatly improve the traffic situation.

Subway that takes you straight to downtown. It would be the best transportation to get to downtown without any traffic to watch football games get to work and other activities. I think a lot more people would be traveling this way.

A new transportation system in my neighborhood could be the use of drones to fly individuals in and around town, or to far off destinations. The drones would fly like helicopters, but can  can also be controlled using a remote control. Unlike a car which can transport several passengers, the drone would be only be able to transport one person.

An app that worked somewhat like Uber, but is for ride-sharing/car pooling.  You put in your destination, whether you can drive or not, what time you need to be to your destination, and an acceptable range for the location.  The app would look for others with similar destinations or destinations en-route for others as well as the best route to minimize drive time, but maximize people getting to their destination.  Then the app would calculate a fair percentage of the ride cost for each person based on their destination, travel distance, etc.  Public transportation here isn't great because we are so spread out.  After each ride you could rate other passengers and the driver and those ratings could be used to filter out bad users entirely or just below a certain rating level.

Have a system of sidewalk rail cars that attaches to the sidewalks of a city. Each rail car can carry passenger anywhere in the city to any destination and stop at any time on its route. This system of transportation will greatly reduce city congestion while doesn't interfere with any of the vehicles that are already on the road.

Have a transportation system in the city where there is a tunneling system filled miniature train with small passenger capacity. I am visually a bus like transportation system that travels on something like rails which are suspended from above.  The rails are not supported by concrete systems from below.  Specialized buses will travel on these rails without causing disruption of regular road traffic.  When it nears a bus stop, the bus will stop and drop itself down to the level of the regular roads, open the door and let the passengers in and out.  Once the door closes it will climb up to the to the level of the suspended rails and travel forward on the rails.

I live near the water, so water transportation would be nice to have. It could be a system of ferries that can go from port to port, carrying passengers like a bus system. This would reduce the amount of cars on the road and the amount of traffic.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. Our society's population is expanding at a rapid rate. The typical modern day modes of transportation, while convenient, have a few downsides.  Every mean of transportation, with the exception of walking, has costs that come with it.  This ranges from having to pay for the cost of gas to paying the physical price of not getting the proper amount of exercise our bodies where meant to have via walking to our destinations. There is one option that could solve these issues.  Imagine a small grass field, similar to the ones you find at playgrounds, with a small parking lot.  Within this parking lot would be a couple of electric powered cars attached to power stations. These setups would be available every few blocks (about as frequent as modern bus-stops). Within the field beside the cars stations would be stationary work out equipment. These would be modeled after the free-to-use exercise stations in places like China. They would have equipment such as: bench presses, ellipticals, bikes, etc.  All of these would be wired underground to the charging station attached to the cars. The energy created from the movement of each device will directly charge the cars in the station.  Off to the side of each piece of equipment would be a touchscreen. A person can set up an account at their local government buildings, providing a valid driver's license,e-mail address, and credit or debit card number. When signed in, each account can track how much a person exercised and convert it to an 'available miles for usage' number.  This means that the more a person uses this equipment, creating more energy for the cars, the more miles the person would be allowed to use the car for.  This however also means, that prior to using the car they would have to deduct the amount of miles they plan to use from their account.  If the person should go over their allotted miles, they will then be subsequently charged on their provided credit card.  This encourages people to work-out more at these stations, so they can avoid the fees for using the car. This set-up would immensely help those who financially can't afford their own form of transportation, while promoting a healthier lifestyle in a way that could easily fit into our society's demanding everyday regime.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.
