They would run quickly perhaps so that  a trolley will collect people and head to its destination every 15 minutes.  It makes short transportation to hub areas cleaner, safer, and nicer, and can be closed during non-business hours of the hub area.

An underground Seqway track which will take a while to build but will be extremely beneficial. There are no turns as underground paths are completely straight. Recharger stations are at every mile or two. There are practically no intersections or traffic lights except at major hubs, which are few and far between. Delivery services such as mail and UPS are a major component of this transportation system, which will make them faster and clear up traffic on major roads.

As a former city dweller who is now car-less in suburbia, I dream of a system of autonomous cars. The cars are available at convenient stations, much like bike rental stalls in cities. They are non-polluting. Anyone with a smart phone and account can book a ride at any time. Ride sharing is also available. These cars can have a pod design, though larger vehicles are available for people who need to transport larger items or many items. They accept voice commands, so programming is easy, and the cars can take you to almost any destination. Links to other transportation hubs, like trains and buses, are also available. The car doesn't need to be returned to its original location, just to another station. The vehicles are always well maintained and reliable, plus the service is affordable to most.

I would say the biggest way to improve innovating is to have all new construction be made in regards to current public transporation hub and those that cnanot be require them to build a public transportation hub. So all new communities have bus access or train access.
Public skype/facetime stations in major transportation hubs (bus or train stations, airports).

This transportation system would be the most spectacular to the entire neighborhood. It is a neighborhood vehicle hub system. It is a hub where everyone with an android or ios or windows phone can open an app and rent out a car or a bike to use around the neighborhood with the additional benefit on these hubs being eco friendly public restrooms with vending machines for those that wish to travel locally and have the munchies.

A form of transportation similar to an airlift, only the seats are at terminals on the ground. You board and they take you to predesignated stops in a direct line, free of traffic. Like a shuttle or train, only on a smaller scale, and ideally seats come in much more frequently, every 30 seconds or so.
A new transportation system  can be something somewhat like a train, but a small train like shuttle, which can take others around the neighborhood, easy, fast and no traffic.

A trolley system would be a great source of transportation, using small trolleys instead of buses.  Another Idea would be a mini bus system that primarily transported people to key areas like the train station or the airport.  A shuttle system.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

What we need is a better public transportation system that services the East end of the city.  Perhaps a bullet shuttle that will pick up in certain areas of the East End, and shuttle t predetermined locations within the city such as the downtown area, in addition to other areas.

I see solar a powered tram replacing all the buses and since the cost is so much lower there will be many more of them so you can get anywhere you want to go anytime. In addition to the in city tram there will be a super high speed solar powered train that can go 150 mph or more! That will make it so what used to be a 2 hour drive or more will now be a short train ride away. For those who do not want to take the tram there will be an unmanned flying drone taxi. In my neighborhood I think the best type of transportation system would be an elevated railway like a tram at disney world it would make commuting between neighboring cities far easier and the technology would make commutes more timely.

My mode of alternative transportation would include cars, buses, and trams running on solar energy in roadways. I'm unsure how it would work exactly, but if we could harness the power of the sun and build vehicles that have the panels either on them or in the tires it could remove the use of fossil fuels.

One Idea I've always had was sky trams. It would operate just like your traditional tram system but instead of a point A to point B ride. You would have an additional 5 to 10 stops on a linear path, to support the stops I would use a magnetic rail system, instead of the old wire cable system. This would cut down on over crowding in terms of public and private transportation.

Firefighters are using jet-packs in Dubai to combat fires in skyscrapers. I propose we use jet-packs for personal transport. It's hard enough to travel in big cities like Miami with all the traffic. Having your own jet pack allows you to literally fly away from a stressful situation such as sitting in traffic or waiting for public transportation. It will save time and is fun. This futuristic technology is here and it works.
THE ALTERNATIVE TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM IS VERY USEFUL TO TRANSPORT ALL THE PRODUCTS AND ITS TIME SAVING

There should be paid service for a bus route to pick up people who live right outside a city. I will use my self as an example for my idea. I live about 20 miles for a major city . If I didn't have a automobile I would not be able to get anywhere important. Now the nearest cilty has a bus route only for those in the city. But there are plenty of people who would use a rural bus . A bus could pick up multiple people in the rural area. The school bus service already does this , I don't know why the city could come up with a plan to offer public transportation for adults living in rural areas. It's just very stupid that this is not a thing in Houston .

This new transportation system is a bullet train in the sky, able to span around the neighborhood with up to 700 passengers in under two minutes. It's sleek silver coat is never late, and always early to make sure everyone gets where they need to go. The rails float there in the sky, ready to carry this majestic beauty to the ends of the neighborhood making sure everyone is early
Transportation by shopping cart taxis. It's fun, it's cheap, and it'll certainly get the kids on board.

Using boats to travel in Miami to beat the rush hour traffic. It's quite simple to travel anywhere in Miami by using the canals and various waterways. Boats or ferries should be used not just for sight seeing but for public transportation.

Chicago - Chicago has a great system and phenomenal public transport. As far as transportation though I wish the highways in the city acted like slotted cars, similar to trains in which in every highway entrance there would be a dedicated lane/railway for vehicles to travel at fast speeds like trains. This would reduce traffic and travel times.

I wish we had separate bicycle highways that were enclosed spaces, both heated and cooled for summer/winter. It would be a cheaper mode of transportation. There would be protection to prevent car vs bicycle accident, a major problem in our area. It would also be healthier and exercise for the day during a commute. I picture it being a rounded space that is clear so you can see your surroundings outside.

I would like to see a bicycle highway.  It would go the length of regular highways, but be for bikes and pedestrians.  It should be wide enough for fast moving road cyclist, it should have passing lanes, and little road crossings.  There should be frequent on and off ramps.  There should also be many large parking areas.  Ideally it would even lead to public transportation areas with ample bike parking.

My new transportation system would be a golf cart system. We have many elderly people who would enjoy being able to get around using golf carts. It would be a wa around the city without having to use the highway.

Railway tunnels off of the highways (outdoor subways) to provide a fast paced mode of transportation on busy streets that work with a system like uber that will have drivers readily available at each location. More for suburban areas, not large city areas that have subway/rail systems.

A Bus system, within the metro area that was funded by a tax on gas purchased by individual commuters. In otherwords, free to the people who use the bus, and costs the people who don't. have the busses rinning from a set time like 6am to 9 pm  and pickups are every 15 min, so you never need to bother with knowing the bus schedule. Also, have all busses make a stop in the center of town so if you need to get across town, take a bus from you house to the center, and from there to your final destination. There should be a bus passing every school, hospital, shopping center, library ect. Simply run smaller buses on less popular routes, use smaller buses in general. make one special route for city to city transfers. The system needs to be free or very affordable, fast and convenient. No need to waste resources and infrastructure on schedules, call centers, web pages, just keep it simple and convenient.

A bus that is programed to do the fastest route possible for what people need. There is a station where they push their destination, and a program figurs out who needs to go where and the best way to do it. Reduces wait time and makes more people want to use it.
A cab system which optimizes fares by calculating the best way to get multiple people to their destination. It's like a bus but it doesn't follow a route.

A circulatory bus system consisting of two vehicle traveling in opposite directions on a set route but with no designated stops. The route in my small district of the city takes approximately 20 minutes to to circumnavigate and consists of goth commercial districts. One would never be more than 10 minutes fro being able to hail the "jitney" bus. This alleviates the use of regular bus system which is much more focused on funneling clientele to central city and runs more or less eradicately.It envisions using current tech and is human centered. It is innovative in it's goals not hardware.
A new bus route that could go through my town. It would have a different route than the buses we currently have.

A new transportation system for my neighborhood would be a uber-like bus service. Buses have specific routes, and can stop at any point on that route if you use the service. That way you can have one pick you up close to your house instead of having to drop your car off at a bus station.

An uber-like system for public transit busses. Riders must request pick up 24 hours ahead of time, and the bus would come to their door or as close as it could to pick the rider up. The fare could be determined by how many riders requested pick up, and drop off to a central location (downtown). From there maybe there would be additional busses that go directly to drop off points rather than on a pre-set route.
buses should be branded by route, and have brightly colored easy to identify signs

Companies should use some of their advertising budget to provide rides to certain places.  This would double as advertising for that company, so they would not lose out on money and we could get unique transportation for several untapped routes, especially if it is discovered that a lot of people are traveling outside of their usual living area, like for a special event.  The companies could create specialized buses so that several people can ride, and can put their logo on the outside of the bus and could name the transportation something catchy using the company name so that word-of-mouth provides extra advertising.

First off, that's a really choppy question.



There could be a network of ride sharing. Sort of like if Uber was a bus. People would have a regular route and others would request a ride to a central location. It would be mostly people commuting to work together. This would be done through phone apps.

How about a deluxe line of buses. You have to pay 150 or above a month for a pass, but these run better routes, and they actually run on time. The regular monthly bus pass is 65, but the service is terrible. On this new route, absolutely no discounts, no half fares, no free rides. Always have security on the bus to get rid of the riff raff. This new deluxe bus wouldn't even share stops with the regular bus route.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

I imagine a way to ride a school bus to various spots on its route. You would be pre-screened as an adult who could act as a school bus monitor and at the same time gain transportation to a location near the school. It would solve the problem of kids riding unsupervised and give another public transportation option in the neighborhood.

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I think a private school bus would be a great idea. Maybe it could be the size of a SUV and fit maybe 4 to 6 kids in it comfortable. Some kids are not able to take a bus to school so parents have to take public transportation every morning to drop them off. It could be like a Uber school bus sort of, each SUV bus will have certain school on their route that they can drop kids off at.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town. 



One thing that may be neat would be large sidewalks where people could ride bikes/scooters/walk and avoid using a vehicle. The main road is fairly busy, and there are quite a few shops around that would be more accessible if we had better transportation than just getting in a car! (Boardman, OH). Little scooters with solar power charging stations would be neat.

It is not innovative in terms of the whole world, but would be very innovative in my community - bike shares. The area where I live is suburban, so difficult to get enough riders for frequent mass transit. And it's too spread out for just walking. Bike share stands, where subscribers had a code to access bikes from a bike locker, would allow people to commute from place to place (even just to nearby main bus routes) with relative ease.

Light rail. Basically, street card running between the most popular stops. They don't have to run everywhere, but on their routes they'd be more efficient than buses. You count put the rails on the side of the streets, near the sidewalks.

Mass transit only routes that expedite buses, bikes and High occupancy vehicles on smaller , yet more direct routes. Toll type control and monitoring. Make a single person in s single car very difficult and punitive

Since rail is very expensive, I'd like to see more express bus routes, hopefully with their own lanes to keep them flowing faster than traffic and give an incentive to use them.  Make the buses as comfortable as possible, again as an incentive for use.

We could have busses that worked like uber.  Instead of having specific spots, people could put in their location and where they want to end.  Then the busses would know when and who to pick up along constantly changing and evolving routes.

App integrated public & private transport, using location services in smartphones to sync to trains, buses, taxis, Ubers Zipcars etc to streamline travel. Using a global integrated app to pay for any type of transport service

I'd like to see the combination of a food truck and a taxi. This way you could grab a fresh made bite to eat while on your way to the destination. There would be a seating area in the front and a small kitchen with a service window in the back. This bus could serve hot and cold sandwiches and maybe drinkable soup in cups with lids to prevent spills. Now all you have to do is hail a cab. Forget finding something to eat then looking for the cab. The food can be prepared for you onboard.

My city is right on the ocean and there are many canals within the city as well, so I think a kind of transportation system with water taxis or some kind of water buses would be really useful. In a lot of cases I think this kind of transportation would be faster and more accessible to people, especially if it was willing to pick people up at designated locations or even right off their own docks for those who have them.

The city could do a partial co pay or cheap taxi or destination bus service. as in you meet the bus at a specific pick up place but then you tell the address you want, no designated stop.

There needs to be a new system that picks you up at your place. A bus system that you can call to pick you up and the closest one will come. Kind of like a taxi but a bus so it can carry a lot more people.

A bus that has a design similar to a hydrofoil boat. The bus would run on special tracks that would be parallel to each other on opposite sides of a street. This passenger compartment would be on top, with the "foils" connecting to the two tracks. There would be open space underneath the passenger compartment where the road is. This way, the bus could move unimpeded by traffic, while also not disrupting traffic itself. Also, passengers would not even see the traffic below them, making the ride smooth, comfortable, and consistent.
A bus with 8 off road tires and a strong engine that could easily get the passengers through even the snowiest of days. We can call it the Wolverine.

A concept similar to Uber, but with a bus. Especially in a city the socialization factor of riding with other passengers while going to a destination could be nice. You would be able to specifically request stops and pickups.
A more affordable public transit (or shuttle bus) that is crowdsourced/crowdfunded and takes passengers anywhere within a certain radius (e.g. 30 mile radius, etc.).

A pod/train system that runs on the shoulder of roads. It would be more active than typical buses, and be more personal in that there can be no more than 4 passengers. It would run on a track or in the future it would would run with automatic sensing software and would drive itself.
A tram in each Mohalla (Locality) that goes to a central place called Zero point and from there a common bus takes all the passengers that arrives in trams to the market.

A zip line from the place where I take the bus to the subway would be great. It would cut out all the traffic and possibly be much faster than taking the bus to the subway. Also, there would be multiple pods that would lock in the destination and go non-stop so it wouldn't be stopping every few minutes to pick up passengers.

I am visually a bus like transportation system that travels on something like rails which are suspended from above.  The rails are not supported by concrete systems from below.  Specialized buses will travel on these rails without causing disruption of regular road traffic.  When it nears a bus stop, the bus will stop and drop itself down to the level of the regular roads, open the door and let the passengers in and out.  Once the door closes it will climb up to the to the level of the suspended rails and travel forward on the rails.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. I think a bullet train would be very useful. A train that can transport passengers fast in between the major areas in the neighborhood, for example to schools, the downtown area, the performing arts theater, shopping districts, the airport etc. It doesn't have to stop very often like a bus but an instead be used for getting between major areas and can be supported by the bus system.
Vehicles that circle around a block, which allow for passengers to jump right on.  Not necessarily a bus.
A more affordable public transit (or shuttle bus) that is crowdsourced/crowdfunded and takes passengers anywhere within a certain radius (e.g. 30 mile radius, etc.).

An uber-like system for public transit busses. Riders must request pick up 24 hours ahead of time, and the bus would come to their door or as close as it could to pick the rider up. The fare could be determined by how many riders requested pick up, and drop off to a central location (downtown). From there maybe there would be additional busses that go directly to drop off points rather than on a pre-set route.

Currently, my city is very underserved by the public transportation system. I believe that the existing public transit should be expanded with a greater fleet of buses, so that all people in my community could be served. The buses currently in operation only reach about half (if that) of the city's occupants, leaving many without an opportunity to get where they need to go quickly and affordably.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.

It is not innovative in terms of the whole world, but would be very innovative in my community - bike shares. The area where I live is suburban, so difficult to get enough riders for frequent mass transit. And it's too spread out for just walking. Bike share stands, where subscribers had a code to access bikes from a bike locker, would allow people to commute from place to place (even just to nearby main bus routes) with relative ease.

Mass transit only routes that expedite buses, bikes and High occupancy vehicles on smaller , yet more direct routes. Toll type control and monitoring. Make a single person in s single car very difficult and punitive

Might as well offer mass transit that also includes dining services in the bus, in addition to completely free wifi.  Could also offer services to wash cars at the pick up site, so that when you get to your car in the evening it's already clean
Unfortunately, I live in a very small/rural town, so future transportation system would likely be simple public bus transit.
A real trolley/tram system, not a bus that they call a trolley. Rails. Automated, pre-programmed directions. Various sensors to determine speed/safety restrictions.

A solar-powered trolley system that works like an automated bus, mixed with a roller coaster.  No need for a driver, as each trolley heads to a central location and goes from different sections of neighborhoods.  They would run quickly perhaps so that  a trolley will collect people and head to its destination every 15 minutes.  It makes short transportation to hub areas cleaner, safer, and nicer, and can be closed during non-business hours of the hub area.

A trolley system would be a great source of transportation, using small trolleys instead of buses.  Another Idea would be a mini bus system that primarily transported people to key areas like the train station or the airport.  A shuttle system.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.
Automated bus lines that run to every street in America. Something similar to a trolley system, without the rails.
Renewable energy vehicle such as an electrical bus or trolley. An Uber like service that uses low emissions vehicles or electrical ones.
Something akin to a streetcar or trolley bus system could be very useful in my city.  It would have its own designated lane and be a useful public transportation alternative.

There could be a train type of system but not using metal tracks like they have in europe (above ground?)  The trolley or bus could be made to target things people wanna go do instead of just transportation.  Like grocery shopping or night out to watch movie theatre and that way everyone is grouped and the businesses upsales, etc can develop better because of that.

We ought to revisit the trolley system because the buses in New York City are plagued by heavy traffic. We should have electric trolleys on main thoroughfares. It worked in the old days. Sometimes old ideas mixed with new technology is GENIUS!

A new transportation system in my neighborhood would be similar to a train line, just on a smaller scale. It would pick people up in a series of pods and deposit them at their place of work for a small fee. This new train type line could also be used in the same way that a bus is, to run errands. The new system would have comfortable couch like chairs and be far more acceptable than the current forms of trnasportation availabe.

A sort of rail line, but it's a single rail and has many hanging carts. The carts hold maybe 4 people at a time, like a taxi. The price would be cheaper than a bus and they would arrive quickly when you need them. You could push a button on poles that are located around the city, far more often than bus stops, and the cart will come to you quickly and take you directly to your destination. No need for bus drivers or waiting for traffic!

A zip line from the place where I take the bus to the subway would be great. It would cut out all the traffic and possibly be much faster than taking the bus to the subway. Also, there would be multiple pods that would lock in the destination and go non-stop so it wouldn't be stopping every few minutes to pick up passengers.
Automated bus lines that run to every street in America. Something similar to a trolley system, without the rails.

Bus lines that run on algorythms generated by apps on citizens' phones in order to insure adequate service and reduce waste.  In off hours, users can "ping" the authority before they reach the stop they expect to be picked up at.

A real help would be a circulator bus system for the neighborhoods surrounding our subway station. How about a deluxe line of buses. You have to pay 150 or above a month for a pass, but these run better routes, and they actually run on time. Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

I have seen a lot on the news lately about 'self-driving' cars, and I think it would be neat if this technology could someday be applied to public transportation. I think 'self driving' buses would be an excellent mode of transportation. I think this would be particularly useful for smaller cities or towns that can't afford to have subway systems. Self driving buses could be programmed to stop at every stop timely and efficiently and could save the city money by eliminating the need to hire drivers and would cut out the issue of human error when it comes to being on time, not showing up for work, or causing accidents.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.

It would be amazing if we had a subway in my city. It would go to good use and people would use cars less. Everyone drives around here because the bus system is lacking and public transport is difficult. We would benefit from a subway system.

Subways with shorter runs. NYC is filled with unused tunnels and stations. Get them up and running. Also, allow people who use any sort of wheel-based transport, that's not a bus or car, to use the bike lanes.

We should have an underground subway system. For a city as large as the one I live in it would make sense. It would be faster for everyone and clear the roads of buses that clog up traffic during rush hour.

I would imagine an electric scooter or hoverboard rental system.  You could use them when going to and from a train station stop and to your final destination.  I imagine a rental system so that you could pick one up at a train or bus station to go your extra distance and return it when you return.  Renting would be a good option if you did not have your own with you or only use it with other public transportation. Bad weather is always an issue using these devices.

An uber-like system for public transit busses. Riders must request pick up 24 hours ahead of time, and the bus would come to their door or as close as it could to pick the rider up. I think a bullet train would be very useful. A train that can transport passengers fast in between the major areas in the neighborhood, for example to schools, the downtown area, the performing arts theater, shopping districts, the airport etc. It doesn't have to stop very often like a bus but an instead be used for getting between major areas and can be supported by the bus system.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

As a former city dweller who is now car-less in suburbia, I dream of a system of autonomous cars. The cars are available at convenient stations, much like bike rental stalls in cities. They are non-polluting. Anyone with a smart phone and account can book a ride at any time. Ride sharing is also available. These cars can have a pod design, though larger vehicles are available for people who need to transport larger items or many items. They accept voice commands, so programming is easy, and the cars can take you to almost any destination. Links to other transportation hubs, like trains and buses, are also available. The car doesn't need to be returned to its original location, just to another station. The vehicles are always well maintained and reliable, plus the service is affordable to most.

Companies should use some of their advertising budget to provide rides to certain places. I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.
Something like a bus stop, however you would be picked up and dropped off by someone who might be passing through, other drivers, company vehicles (like UPS trucks), etc.

Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). A new transportation system for my neighborhood would be a uber-like bus service. Buses have specific routes, and can stop at any point on that route if you use the service. That way you can have one pick you up close to your house instead of having to drop your car off at a bus station.

I imagine a way to ride a school bus to various spots on its route. You would be pre-screened as an adult who could act as a school bus monitor and at the same time gain transportation to a location near the school. It would solve the problem of kids riding unsupervised and give another public transportation option in the neighborhood.

I'd like to see the railroad tracks by our house be repurposed as a walking and biking route for the neighborhood.  It would be really sweet if they could use that and carry the corridor all the way to the nearest town and shopping area.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.

A new way to transport in my neighborhood? I would honestly say cabs. They are not around where I live. But a cheaper way and only in the city. It's mostly just busses and the stops are few and far between.

A pedi cab service similar to Uber. People would sign up to drive people around on their bicycles. It's a small neighborhood and could easily be done. The call service could have a phone app and website to make it easier to schedule pick ups.

It's a small town. In and near the town center there will be bike lanes and you will be able to access all neighborhoods in an easy and safe manner. There will be bike rental kiosks throughout the area. For areas outside town there could be a service with electric vehicles that you can book ahead of time and you can catch a ride to select locations around town.

This new transportation system is a bullet train in the sky, able to span around the neighborhood with up to 700 passengers in under two minutes. It's sleek silver coat is never late, and always early to make sure everyone gets where they need to go. The rails float there in the sky, ready to carry this majestic beauty to the ends of the neighborhood making sure everyone is early

I think that some sort of charging commuter car should be parked in every neighborhood. People could coordinate commute times and use electric cars instead of gas, in exchange they pay $1 a day to drive the car per person.

In my neighborhood, any kind of public transportation would be innovative. Due to the apparent stigma of such, I would propose a lovely electric-run "uber coach" instead of the big ugly city bus. This could be as simple as a mini-van and could deliver us suffering commuters of Southern California from a few select and regular pick-up spots to bigger, car-pool mega spots at various freeway points.

There are solar powered buses in my neighborhood which are 100% sustainable and operate autonomously, very much like the commuter trams at some airports such as Miami International Airport. These require no labor, and as such, have no human element involved in decisionmaking. As they are programmed to stop at intervals (designated by where the bus stops would be) there is a set time to off-load and pick up customers. OF course, handicapped and large groups can press a certain button which would allow more time and/or ramps to deploy.

I live in a rural area, it's pretty hilly but it runs along the length of a valley. It would be really nice to have a walking/bike path that connects the residential neighborhood to the commercial district without having the bike/walk on the road. Although it's generally slow traffic, walking on the road is never exactly safe. Especially in the winter. To be able to network together the few towns in the valley too would be very nice.
Mini bus services around the neighborhood covering the residential area so that single rides can be reduced

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.
A both walking and bike lane that provides safety from traffic, is well lit, and connects key locations around the neighborhood.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.

Not just in my neighborhood but metro-wide, my city recently established time share bicycles people can rent and ride when they have a short distance to travel. The bikes are all of the same design, having a large sturdy frame painted light blue, three gears (the gear box is inside the rear wheel axle, and LED blinker lights for safety. Necessarily, it's a one-size-fits-all arrangement; there's no way to raise or lower the seat unless you carry your own tools around with you, so if you're a tall person and use one of these bikes you'll be knocking yourself in the chin with your knees.

A system where there are rails above you and nothing underneath you.

You sit in a cart of sorts and you are guided along near the streets, maybe above the streets or sidewalk.

The railings connect overhead and end at each sidewalk and gives you a nice view of the neighborhood, kind of like a ski-lift.

My neighborhood is very organized, but has very few buses.  I'd love to see a ski 'pod' style transportation.  There would be several station, and you would enter a pod, and ride.  There would be a whole network of pod so you could go all over town.  It will also be overhead, like over the sidewalks and bike paths.

Ultimate monkey bars.  People are too fat in my area, forcing them to travel via monkey bars across the neighborhood should help not only with emission decrease, but weight decrease as well!  There will just be an overhead system running the lengths of the sidewalks at 7 foot high so no one gets hurt if they fall.
A bunch of self driving cars that will replace buses and taxis. The will have free wifi and be very cheap.

A fleet of cheap, reliable, automated taxi cars. The cars would drive automatically after an input was made for the destination. These cars would be self charging with paint that has solar energy potential.
A taxi service where self-driving cars can be dispatched to a client which then drive the client to their destination and then return to HQ.

As a socially awkward recluse who doesn't drive, I want to be able to call an automated system for a driver-less taxi. I want the option to pay online via debit/credit, gift card or Paypal or have the option to insert bills into the car door before being able to enter. I'd like to be able to pick my music genres for the ride as well.

Automated taxi service. Would have several dispatch stations in key areas of city. Person could call for a ride from an app on their phone and it would send a car to them. The software could calculate rate for the trip and make you pay before as a confirmation before sending a car out. Car could then drive customer to said destination.  Self driveable cars that could provide a much better service than the often RUDE cab drivers could provide. Plus, I trust a robot way more than some of these morons driving!
I live in a snowy climate, so there are a lot of times that we can't drive our cars anywhere because of all the snow. So a snowmobile taxi might work.

I live in a town right on the ocean and there are many canals here. I think a canoe taxi service would be really convenient and fun. It wouldn't get people to their desired locations super fast but it would allow people to travel leisurely and enjoy the scenery along the way. It would also be really healthy for the people driving the canoes and help them to stay fit.

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.

I see a totally different way of transportation in the future. I see solar a powered tram replacing all the buses and since the cost is so much lower there will be many more of them so you can get anywhere you want to go anytime. In addition to the in city tram there will be a super high speed solar powered train that can go 150 mph or more! That will make it so what used to be a 2 hour drive or more will now be a short train ride away. For those who do not want to take the tram there will be an unmanned flying drone taxi. All you do it either tell it your destination or input the location yourself and it automatically takes you there.

I would love to see some kind of computer-operated taxi service in my city. The roads would be a lot safer of cars weren't being driven by humans, and I feel like people would be a lot more productive. I would love if I could just sit in the backseat and read or do work on my way to work, instead of having to pay attention to the road every second. It would also save money from having to buy a car if I could jsut call one of these taxis whenever I need to go somewhere.

Self driving cars that could detect traffic/other cars and could navigate to a specific location would be great in this town, especially at night to avoid accidents due to intoxicated driving of college students. The cars could be rented from the town and ordered similarly to taxi cabs, and could drive students home from the bars for a fee without relying on very tired or intoxicated friends to do so.
think it will be self driving cars aka taxis coming soon. really when apple says they are working on a self driving car

Transportation that would allow people to rent out electric self driving cars. This would let people have cars pick them up at whatever location they want and have the car autonomously drive to their destination. Similar to a fleet of self driving electric taxis. This would greatly reduce the cost of transportation in my opinion because people would not have to buy cars but could rather rent or lease them.
Combining food delivery services with taxi driving to maximize efficiency.

A network of publicly available electric cars will drive around the city in the most efficient manner possible. People will use apps to call a car to get them =from one of many pickup spots and drop them off before they go on the next passenger.

A pod/train system that runs on the shoulder of roads. It would be more active than typical buses, and be more personal in that there can be no more than 4 passengers. It would run on a track or in the future it would would run with automatic sensing software and would drive itself.

An app that worked somewhat like Uber, but is for ride-sharing/car pooling.  You put in your destination, whether you can drive or not, what time you need to be to your destination, and an acceptable range for the location.  The app would look for others with similar destinations or destinations en-route for others as well as the best route to minimize drive time, but maximize people getting to their destination.  Then the app would calculate a fair percentage of the ride cost for each person based on their destination, travel distance, etc.  Public transportation here isn't great because we are so spread out.  After each ride you could rate other passengers and the driver and those ratings could be used to filter out bad users entirely or just below a certain rating level.

An automated system of cabs. Not cars though, more like carriages driven by AI "Horses" (Imagine that new Harley electric motorcycle engine, in a short, small, bullet shaped car like you used to see on the SIDE of a motorcycle, pulling a carriage, with an AI brain controlling it). A system like this would have the novelty and functionality of pulling people when you wanted to, or you could just use the AI 'sidecar' to run courier errands on the ground for companies that wanted fast delivery. Think like Amazon drones without the flying, the noise or the whole 'being small enough to get shot down by a .22 and stolen' thing. It keeps the battery away from the passengers if there is ever a crash, too. Which is good because those things can explode sometimes. The best thing about it, though? When it's just moving small items around for parcel delivery, it's not wasting fuel hauling an empty cab around with it. I can't stand seeing people waste so much energy driving a giant SUV around with no passengers or cargo. That act alone should be a top priority for politicians pushing for environmental reform to be talking about.

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

In the future, self driving cabs can be summoned via mobile phone, to pick up the driver and take them to a particular destination via a touchscreen or other similar interface located inside the vehicle.  Some difficulty may occur if the passenger is unsure of the address of his or her destination, but a trained attendant can be called to determine the location for the passenger.

My idea is a combination of self driving cars, rideshare and a train. Commuters would pay for a ticket and a line of connected self driving cars would take commuters going the same route/direction to a certain dropoff point, like a train does. Then when the string of cars reaches the stop point, each passenger can enter their desired destination into the touchpad screen in the car and they would be driven to their individual destinations. The self driving cars would break off individually from the train to take these passengers, then they'd return on their own to the "train station" to go pick up more passengers.

The future of transport in my city is likely a self driving car service system. There will be kiosks with cars waiting and you simply go into the car, put your destination into a computer and pay. It is as simple as that. The self driving cars will know how to avoid traffic and accidents and will automatically take the shortest and most sensible route to any destination. The self driving car will allow for multiple passengers and the cars will vary in size.

A social platform similar to facebook related to all things travel. People would be able to connect with others and find people traveling the same route. One person would volunteer to drive and would pick everyone up, and their cards are automatically charged the rate in which gas costs along with depreciation of vehicle. If 3 riders, each pay 1/3.. 4 riders pay 1/4, etc.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town. 



One thing that may be neat would be large sidewalks where people could ride bikes/scooters/walk and avoid using a vehicle. The main road is fairly busy, and there are quite a few shops around that would be more accessible if we had better transportation than just getting in a car! (Boardman, OH). Little scooters with solar power charging stations would be neat.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

The self driving car will allow for multiple passengers and the cars will vary in size.

A rail system that is build from the ground up. This would be capable of high speeds typically not able to travel when driving or on another train. This would make work transit much faster.

A Railway system for cars, like something out of minority report. You can still drive on the roads but the speed limit is controlled and there is never any accidents because you input your destination into a program in the individual cars and let the railway system get you there.

I would like to see all self driving cars, driving at top speeds because human error and crashes have been removed from the equation. So everyone can get to their destination five, maybe ten times as fast, without a significant infrastructure overhaul.

In the interest of reducing traffic and accidents, a new series of self-driving only roads and lanes are opened.  On these roads, ONLY self driving cars are authorized to drive, and on them there are no speed limits (not that the self-driving cars would be going that much faster than normal). Unfettered by the chaos of common roads and the limitations of human judgement, these exclusively self-driving vehicle areas allow the navigational AIs to coordinate for an optimally fast and efficient journey.

It would be great if we could improve the pubic transportation and reduce the number of cars on the road. I would like to see self driving buses as well as bus only lanes and self driving cars. No manually controlled cars would be allowed and because of this hopefully the roads will be safer because most accidents and caused by human error. We could have the speed limits increased as well because self driving cars can "see" a lot father ahead than humans.
roads with different speed limits so people that want to drive faster can go on one and people driving slower on the other
A electric scooter sharing program for getting around town without having to drive a car and use too much gas or take up too much space.

A network of green transportation for rent. You insert coins and it releases a bike, a skateboard, a scooter or some other form of efficient transportation. You drive it to your destination and once you deliver it to the hotpspot you can get your money back, if it is in good condition.

CAR IS GOOD FOR FAMILY DRIVE.

BUS IS SUITABLE FOR LONG TRAVELLING

I would really like to see separate lanes for scooters in my area.  A lot more people are commuting this way, and it would be good if it was a safer way to drive.

In my area, we don't have buses or sidewalks. You HAVE to drive a car, even though the area is big enough for a bus. I would love to have an eco-friendly bus route through the main part of town.

Ride scooters to a local bus stop that. Houses scooters on the bus, up to 10 miles from house, to work in the inner city, (25 miles from bus stop) it would save gas and pollution, instead of 25 people driving take a bus. Scooters get better Mpg and it's safer to stay on a bus on a highway than a scooter.

A fare based system would allow heavy car users to pay more and light ones to pay less for gas, tolls, etc.  Their car will have a gps tracker to see where and when they go (downtown, rush hour, etc.)  This will help the people who don't need to drive as much and tax the ones that are always on the road.

I live on an army base. There are hundreds of vehicles that just sit around and collect rust, and it would be wonderful if the military could find some way to rent these vehicles out to the public. This would create income for individual units and help add to their budget, as well as providing vehicles to civilians who need them and even potentially drawing in interested persons who would otherwise never have driven a military vehicle.

I'm imagining a car sharing service with locations throughout the city where you can go pick up a car without having to reserve one in advance. Nor would you have to interact with any people at the pickup/dropoff location. It would be somehow automated. Perhaps you would subscribe to the service an at annual or monthly rate and be given a special kind of 'key' that would give access to any of the cars currently at the pick up location. It would be first come first serve, and there would be smart technology embedded in both the cars and the keys. Your universal key would be linked to your account, and the car you used would transmit all relevant information to the system. Such as , time of pick up. number of miles drive. amount of gas used. Then the fees would be adjusted accordingly based on the type of car you used, miles driven, gas consumed etc. all of this without any human employees and all the fuss that comes with tradiional car rental. Things like insurance and billing info would all be done upfront when a patron sets up an account. This is genius, the more i think about it!

Perhaps you would subscribe to the service an at annual or monthly rate and be given a special kind of 'key' that would give access to any of the cars currently at the pick up location. It would be first come first serve, and there would be smart technology embedded in both the cars and the keys. Your universal key would be linked to your account, and the car you used would transmit all relevant information to the system. Such as , time of pick up. number of miles drive. amount of gas used. Then the fees would be adjusted accordingly based on the type of car you used, miles driven, gas consumed etc. all of this without any human employees and all the fuss that comes with tradiional car rental. Things like insurance and billing info would all be done upfront when a patron sets up an account. This is genius, the more i think about it!

Conveyor belts on the sidewalks, similar to the ones on the airports, wouldn't be a bad idea. This would be perfect if you live near lots of stores, like a grocery store, drug stores, post offices, shopping centers, etc. This will cut back on driving.

I wish we had a monorail between the airport and our city. We aren't connected to any public transportation system, but more than 70% of our residents travel by plane more than once a year. Many people travel for work, etc. Rather than each of us driving and paying to park our cars there, if we could stay in our suburb and take the monorail (or train) to and from it would save a great deal of money and time.

I would like to see a short-term car rental service with semi-autonomous driving. For example, if I needed to go to the airport and didn't want to leave my current car in a parking lot their I could rent a car that I could summon with a smartphone app. The car would be able autonomously drive directly to me or a location I choose through the app. After I was at the location of my choosing and no longer needed the car, I could then use the app to send the car away.

Moving sidewalks all over the city would be amazing. People could hop on and even sit and get to their destination.  They'd be like the ones in airports, but they would go faster.  Some could even run into and through tubes so people would be protected in bad weather.  Something like a gerbil habitat would be amazing.  I think it would promote people walking instead of driving.  Or, just standing on the moving sidewalks.  It would reduce pollution if people took things like this around the city.

My idea would be to use a moving belt (like used in airport terminals) instead of sidewalks to get around my neighborhood. I live is a small town (population about 500), so it would encourage people to drive less to get to destinations that are close to their homes.

Everything runs on automated self driving cars.  Normal cars are not allowed on the road.  Everything will run smoothly since it is computer operated and parking spaces won't be needed.  Bicyclists will no longer have to worry.

Have driverless cars available for instant calls.

The cars would be driving around until someone requests it or parked in a parking lot until called.

I would like to see a short-term car rental service with semi-autonomous driving. For example, if I needed to go to the airport and didn't want to leave my current car in a parking lot their I could rent a car that I could summon with a smartphone app. The car would be able autonomously drive directly to me or a location I choose through the app. After I was at the location of my choosing and no longer needed the car, I could then use the app to send the car away.

My neighborhood added an above ground train similar to the "L" in Chicago.  It runs along the highways bringing people downtown from the suburbs.  It does a few loops downtown and runs near the major companies to get people to work.  It is much cheaper and more convenient than driving downtown and parking.

This idea would have to be built in a city near a river, or attached to a solar farm because it relies on using naturally produced hydroelectric or solar power. Basically, it's a train on an electrified track, that moves slowly and stops at intervals in a big loop throughout a city. It would make stops the same way buses make stops. If you rode it long enough, you'd wind up at the same stop you got on at.  It relies completely on green energy, no exhaust just some electric motors driving the cars. People would be able to get on and just ride to where they needed to get off, leaving their personal vehicle in a parking area. It could be configured to have small, individual cars maybe fitted with a GPS system so you could tell it where you needed to go and it would get you as close as possible. The main idea is it would be free and the city could tax businesses a small amount for serving their parts of town, just to help pay maintenance costs.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

My neighborhood added an above ground train similar to the "L" in Chicago.  It runs along the highways bringing people downtown from the suburbs.  It does a few loops downtown and runs near the major companies to get people to work.  It is much cheaper and more convenient than driving downtown and parking.

Ride scooters to a local bus stop that. Houses scooters on the bus, up to 10 miles from house, to work in the inner city, (25 miles from bus stop) it would save gas and pollution, instead of 25 people driving take a bus. Scooters get better Mpg and it's safer to stay on a bus on a highway than a scooter.
The neighborhood needs a rail system that runs adjacent to the highway. This would go from major city to major city with the same stops as for those that drive.

An automated system of cabs. Not cars though, more like carriages driven by AI "Horses" (Imagine that new Harley electric motorcycle engine, in a short, small, bullet shaped car like you used to see on the SIDE of a motorcycle, pulling a carriage, with an AI brain controlling it). A system like this would have the novelty and functionality of pulling people when you wanted to, or you could just use the AI 'sidecar' to run courier errands on the ground for companies that wanted fast delivery. Think like Amazon drones without the flying, the noise or the whole 'being small enough to get shot down by a .22 and stolen' thing. It keeps the battery away from the passengers if there is ever a crash, too. Which is good because those things can explode sometimes. The best thing about it, though? When it's just moving small items around for parcel delivery, it's not wasting fuel hauling an empty cab around with it. I can't stand seeing people waste so much energy driving a giant SUV around with no passengers or cargo. That act alone should be a top priority for politicians pushing for environmental reform to be talking about.

Every car would be able to hover or fly. Every car that runs off gasoline will be rare to find and all the cars have a feature that are able to drive themselves. Even motorcycles will be something that you find in a museum.

My idea is to have a service like zipcar in which someone rents the use of a car by paying a monthly fee except that it would be mopeds for individuals or something larger like a pick up truck.  Just more options than a small smart car.  I used to live in Tokyo and driving a car there was awful but not something like a moped or motorcycle because they could ride in between the cars.  A larger vehicle like a pickup truck would be good for people who need to rent something to haul furniture or something like that but don't want to drive all the way to a car rental place or Lowe's to get the truck.  Everything would be rentable using an app and the cars would feature opening the doors and starting the cars through the app itself.

There could be a really good motorcycle driver that would drive fast and come pick you up. He would know back roads and side allys very well. He could weve in and out of traffic and get you somewhere really fast.
A rail system that is build from the ground up. This would be capable of high speeds typically not able to travel when driving or on another train. This would make work transit much faster.

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

My neighborhood filled with uber drives. However, there is no cost assoicated with the transit it is all provided by the town. It would be like new york city (think of cabs), however nice black cars everywhere and someone can hop in to any one they want free of charge. Baisically be like public transit with uber and they will take you wherever you want.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

Self driving rental trucks.  They come to you instead of having to drive it all the way across town to where you live. You load  then unload your stuff then it drives itself back to the rental place.

My small rural town doesn't even have an intact bus system, so anything would be better than it is now. But I would like a service that has people who drive pick up trucks to help you move things. Hyperloop:  essentially a super fast subway in a pressurized tube like they use at the drive up to a bank to send things back and forth only on a scale large enough for people to ride in

I have seen a lot on the news lately about 'self-driving' cars, and I think it would be neat if this technology could someday be applied to public transportation. I think 'self driving' buses would be an excellent mode of transportation. I think this would be particularly useful for smaller cities or towns that can't afford to have subway systems. Self driving buses could be programmed to stop at every stop timely and efficiently and could save the city money by eliminating the need to hire drivers and would cut out the issue of human error when it comes to being on time, not showing up for work, or causing accidents.

It would be amazing if we had a subway in my city. It would go to good use and people would use cars less. Everyone drives around here because the bus system is lacking and public transport is difficult. We would benefit from a subway system.

A fare based system would allow heavy car users to pay more and light ones to pay less for gas, tolls, etc.  Their car will have a gps tracker to see where and when they go (downtown, rush hour, etc.)  This will help the people who don't need to drive as much and tax the ones that are always on the road.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

Im from Seattle and it is mostly built over the top of the old city that burned down. I would think that they'd be able to build subways here at least through the downtown area where they have underground tours of the city.

In the downtown area, stations to rent bicycles or even mopeds. Maybe you could have a really cheap membership and present your card at the check out station. My neighborhood will continue to use mainly personal vehicles as a mode of transportation, though the downtown area is working on an underground rail system.
