There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

The area is very car-dependent, but a train or monorail going down the middle or above the main highways would be a great way to travel down the expressways and parkways without having to depend on a car.

Railway tunnels off of the highways (outdoor subways) to provide a fast paced mode of transportation on busy streets that work with a system like uber that will have drivers readily available at each location. More for suburban areas, not large city areas that have subway/rail systems.

I wish we had separate bicycle highways that were enclosed spaces, both heated and cooled for summer/winter. It would be a cheaper mode of transportation. There would be protection to prevent car vs bicycle accident, a major problem in our area. It would also be healthier and exercise for the day during a commute. I picture it being a rounded space that is clear so you can see your surroundings outside.

A central hub for a ridesharing service that provides cars for small groups to take to neighboring towns. I live in a rural area, a few minutes from a very small village. The nearest SMALL city is about 30 minutes away, and the nearest decent sized city is almost an hour away. A ridesharing service would make accessing these places much easier, and if the company provided the car (for a fee, of course), those without vehicles could be serviced.

A solar-powered trolley system that works like an automated bus, mixed with a roller coaster.  No need for a driver, as each trolley heads to a central location and goes from different sections of neighborhoods.  They would run quickly perhaps so that  a trolley will collect people and head to its destination every 15 minutes.  It makes short transportation to hub areas cleaner, safer, and nicer, and can be closed during non-business hours of the hub area.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

I would love it if the city made walking and riding a bike more user friendly. There are no areas that are safe for pedestrians or bikers. If there were a bike lane, more people could move independently and get to where they are going. Commuters using more than one mode of transportation would be able to get to their destinations more quickly and with greater safety.

A transportation Idea I have is to have networked building walkways. Think of it like your average street crossing but instead of connecting streets it connects neighboring buildings instead. There would be no access to private buildings but pedestrians would be able to walk enclosed walkways running through special areas in the building to get to the next. I think this idea is very practical in heavy urban areas and would be a refreshing change from the average commute.

I'd like to see shuttle trams in my area. It's a small section based urban area that has about four different areas all residents will have to visit at some point in time. If we had a shuttle system that specifically transported people from a central point to the four primary destinations it would incredibly reduce the use of fossil fuels, traffic, and accidents in the area.

I would like a city trolley. The trolley would travel around the city several times a day, taking and picking up residents from the major shopping areas. The trolley stops should be no more than two blocks from any neighborhood.

A new transportation system in my neighborhood would be a railway system available to rural and outlying areas.  It would stretch along the roadway and connect to different cities and stops much like a trolley system or train system.  People could get on and off at different points.  They could schedule to be picked up at different times during the day.
An above-ground train system. We scrapped a trolley system, and some areas can't support a subway. Above-ground might be useful for us.

A moving sidewalk - like the ones you would see in an airport to help expedite movement between terminals.  Around my area there are a lot of close shops, so people could walk, but getting loads of bags home would be difficult.  Having mechanical walkways would enable people to do their shopping but reduce their need to use cars, and at the same time set all their bags down so they don't have to figure out how to lug them home, especially if they've purchased something heavy.  It could also allow people to get where they need to go faster, if they continue to walk along the moving sidewalk.  They could sit alongside regular sidewalks, so people who still wanted to go out for a walk and get some fresh air could do so.  The mechanical/moving sidewalks would be made out of metal, look like a flat escalator, have hand railings, and each side of the road would have a sidewalk that goes the same way as traffic.

Public, foot-based transportation. Something like the automatic walkways in airports, but for long stretches of large cities, particularly between common high-traffic areas. It would probably be best if the walkways were raised, to avoid conflict with other ground traffic. It must also include access for the disabled, be easy enough for even tech-fearful users, and extremely safe (with monitored auto-shutoff where applicable).

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

In dense urban areas have a series of high tension wires between buildings. Have a  mechanized seat something like a zipline  that people would ride on. This would need a seatbelt or maybe an enclosed capsule for safety but the idea is making the seat as compact as possible .

There are a lot of fairly narrow paths in between buildings in my area. It would be good if they could be paved smoother to be used by bicyclists. It would make their travel more efficient and would also increase their safety as they wouldn't have to spend as much time on roads meant for cars.

A transportation Idea I have is to have networked building walkways. Think of it like your average street crossing but instead of connecting streets it connects neighboring buildings instead. There would be no access to private buildings but pedestrians would be able to walk enclosed walkways running through special areas in the building to get to the next. I think this idea is very practical in heavy urban areas and would be a refreshing change from the average commute.

A motorized scooter "stop."  Basically a few very popular areas you can pick up a scooter from an agent.  Credit is the only thing that's acceptable, as they need to have something on file in case you ride off with the scooter.  These locations where you can both rent, and return scooters will only be in very popular areas (Such as the mall, a large amount of business buildings, and the like.)  Make it relatively affordable, and have people be able to write it off as an expense.

I live in a rural community about 1 hour from a city. I would like to see this area build a light rail commuter line that could link these isolated communities and boost the economy. Many people out here do not even have cars.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.

A Bus system, within the metro area that was funded by a tax on gas purchased by individual commuters. In otherwords, free to the people who use the bus, and costs the people who don't. have the busses rinning from a set time like 6am to 9 pm  and pickups are every 15 min, so you never need to bother with knowing the bus schedule. Also, have all busses make a stop in the center of town so if you need to get across town, take a bus from you house to the center, and from there to your final destination. There should be a bus passing every school, hospital, shopping center, library ect. Simply run smaller buses on less popular routes, use smaller buses in general. make one special route for city to city transfers. The system needs to be free or very affordable, fast and convenient. No need to waste resources and infrastructure on schedules, call centers, web pages, just keep it simple and convenient.

I would love it if the city made walking and riding a bike more user friendly. There are no areas that are safe for pedestrians or bikers. If there were a bike lane, more people could move independently and get to where they are going. Commuters using more than one mode of transportation would be able to get to their destinations more quickly and with greater safety.

I live in a rural area, it's pretty hilly but it runs along the length of a valley. It would be really nice to have a walking/bike path that connects the residential neighborhood to the commercial district without having the bike/walk on the road. Although it's generally slow traffic, walking on the road is never exactly safe. Especially in the winter. To be able to network together the few towns in the valley too would be very nice.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

I can imagine my neighborhood having a high speed maglev train. It will levitate on top of a rail that will span around the entire city to avoid traffic. It will be fast and efficient to provide good transportation services.

my neighborhood future transportation system will be made up of flying cars. This cars will be able to take off and land like helicopters. There will be no more traffic jams, traffic light, annoying speed limits and harassing cops. People will be able to travel to any part of the world without going through airports and flight connections. There will be new telecommunication and navigation technology that will help the drivers navigate safely without having mid air collisions and also mid air gas stations to refuel the cars.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.

Due to the amount of traffic around Tampa and surrounding towns, there is much congestion during rush hours. To help alleviate some of this, I suggest uni-directional bridge to be built that reduce traffic during rush hours. In the morning, the bridge would allow traffic going west towards the base. In the evening, traffic would flow to the east.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.
The future of transportation in my city is by having self-automated driverless cars. They would reduce the amount of traffic congestion and reduce the number of car accidents.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

The system will be based off cable cars.  It's cheaper and easier to put up than bridges or building tunnels.  They will have their own traffic free paths.  The paths can even intersect by having the cables much higher than the other line's.  There can be platforms every so often so people can get on and off but not too many as to keep cost and commute time down.

My city would benefit from an elevated and enclosed train line. Regional rail is the preferred choice for many commuters but is unreliable and frustrating due to weather and traffic related delays. Though the infrastructure investment would be great, we are in need of an overhaul anyway and should improve the current system.

A sort of rail line, but it's a single rail and has many hanging carts. The carts hold maybe 4 people at a time, like a taxi. The price would be cheaper than a bus and they would arrive quickly when you need them. You could push a button on poles that are located around the city, far more often than bus stops, and the cart will come to you quickly and take you directly to your destination. No need for bus drivers or waiting for traffic!

There can be platforms every so often so people can get on and off but not too many as to keep cost and commute time down.

A magnetic roadway system, where people move in modular pods that are controlled by a central operating system (COS). Magnets underneath the street guide your pod along, and every movement of all of the pods is controlled perfectly by the computerized system, it is completely autonomous. If your whole family wants to go into town, you assemble your four-pod system and take off, where traffic is optimized perfectly by the COS. If just you are on your way to work, you hop in your single passenger pod, and take off!

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

I live near the water, so water transportation would be nice to have. It could be a system of ferries that can go from port to port, carrying passengers like a bus system. This would reduce the amount of cars on the road and the amount of traffic.

A bus that has a design similar to a hydrofoil boat. The bus would run on special tracks that would be parallel to each other on opposite sides of a street. This passenger compartment would be on top, with the "foils" connecting to the two tracks. There would be open space underneath the passenger compartment where the road is. This way, the bus could move unimpeded by traffic, while also not disrupting traffic itself. Also, passengers would not even see the traffic below them, making the ride smooth, comfortable, and consistent.

My Idea would be to make the alleyways in my city a lot more bike friendly.  Honestly they are very rarely ever used by the city or homeowners so to make them this way would be beneficial for so many others. This would I believe encourage more people to use bicycles since I know I am terrified when riding my bicycle next to extremely lage and fast moving automobile traffic on my cities roads and highways.

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.
I would like to see a hover system that occupies the same route as roads and highways to bypass traffic.

Segways!  Segway sidewalks that go over streets and above the normal sidewalks people walk on so you can ride your segway without stopping for traffic or having to worry about a pedestrian taking up space to get by. Segway sidewalks can even run on the edge of a major highway in bigger cities like mine to keep routes short and simple. We can even make the segways charge on solar power so they will never go dead while you're out running about.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

An overhead puppy cart system, the same concept as in skii resorts. I live in NYC, and outside of traveling by train, there are no other practicals transportation which avoids traffic. Unlike the the train system, you would be able to make direct routes, with a bonus of great views around the city

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

I'd like to see shuttle trams in my area. It's a small section based urban area that has about four different areas all residents will have to visit at some point in time. If we had a shuttle system that specifically transported people from a central point to the four primary destinations it would incredibly reduce the use of fossil fuels, traffic, and accidents in the area.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.

our city is metro .population is a big problem there and traffic too .large no of people use public transport like trains and buses but also use scooter in large nos as its easy to go to places when there is lot of traffic on rads to avoid jams.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.

Segways!  Segway sidewalks that go over streets and above the normal sidewalks people walk on so you can ride your segway without stopping for traffic or having to worry about a pedestrian taking up space to get by. Segway sidewalks can even run on the edge of a major highway in bigger cities like mine to keep routes short and simple. We can even make the segways charge on solar power so they will never go dead while you're out running about.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.

I think the idea of rickshaws are a good one.  But in most places, like cities or suburban areas with hills, a traditional rickshaw wouldn't be practical.  I think that a bike with an electric motor and a cab on the back would be a good solution.  It's nicer for the environment and a more personal connection than a taxi.  Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

Firefighters are using jet-packs in Dubai to combat fires in skyscrapers. I propose we use jet-packs for personal transport. It's hard enough to travel in big cities like Miami with all the traffic. Having your own jet pack allows you to literally fly away from a stressful situation such as sitting in traffic or waiting for public transportation. It will save time and is fun. This futuristic technology is here and it works.

An underground walkway would be useful in my neighbourhood because you would not need to stop traffic to cross the street.

A moving sidewalk - like the ones you would see in an airport to help expedite movement between terminals.  Around my area there are a lot of close shops, so people could walk, but getting loads of bags home would be difficult.  Having mechanical walkways would enable people to do their shopping but reduce their need to use cars, and at the same time set all their bags down so they don't have to figure out how to lug them home, especially if they've purchased something heavy.  It could also allow people to get where they need to go faster, if they continue to walk along the moving sidewalk.  They could sit alongside regular sidewalks, so people who still wanted to go out for a walk and get some fresh air could do so.  The mechanical/moving sidewalks would be made out of metal, look like a flat escalator, have hand railings, and each side of the road would have a sidewalk that goes the same way as traffic.

I live near the water, so water transportation would be nice to have. It could be a system of ferries that can go from port to port, carrying passengers like a bus system. This would reduce the amount of cars on the road and the amount of traffic.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

I imagine a taxi speed boat that could take you downtown in a matter of minutes. It will help skip all the traffic on the street and cut your time in half. Perfect for people who live by bodies of water and are in a rush like NYC.

If we could be so technologically advanced to create giant versions of the airport conveyor belts where humans are carried across, that would be my new method of transportation. Since people are mostly lazy and want something to do the work for them (hence the upcoming popularity of the hands-free segway), this would be perfect to eliminate at least a fourth of the traffic on the street from cars.

my neighborhood future transportation system will be made up of flying cars. This cars will be able to take off and land like helicopters. There will be no more traffic jams, traffic light, annoying speed limits and harassing cops. People will be able to travel to any part of the world without going through airports and flight connections. There will be new telecommunication and navigation technology that will help the drivers navigate safely without having mid air collisions and also mid air gas stations to refuel the cars.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

A moving sidewalk - like the ones you would see in an airport to help expedite movement between terminals.  Around my area there are a lot of close shops, so people could walk, but getting loads of bags home would be difficult.  Having mechanical walkways would enable people to do their shopping but reduce their need to use cars, and at the same time set all their bags down so they don't have to figure out how to lug them home, especially if they've purchased something heavy.  It could also allow people to get where they need to go faster, if they continue to walk along the moving sidewalk.  They could sit alongside regular sidewalks, so people who still wanted to go out for a walk and get some fresh air could do so.  The mechanical/moving sidewalks would be made out of metal, look like a flat escalator, have hand railings, and each side of the road would have a sidewalk that goes the same way as traffic.

Segways!  Segway sidewalks that go over streets and above the normal sidewalks people walk on so you can ride your segway without stopping for traffic or having to worry about a pedestrian taking up space to get by. Segway sidewalks can even run on the edge of a major highway in bigger cities like mine to keep routes short and simple. We can even make the segways charge on solar power so they will never go dead while you're out running about.

A bus that has a design similar to a hydrofoil boat. The bus would run on special tracks that would be parallel to each other on opposite sides of a street. This passenger compartment would be on top, with the "foils" connecting to the two tracks. There would be open space underneath the passenger compartment where the road is. This way, the bus could move unimpeded by traffic, while also not disrupting traffic itself. Also, passengers would not even see the traffic below them, making the ride smooth, comfortable, and consistent.

Invest in personal helicopters, these would be like the size of a small above ground pool. They won't take up much space and they'll allow people to get around faster since they won't be stuck in traffic.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

I am thinking about a flying transport system. It should fly with balloon or air system. It should not need engine or fuel. So expence would be cheap. It should occupy 15-25 people at a time. It moves with air adjustment, drag, thrust, pressure etc. The flyer lands every important point in a city. So people can travel across the city with less time and money. No traffic block, signals, air pollution etc.

I'd like to see some sort of autonomous shared fleet of cars that are fueled in some sort of environmentally friendly way. Solar panels on the roof? Maybe bike pedaling inside if you want to exercise and provide a small amount of power? I feel like autonomous cars alone will save a ton of energy just by eliminating traffic jams. And cut down on wind resistance since you wouldn't need to keep the traditional design necessarily.

I'd like to see shuttle trams in my area. It's a small section based urban area that has about four different areas all residents will have to visit at some point in time. If we had a shuttle system that specifically transported people from a central point to the four primary destinations it would incredibly reduce the use of fossil fuels, traffic, and accidents in the area.

Moped rentals. Like bike rentals, these are open access places where someone can rent a small vehicle like a moped or scooter by using their credit card or maybe their ID as their "deposit". If they steal the vehicle or damage it, they are billed, but otherwise, must simply have the vehicle back in their stall at the designated time. On-board computers diagnose the vehicles to check for problems or missing parts, and a GPS keeps track of them for asset protection and data collection purposes.

I imagine a type of highway for bicycles where people can use on and off ramps easily to reach their destination. They wont have to worry about cars since its a bike only highway system. it will get people to their destination quicker since they dont have to stop at traffic lights and watch out for pedestrians.

I would like to see a bicycle highway.  It would go the length of regular highways, but be for bikes and pedestrians.  It should be wide enough for fast moving road cyclist, it should have passing lanes, and little road crossings.  There should be frequent on and off ramps.  There should also be many large parking areas.  Ideally it would even lead to public transportation areas with ample bike parking.

I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people.  It can almost be like an HOV lane for pedestrians for people who need to walk brisker and faster and get somewhere.  Even slow jogs or panicked gallops would be allowed!  When it's really crowded and busy on the streets, I always feel like a pinball ball.  I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

Hoverboards that really move along and can occupy the bike lanes in some major cities would help unclog pedestrian side walks. Lnaes for Elf cars and Fred Flintstone type vehicles. More companies should be like Google and provide transportation for their employees. Hoover boats that glide across bays 10 times faster that farries plowing throw the water.

I would love it if the city made walking and riding a bike more user friendly. There are no areas that are safe for pedestrians or bikers. If there were a bike lane, more people could move independently and get to where they are going. Commuters using more than one mode of transportation would be able to get to their destinations more quickly and with greater safety.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.
Covered and underground or above ground lanes for bikes, pedestrians, and disabled that are always protected from inclement weather.

Publicly available bicycles could be stationed at different regions of the town: different parts of the University campus, the downtown square, the region of stores and malls for shopping. This would allow students to be able to rent and use a bike to get around without having to own one and worry about its safety.

Not just in my neighborhood but metro-wide, my city recently established time share bicycles people can rent and ride when they have a short distance to travel. The bikes are all of the same design, having a large sturdy frame painted light blue, three gears (the gear box is inside the rear wheel axle, and LED blinker lights for safety. Necessarily, it's a one-size-fits-all arrangement; there's no way to raise or lower the seat unless you carry your own tools around with you, so if you're a tall person and use one of these bikes you'll be knocking yourself in the chin with your knees.

an app that takes into account both traffic and train congestion, as well as the speeds to walk or bike, to tell you the fastest mode of transport to a destination. For example, train  might typically be quicker to get from A to B, but when trains are spaced 20 minutes apart late at night and there is no traffic, driving/taxi would be faster.

My neighborhood has little walk-ability due to poor road quality and an abundance of speed bumps. My Idea is simple in that they can add multiple lanes above the street for bikes and people walking. This would be on par with what cities have over major crossings but will cost relatively little money compared with adding a train or increasing the once daily buses. This would also allow any expansion of the roads under the walkways and reduce the 10 or so deaths a year from cars hitting people when they are just walking on the side of the road.

An underground network system in the neighborhood, like a subway but only bikes and small motorcycles can travel through. This will be a good way to protect against the weather and steer clear of any incoming cars.

Express subway lines would be nice.  WMATA is a terrible system.  But I'd be happy if we could get some sidewalks and bike lanes in our neighborhood.  A real help would be a circulator bus system for the neighborhoods surrounding our subway station.  The current system runs point to point and doesn't reduce car trips to the grocery store and local mall.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Our society's population is expanding at a rapid rate. The typical modern day modes of transportation, while convenient, have a few downsides.  Every mean of transportation, with the exception of walking, has costs that come with it.  This ranges from having to pay for the cost of gas to paying the physical price of not getting the proper amount of exercise our bodies where meant to have via walking to our destinations. There is one option that could solve these issues.  Imagine a small grass field, similar to the ones you find at playgrounds, with a small parking lot.  Within this parking lot would be a couple of electric powered cars attached to power stations. These setups would be available every few blocks (about as frequent as modern bus-stops). Within the field beside the cars stations would be stationary work out equipment. These would be modeled after the free-to-use exercise stations in places like China. They would have equipment such as: bench presses, ellipticals, bikes, etc.  All of these would be wired underground to the charging station attached to the cars. The energy created from the movement of each device will directly charge the cars in the station.  Off to the side of each piece of equipment would be a touchscreen. A person can set up an account at their local government buildings, providing a valid driver's license,e-mail address, and credit or debit card number. When signed in, each account can track how much a person exercised and convert it to an 'available miles for usage' number.  This means that the more a person uses this equipment, creating more energy for the cars, the more miles the person would be allowed to use the car for.  This however also means, that prior to using the car they would have to deduct the amount of miles they plan to use from their account.  If the person should go over their allotted miles, they will then be subsequently charged on their provided credit card.  This encourages people to work-out more at these stations, so they can avoid the fees for using the car. This set-up would immensely help those who financially can't afford their own form of transportation, while promoting a healthier lifestyle in a way that could easily fit into our society's demanding everyday regime.

Bike taxies -- hook up a carriage to a bike and charge people for short-distance rides

I think that a new mod of transportation in my neighborhood would be a electric bike taxi system. It would be an electric bike pulling a carriage that hold up to 3 other people. The system will travel from people's houses to their work place, local shopping centers and local entertainment places.

I think the idea of rickshaws are a good one.  But in most places, like cities or suburban areas with hills, a traditional rickshaw wouldn't be practical.  I think that a bike with an electric motor and a cab on the back would be a good solution.  It's nicer for the environment and a more personal connection than a taxi.  Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

My Idea would be to make the alleyways in my city a lot more bike friendly.  Honestly they are very rarely ever used by the city or homeowners so to make them this way would be beneficial for so many others. This would I believe encourage more people to use bicycles since I know I am terrified when riding my bicycle next to extremely lage and fast moving automobile traffic on my cities roads and highways.

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

I imagine a type of highway for bicycles where people can use on and off ramps easily to reach their destination. They wont have to worry about cars since its a bike only highway system. it will get people to their destination quicker since they dont have to stop at traffic lights and watch out for pedestrians.

I would like to see a bicycle highway.  It would go the length of regular highways, but be for bikes and pedestrians.  It should be wide enough for fast moving road cyclist, it should have passing lanes, and little road crossings.  There should be frequent on and off ramps. Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

It is not innovative in terms of the whole world, but would be very innovative in my community - bike shares. The area where I live is suburban, so difficult to get enough riders for frequent mass transit. And it's too spread out for just walking. I think there should be "speed walking" lanes set up.  Separate from where pedestrians walk and separate from bike trails.  I would love it if there were "fast lanes" around the strip malls and commercial areas of my city.  I tend to speed walk and get so frustrated with trying to dart and dodge around people. I think having a dedicated lane to faster walkers or a "passing lane" would really help with the flow of pedestrian traffic and its effectiveness.

Rent a cycle, a set of motorcycles that you can pay for per hour to take and go to the store or rent for the day for work on warm days. they'd have a wheel lock like the citi bikes in New york so you put your card in and go

Not just in my neighborhood but metro-wide, my city recently established time share bicycles people can rent and ride when they have a short distance to travel. The bikes are all of the same design, having a large sturdy frame painted light blue, three gears (the gear box is inside the rear wheel axle, and LED blinker lights for safety. Necessarily, it's a one-size-fits-all arrangement; there's no way to raise or lower the seat unless you carry your own tools around with you, so if you're a tall person and use one of these bikes you'll be knocking yourself in the chin with your knees.

Our society's population is expanding at a rapid rate. The typical modern day modes of transportation, while convenient, have a few downsides.  Every mean of transportation, with the exception of walking, has costs that come with it.  This ranges from having to pay for the cost of gas to paying the physical price of not getting the proper amount of exercise our bodies where meant to have via walking to our destinations. There is one option that could solve these issues.  Imagine a small grass field, similar to the ones you find at playgrounds, with a small parking lot.  Within this parking lot would be a couple of electric powered cars attached to power stations. These setups would be available every few blocks (about as frequent as modern bus-stops). Within the field beside the cars stations would be stationary work out equipment. These would be modeled after the free-to-use exercise stations in places like China. They would have equipment such as: bench presses, ellipticals, bikes, etc.  All of these would be wired underground to the charging station attached to the cars. The energy created from the movement of each device will directly charge the cars in the station.  Off to the side of each piece of equipment would be a touchscreen. A person can set up an account at their local government buildings, providing a valid driver's license,e-mail address, and credit or debit card number. When signed in, each account can track how much a person exercised and convert it to an 'available miles for usage' number.  This means that the more a person uses this equipment, creating more energy for the cars, the more miles the person would be allowed to use the car for.  This however also means, that prior to using the car they would have to deduct the amount of miles they plan to use from their account.  If the person should go over their allotted miles, they will then be subsequently charged on their provided credit card.  This encourages people to work-out more at these stations, so they can avoid the fees for using the car. This set-up would immensely help those who financially can't afford their own form of transportation, while promoting a healthier lifestyle in a way that could easily fit into our society's demanding everyday regime.

an app that takes into account both traffic and train congestion, as well as the speeds to walk or bike, to tell you the fastest mode of transport to a destination. For example, train  might typically be quicker to get from A to B, but when trains are spaced 20 minutes apart late at night and there is no traffic, driving/taxi would be faster.

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

I can imagine my neighborhood having a high speed maglev train. It will levitate on top of a rail that will span around the entire city to avoid traffic. It will be fast and efficient to provide good transportation services.

I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. The entire system could be above street level. The speed would be about 5 mph with platforms every block.

My neighborhood has little walk-ability due to poor road quality and an abundance of speed bumps. My Idea is simple in that they can add multiple lanes above the street for bikes and people walking. This would be on par with what cities have over major crossings but will cost relatively little money compared with adding a train or increasing the once daily buses. This would also allow any expansion of the roads under the walkways and reduce the 10 or so deaths a year from cars hitting people when they are just walking on the side of the road.

Chicago - Chicago has a great system and phenomenal public transport. As far as transportation though I wish the highways in the city acted like slotted cars, similar to trains in which in every highway entrance there would be a dedicated lane/railway for vehicles to travel at fast speeds like trains. Elon Musk's Hyperloop, Hi speed trains traveling in tubes above the city.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

My idea is a combination of self driving cars, rideshare and a train. Commuters would pay for a ticket and a line of connected self driving cars would take commuters going the same route/direction to a certain dropoff point, like a train does. Then when the string of cars reaches the stop point, each passenger can enter their desired destination into the touchpad screen in the car and they would be driven to their individual destinations. The self driving cars would break off individually from the train to take these passengers, then they'd return on their own to the "train station" to go pick up more passengers.

My idea would be a people mover, basically like a combination of a elevator and a train. It would be a box people stand in and it glides on a track really quickly. They would look like long boxes and hang from long lines that steer it and provide power. Their main concern would be to get many people somewhere extremely fast and efficiently, not really for comfort.

My city would benefit from an elevated and enclosed train line. Regional rail is the preferred choice for many commuters but is unreliable and frustrating due to weather and traffic related delays. There should be a train system in our county. It should have a magnetic railway so it can be as green as possible and use light power.

A new transportation system in my neighborhood would be a railway system available to rural and outlying areas.  It would stretch along the roadway and connect to different cities and stops much like a trolley system or train system.  People could get on and off at different points.  They could schedule to be picked up at different times during the day.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

In the future, self driving cabs can be summoned via mobile phone, to pick up the driver and take them to a particular destination via a touchscreen or other similar interface located inside the vehicle.  Some difficulty may occur if the passenger is unsure of the address of his or her destination, but a trained attendant can be called to determine the location for the passenger.

A train that can transport passengers fast in between the major areas in the neighborhood, for example to schools, the downtown area, the performing arts theater, shopping districts, the airport etc. It doesn't have to stop very often like a bus but an instead be used for getting between major areas and can be supported by the bus system.

My idea is a combination of self driving cars, rideshare and a train. Commuters would pay for a ticket and a line of connected self driving cars would take commuters going the same route/direction to a certain dropoff point, like a train does. Then when the string of cars reaches the stop point, each passenger can enter their desired destination into the touchpad screen in the car and they would be driven to their individual destinations. The self driving cars would break off individually from the train to take these passengers, then they'd return on their own to the "train station" to go pick up more passengers.

I think a bullet train would be very useful. A train that can transport passengers fast in between the major areas in the neighborhood, for example to schools, the downtown area, the performing arts theater, shopping districts, the airport etc. It doesn't have to stop very often like a bus but an instead be used for getting between major areas and can be supported by the bus system.

My neighborhood added an above ground train similar to the "L" in Chicago.  It runs along the highways bringing people downtown from the suburbs. I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

I'm envisioning a system of small feet-sized platforms, along with a handle at arm-height, running on street-level light rail tracks throughout the city. Like an escalator, these continuously run in a loop around the city/neighborhood, and passengers can jump on and off at will. (Access would be prepaid and mediated by a RFID chip card and scanner on the devices.) These would probably move at about 5-10 miles per hour - faster than regular walking, but slower than other forms of transport that require more infrastructure and potential for danger. It'd kinda be like, Razor scooters but built into the city landscape and available at-will. Like a bike-share system, but always there and with no energy or exercise expended. This would be a great way for tired people to avoid walking, and would speed up trips to the closest subway station/bus stop.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.
Use a sky rail train to transport people.  Similar to a subway, but rather than below ground, it would be above ground.

Subways with shorter runs. NYC is filled with unused tunnels and stations. Get them up and running. Also, allow people who use any sort of wheel-based transport, that's not a bus or car, to use the bike lanes.

I'm envisioning a system of small feet-sized platforms, along with a handle at arm-height, running on street-level light rail tracks throughout the city. Like an escalator, these continuously run in a loop around the city/neighborhood, and passengers can jump on and off at will. (Access would be prepaid and mediated by a RFID chip card and scanner on the devices.) These would probably move at about 5-10 miles per hour - faster than regular walking, but slower than other forms of transport that require more infrastructure and potential for danger. It'd kinda be like, Razor scooters but built into the city landscape and available at-will. Like a bike-share system, but always there and with no energy or exercise expended. This would be a great way for tired people to avoid walking, and would speed up trips to the closest subway station/bus stop.

An elevated wagon wheel shaped, high speed rail system would be excellent. The outer ring would be bi-directional allowing quick transport around the city. The spokes would be bi-directional and allow quick transport from inner and outer within the quadrants.

an app that takes into account both traffic and train congestion, as well as the speeds to walk or bike, to tell you the fastest mode of transport to a destination. For example, train  might typically be quicker to get from A to B, but when trains are spaced 20 minutes apart late at night and there is no traffic, driving/taxi would be faster.

Picture a vehicle of transport that almost resembles a giant scooter. But the thing is that more than a few people can ride it at a time and it can be programmed to go to the destination that you need. There is also the option of seatbelts or straps that can prevent the riders from falling out or off. In the back of the scooter object would be a large area where personal baggage and things can be kept and it automatically locks once enough passengers are aboard. This area is kept locked by the operator of the scooter ride. On each side of the edges of the scooter ride are places for phones and other devices to be plugged in. The scooter ride would be plugged in to keep it charged up and there would be solar panels on the back to make sure that the ride can be energized and charged for a moment's notice.

I think a bullet train would be very useful. A train that can transport passengers fast in between the major areas in the neighborhood, for example to schools, the downtown area, the performing arts theater, shopping districts, the airport etc. It doesn't have to stop very often like a bus but an instead be used for getting between major areas and can be supported by the bus system.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

I'd like to see shuttle trams in my area. It's a small section based urban area that has about four different areas all residents will have to visit at some point in time. If we had a shuttle system that specifically transported people from a central point to the four primary destinations it would incredibly reduce the use of fossil fuels, traffic, and accidents in the area.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

I am thinking about a flying transport system. It should fly with balloon or air system. It should not need engine or fuel. So expence would be cheap. It should occupy 15-25 people at a time. It moves with air adjustment, drag, thrust, pressure etc. The flyer lands every important point in a city. So people can travel across the city with less time and money. No traffic block, signals, air pollution etc.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.
