My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

In the future, self driving cabs can be summoned via mobile phone, to pick up the driver and take them to a particular destination via a touchscreen or other similar interface located inside the vehicle.  Some difficulty may occur if the passenger is unsure of the address of his or her destination, but a trained attendant can be called to determine the location for the passenger.

Picture a vehicle of transport that almost resembles a giant scooter. But the thing is that more than a few people can ride it at a time and it can be programmed to go to the destination that you need. There is also the option of seatbelts or straps that can prevent the riders from falling out or off. In the back of the scooter object would be a large area where personal baggage and things can be kept and it automatically locks once enough passengers are aboard. This area is kept locked by the operator of the scooter ride. On each side of the edges of the scooter ride are places for phones and other devices to be plugged in. The scooter ride would be plugged in to keep it charged up and there would be solar panels on the back to make sure that the ride can be energized and charged for a moment's notice.
Vehicles that circle around a block, which allow for passengers to jump right on.  Not necessarily a bus.

This system would be made up of a continuous stream of drivers of small vehicles.  The vehicles might be three-wheelers or some other form of small, motorized vehicles.  Besides the driver, the vehicles would only have space for two other occupants.  The vehicles would continue on the same busy stretch of road.  In other words, they would be on a fixed path.  Also, there would be a large number of these vehicles, a constant stream, so the passenger would never have to wait longer than a minute or two.  The passengers would have prepaid for the service, so there would be no need to exchange money with the driver.

Have a system of sidewalk rail cars that attaches to the sidewalks of a city. Each rail car can carry passenger anywhere in the city to any destination and stop at any time on its route. This system of transportation will greatly reduce city congestion while doesn't interfere with any of the vehicles that are already on the road.

AutoTram - The network of AutoTram tracks criss-cross major streets and also cut across the city in subterranean tunnels. Instead of larger vehicles that carry many people, but have rigid, pre-defined routes, the AutoTram is reserved through the internet, and will pick up and drop off several small groups of passengers who have stops along an arithmetically chosen route.

A social platform similar to facebook related to all things travel. People would be able to connect with others and find people traveling the same route. One person would volunteer to drive and would pick everyone up, and their cards are automatically charged the rate in which gas costs along with depreciation of vehicle. If 3 riders, each pay 1/3.. 4 riders pay 1/4, etc.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

Have a system of sidewalk rail cars that attaches to the sidewalks of a city. Each rail car can carry passenger anywhere in the city to any destination and stop at any time on its route. This system of transportation will greatly reduce city congestion while doesn't interfere with any of the vehicles that are already on the road.

A circulatory bus system consisting of two vehicle traveling in opposite directions on a set route but with no designated stops. The route in my small district of the city takes approximately 20 minutes to to circumnavigate and consists of goth commercial districts. One would never be more than 10 minutes fro being able to hail the "jitney" bus. This alleviates the use of regular bus system which is much more focused on funneling clientele to central city and runs more or less eradicately.It envisions using current tech and is human centered. It is innovative in it's goals not hardware.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

AutoTram - The network of AutoTram tracks criss-cross major streets and also cut across the city in subterranean tunnels. Instead of larger vehicles that carry many people, but have rigid, pre-defined routes, the AutoTram is reserved through the internet, and will pick up and drop off several small groups of passengers who have stops along an arithmetically chosen route.
A personal transport vehicle, perhaps shaped like a scooter or segway, that collapses and folds into a backpack with straps that retract.

Picture a vehicle of transport that almost resembles a giant scooter. But the thing is that more than a few people can ride it at a time and it can be programmed to go to the destination that you need. There is also the option of seatbelts or straps that can prevent the riders from falling out or off. In the back of the scooter object would be a large area where personal baggage and things can be kept and it automatically locks once enough passengers are aboard. This area is kept locked by the operator of the scooter ride. On each side of the edges of the scooter ride are places for phones and other devices to be plugged in. The scooter ride would be plugged in to keep it charged up and there would be solar panels on the back to make sure that the ride can be energized and charged for a moment's notice.

Moped rentals. Like bike rentals, these are open access places where someone can rent a small vehicle like a moped or scooter by using their credit card or maybe their ID as their "deposit". If they steal the vehicle or damage it, they are billed, but otherwise, must simply have the vehicle back in their stall at the designated time. On-board computers diagnose the vehicles to check for problems or missing parts, and a GPS keeps track of them for asset protection and data collection purposes.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

I live in a chicago suburb and I believe that driverless cars are the future.  But what I actually prefer is everyone driving their own vehicle, what i actually hope happens in the future is that licenses are much harder to get...there are so many people out there with no clue of the rules of the road and it is hazardous to everyone around them.

I'd like to see vehicles that will fly, take up little space on the ground, go up and down more like a helicopter so large parking runways are not needed. These cars would almost fly themselves and need little direction other than where they're going.

Our new transportation system would involve golf carts.  Several roads would be designated as golf-cart-only areas and include parking.  New paths could be created because they take up less space than normal roads and even designated lanes on existing roads could be defined to use existing infrastructure.  The environment would be healthier with less pollutants, crowding would be less due to smaller size vehicles, and it would even encourage healthier lifestyles out in the air and sunshine.

This idea would have to be built in a city near a river, or attached to a solar farm because it relies on using naturally produced hydroelectric or solar power. Basically, it's a train on an electrified track, that moves slowly and stops at intervals in a big loop throughout a city. It would make stops the same way buses make stops. If you rode it long enough, you'd wind up at the same stop you got on at.  It relies completely on green energy, no exhaust just some electric motors driving the cars. People would be able to get on and just ride to where they needed to get off, leaving their personal vehicle in a parking area. It could be configured to have small, individual cars maybe fitted with a GPS system so you could tell it where you needed to go and it would get you as close as possible. The main idea is it would be free and the city could tax businesses a small amount for serving their parts of town, just to help pay maintenance costs.

I get out of my house and before I leave my apartment on my 12th floor I just press a button on my app on my phone to type a location of the place i need to go.This would in turn contact all local data base systems of GPS based transport systems irrespective of the vendors available or government supported transport systems which include Cabs,Buses,Trains,Subway,3 Wheelers and most importantly assuming the people of the future will care a lot more about the environment and all the people who are going alone in a 5 seater car would have a option of sharing there carbon footprint left by the vehicle.And if the co-ordinates of the person with the car and the co-ordinates of the Person who is using the app matches then a Random Unique (one time use)Number or Picture or Anything which would be visible from atleast 10 feet away on a Min 6 inch screen.However this interface can be avoided by tracking the dots on the GPS system or by sending a snap shot of the car number or a photo of the person himself which will be destroyed automatically by the system once the person is down from the Vehicle.Punch Line Before I get to the main gates of the apartment.I should have the list of Vehicles available to me and the time it would take the vehicle to reach my place based on GPS and traffic conditions and also how much time would it take to reach my destination again based on real time traffic conditions and also most importantly.if i take  the public transport system.How much time would it take to reach the same destination and also how much Carbon foot print would i save from doing it.And also the time required by the vehicle to reach the local transport systems if it is not a walkable distance.There are many more ,But i think that is enough for the day.

Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.
Something like a bus stop, however you would be picked up and dropped off by someone who might be passing through, other drivers, company vehicles (like UPS trucks), etc.

I have recently returned a small-to-mid-sized city (60,000+ people, down from over 125,000 at its peak) after 20 years, and the public transportation system here is non-existent, Uber does not exist here (the nearest key city of 250,000+ people is 40 miles away), and there are 2 very small taxi companies which are not cost-effective or nearby enough to be efficient to use. In a situation like this, any alternative transportation would be beneficial, as this is a city where without a car/traditional vehicle, your ability to get even basic errands accomplished is compromised greatly. The city cited low ridership and rising fuel costs to keep the giant, hulking city buses operating as the reason for cancelling the public routes. My proposal would be to have smaller, and highly fuel-efficient modified Sprinter vans, each serving one small portion of the community, and running a smaller amount of the fleet during off-peak hours. This would allow the most economical and efficient model for the community to have access to needed transportation.

More companies should be like Google and provide transportation for their employees. Hoover boats that glide across bays 10 times faster that farries plowing throw the water.

The current highway infa structure in this country is outdated and in disrepair. We should reinvest in our bridges and highways and retrofit them with sensors to aid in the development of autonomous vehicles. Thus reducing gridlock, emissions, accidents, and travel times.

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

I think we need to tap into the power of magnets.  We can use solar panels all through the roads, then use them to power magnets on the road.  The vehicles will have oppositely polarized magnets that will be controllable in the car.  I guess it will work like those trains that use magnets, but someone smart will figure out a way to control the magnets independently.  The car battery will power the magnet on the car, and can be shut off immediately once the power is cut in case of emergency.

This is about a single user system. It is similar to a bicycle. But it's does not run on road. It has specific path made only for this vehicle like a railway track. The track has frictionless surface. The bottom of the vehicle is also frictionless. The vehicle does not have round wheels. But instead flat frictionless bottom (but also can be frictionless wheel). Vehicle does not need fuel. First we clips the vehicle to the track manually. We sit and unclip the vehicle from the track and apply some mechanical force just like in the bicycle to move forward. After that the vehicle moves without any force. Because there is no friction.We just sit and relax. When we apply brake, clips is attached the bottom of track and it stops. The track should be spread all across the city. Vehicle is portable. We take it from home or rent from government.

A central hub for a ridesharing service that provides cars for small groups to take to neighboring towns. I live in a rural area, a few minutes from a very small village. The nearest SMALL city is about 30 minutes away, and the nearest decent sized city is almost an hour away. A ridesharing service would make accessing these places much easier, and if the company provided the car (for a fee, of course), those without vehicles could be serviced.

My idea is of a drive-on subway. Just like cars can be driven onto ferries, where a person can stay in there car while the ferry transports them across the water and then drive off the ferry onto land again once the ferry has reached its destination, drive-on subways would allow something similar. Certain stops would not be for people boarding, but for cars. The cars would go into specialized compartments and the drivers would be required to stay in their vehicles so as not to cause any danger. The cars would be allowed to drive off of the subway vehicle at certain stops too. This way, people could be using both the subway system and their cars at the same time, so they end up with the benefits of both! The subway can take them somewhere along its route, and their car can take them the rest of the way where the subway doesn't go. It would cut down on traffic and probably encourage people to take the subway even when they're not using their car. A lot of people are hesitant to try public transit, but once they try it, they find it efficient, so this would really show people how efficient it can be. 

While on board the subway, the people in cars would see lights in their compartment, just like a stoplight, telling them when it is okay to drive off. The doors would automatically open at every stop where cars are allowed to exit, and then a green light would go on that the driver could easily see, so they'd know it's their time to drive off. When it turns to yellow, it means the doors are closing soon, so the driver should either hurry up or choose to stay on. Of course, the doors would have motion-sensors so they wouldn't close on a car either way. There would also be maps inside each compartment with cars showing where the stops are, so a driver can prepare for where they need to get off at.

I see the potential for self-driving cars to replace taxi services. People would call an automated line, or perhaps interact with a site/app on their computers/phones, to schedule to be picked up by the service. Meanwhile, a network that keeps track of all self-driving cars in its region would figure out which car was closest or would have to deviate the least to pick up the passenger within 5-10 minutes of being hailed. These cars could be compartmentalized to hold four or six passengers without individuals having to worry about undesired contact with the other passengers. The cars could run on electricity and the network would consider battery life with regards to planning routes and destinations.

I see the potential for self-driving cars to replace taxi services. People would call an automated line, or perhaps interact with a site/app on their computers/phones, to schedule to be picked up by the service. Meanwhile, a network that keeps track of all self-driving cars in its region would figure out which car was closest or would have to deviate the least to pick up the passenger within 5-10 minutes of being hailed. These cars could be compartmentalized to hold four or six passengers without individuals having to worry about undesired contact with the other passengers. The cars could run on electricity and the network would consider battery life with regards to planning routes and destinations.

I live in a town right on the ocean and there are many canals here. I think a canoe taxi service would be really convenient and fun. It wouldn't get people to their desired locations super fast but it would allow people to travel leisurely and enjoy the scenery along the way. It would also be really healthy for the people driving the canoes and help them to stay fit.

I live in a very rural area that doesn't get bus service because of low population. My idea would be a bus service that runs on the same premise as a taxi service... when someone in the area would need a ride, the bus would alter its route to pick up a passenger. That way, the remote area could be serviced by mass transit, yet wouldn't have to waste fuel or money driving to the remote area all of the time. These requests could be put in via phone, web portal, or e-mail.

Automated taxi service. Would have several dispatch stations in key areas of city. Person could call for a ride from an app on their phone and it would send a car to them. The software could calculate rate for the trip and make you pay before as a confirmation before sending a car out. Car could then drive customer to said destination.  Self driveable cars that could provide a much better service than the often RUDE cab drivers could provide. Plus, I trust a robot way more than some of these morons driving!

Self-driving cars where the cars are guided on directed routes by computers. The cars are not owned by any one person but are paid for using some sort of subscription service, so they are common property of users.

I see self driving cars for personal transportation. There will be several sizes available depending on the number of passengers. There will be cars for a single passenger and buses for large groups. You will pay by mile as well as a monthly fee to access the service. Almost all deliveries will be performed by drone. The postal service itself will begin to implement this delivery method on some routes. There will be specific roadways built to accommodate these new vehicles and special lanes, much like a carpool lane, that are available to only automated transports. Traffic, pollution and accidents will decrease sharply and it will be difficult to even obtain a license for a private vehicle although not impossible. This will largely be in place at the turn of the next century but some will be in service sooner.

But there are plenty of people who would use a rural bus . A bus could pick up multiple people in the rural area. The school bus service already does this , I don't know why the city could come up with a plan to offer public transportation for adults living in rural areas. It's just very stupid that this is not a thing in Houston .

My idea is to have a service like zipcar in which someone rents the use of a car by paying a monthly fee except that it would be mopeds for individuals or something larger like a pick up truck.  Just more options than a small smart car.  I used to live in Tokyo and driving a car there was awful but not something like a moped or motorcycle because they could ride in between the cars.  A larger vehicle like a pickup truck would be good for people who need to rent something to haul furniture or something like that but don't want to drive all the way to a car rental place or Lowe's to get the truck.  Everything would be rentable using an app and the cars would feature opening the doors and starting the cars through the app itself.

Atlanta could have a much, much wider public transportation system. The subway would go to many different neighborhoods, extending in different directions instead of being a simple cross. More money and attention would be given to public transportation, extending bus and trolley service while halting the neverending expansion of parking and roads. Much more attention will be given to cyclist and pedestrian safety, with enforced ticketing for drivers that ignore traffic laws along with more bike lanes and pedestrian crossings.

The new transportation is a light rail that also includes trolley service for my neighborhood and city. For $1.00 each way, the light rail runs from east to west and from north to south. In addition, the light rail runs until midnight Monday through Friday and 24 hours a day on weekends. The light rail takes you to all major events in the city and portion of all fares go to pay for school resources in the community.

From small towns to big cities, public transportation is helping to generate new vitality like never

before. Beautiful, walkable town squares combine residential, retail, office, recreation and public

transportation features to make community living easy. New bus services and light rail extensions

improve mobility and ease congestion. Even the smallest adjustments, like widening sidewalks and

adding bikeways, can provide dramatic impact and value.

This idea is called 'Rolling taxi'. The system is a large ball. single large ball. Inside the ball, people can sit . People sit or stand at the centre of the ball. As ball rolls on specially made road the centre region doesn't move. The centre region where people sit is attached to the  inner surface of the ball in a special manner so that people do not move. The speed and direction of the ball can control using technology. The ball roll all across the city with people inside on a special track. Speed is high and expense is less. Also it is fun.

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.

a new system in my neighborhood could be bicycle - but have taxi options, so additional seats attached, perhaps rickshaw style. A person would pedal (no motors, so no issues with being on road) and there would be a seat on the back for a rider. There would be a helmet with each rider.

I think that a bike with an electric motor and a cab on the back would be a good solution.  It's nicer for the environment and a more personal connection than a taxi.  Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

A bus with 8 off road tires and a strong engine that could easily get the passengers through even the snowiest of days. We can call it the Wolverine.

A bus that has a design similar to a hydrofoil boat. The bus would run on special tracks that would be parallel to each other on opposite sides of a street. This passenger compartment would be on top, with the "foils" connecting to the two tracks. There would be open space underneath the passenger compartment where the road is. This way, the bus could move unimpeded by traffic, while also not disrupting traffic itself. Also, passengers would not even see the traffic below them, making the ride smooth, comfortable, and consistent.

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

I would like to see a bicycle highway.  It would go the length of regular highways, but be for bikes and pedestrians. My Idea would be to make the alleyways in my city a lot more bike friendly.  Honestly they are very rarely ever used by the city or homeowners so to make them this way would be beneficial for so many others. This would I believe encourage more people to use bicycles since I know I am terrified when riding my bicycle next to extremely lage and fast moving automobile traffic on my cities roads and highways.

I imagine a series of widening arches or loops of roadway and of several different sizes to accompany different types of pubic transport. Cars wouldn't be allowed in the city but stored at various exit point garages which would be provided by the city. Small roads would have small shuttles, large roads would have large fast moving shuttles that span the city. Independently, smaller walkways would be used for pedestrians and cyclists (and other man powered or tiny engine machines.) Larger walkways could become festival street fair type roads that are common in places like Greece.

I think the idea of rickshaws are a good one.  But in most places, like cities or suburban areas with hills, a traditional rickshaw wouldn't be practical.  I think that a bike with an electric motor and a cab on the back would be a good solution.  It's nicer for the environment and a more personal connection than a taxi.  Plus, traffic might be alleviated a bit since there's less cars on the road.

This is about a single user system. It is similar to a bicycle. But it's does not run on road. It has specific path made only for this vehicle like a railway track. The track has frictionless surface. The bottom of the vehicle is also frictionless. The vehicle does not have round wheels. But instead flat frictionless bottom (but also can be frictionless wheel). Vehicle does not need fuel. First we clips the vehicle to the track manually. We sit and unclip the vehicle from the track and apply some mechanical force just like in the bicycle to move forward. After that the vehicle moves without any force. Because there is no friction.We just sit and relax. When we apply brake, clips is attached the bottom of track and it stops. The track should be spread all across the city. Vehicle is portable. We take it from home or rent from government.

I'm envisioning a system of small feet-sized platforms, along with a handle at arm-height, running on street-level light rail tracks throughout the city. Like an escalator, these continuously run in a loop around the city/neighborhood, and passengers can jump on and off at will. (Access would be prepaid and mediated by a RFID chip card and scanner on the devices.) These would probably move at about 5-10 miles per hour - faster than regular walking, but slower than other forms of transport that require more infrastructure and potential for danger. It'd kinda be like, Razor scooters but built into the city landscape and available at-will. Like a bike-share system, but always there and with no energy or exercise expended. This would be a great way for tired people to avoid walking, and would speed up trips to the closest subway station/bus stop.

I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. The entire system could be above street level. The speed would be about 5 mph with platforms every block.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

A sort of rail line, but it's a single rail and has many hanging carts. The carts hold maybe 4 people at a time, like a taxi. The price would be cheaper than a bus and they would arrive quickly when you need them. You could push a button on poles that are located around the city, far more often than bus stops, and the cart will come to you quickly and take you directly to your destination. No need for bus drivers or waiting for traffic!
A rail system that is build from the ground up. This would be capable of high speeds typically not able to travel when driving or on another train. This would make work transit much faster.
I would love to see more light rail transit added to Pittsburgh to alleviate some of the traffic congestion under ground

I live in NYC. Travel is not too difficult, with the only real concern being the price of a subway ticket or a taxi ride. With more options, they become cheaper, but space is also an issue. I believe that since the roads and the undergrounds are already full, the only real option is to expand transportation above ground, such as on rails between buildings. This would create tiers of roads to be used by trains, that would speed up and cheapen the overall problem.

A rail that goes back and forth from campus with known arrival times would be ideal for students to travel from campus to their homes and neighborhoods. This would be like a miniature above ground subway.

An electric monorail with a few cars that travel between the shopping center about a mile a way from us through the little downtown and stopping at the regional rail station a mile the other direction from us. It would have 2 or 3 trains that run back and forth all day and night transporting people between those two major zones in our neighborhood, eliminating the need for cars to travel nearby.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.
I would like to see an expanded light rail system with more of a neighborhood connection.  Right now our light rail pretty much just connects the Downtown core with the airport.

I thought of a light rail and below-ground subway system could be transport people to and from a downtown arena we have here in metro Columbus, Ohio. Right now most people use cars and a few people use buses, but that's about it. Congestion could be decreased substantially provided people who normally commute by themselves to and from hockey games that take place two to three times a week. This would solve congestion issues on the nights where these games take place and reduce the need for a large amount of safety and security officers to direct traffic and play crowd control on weekends and Fridays.
monorail loop from college to mall to hospital to rail line

Monorail through the city! Just like Disneyland, this city-wide system allows you to see the city from a bird's eye! Simply get on at one of the many stations around town and enjoy your ride without stops, traffic or bad weather. The rails above the city means growth can continue without getting in the way of transport, and means you can watch the world below!

It is similar to the monorail at Wald Disney world. It goes all around the town and stops when people use an app and state they need a pickup. It can go to individual streets and addresses because it needs no rails, but can use multiple-line systems to navigate the town. It makes scheduled stops, but can also be called by the app. It is free, paid for by local and state taxes, and very clean and quick. People use it for a wide variety of uses, from nights on the town, to grocery shopping, to work commute. It is very safe, clean and fun.

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.

A monorail system that is above everyone.  There would be rail cars on it that go in a multitude of directions.  People can still use the other forms of transportation, but this form would be strictly for people looking to get around in the city.  They would park their cars before entering the city, and use this quick system for getting around.  No more crowded, expensive parking in the city.

My transportation suggestion (in my town) would be to avoid the freeways and allow me to get to work using a rail way-type system.  This would be either underground or overground.  This is not an something that we see on the west coast a lot, so it would be very helpful to many commuters in the town I live.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.

I'm envisioning a system of small feet-sized platforms, along with a handle at arm-height, running on street-level light rail tracks throughout the city. Like an escalator, these continuously run in a loop around the city/neighborhood, and passengers can jump on and off at will. (Access would be prepaid and mediated by a RFID chip card and scanner on the devices.) These would probably move at about 5-10 miles per hour - faster than regular walking, but slower than other forms of transport that require more infrastructure and potential for danger. It'd kinda be like, Razor scooters but built into the city landscape and available at-will. Like a bike-share system, but always there and with no energy or exercise expended. This would be a great way for tired people to avoid walking, and would speed up trips to the closest subway station/bus stop.

This new transportation system is a bullet train in the sky, able to span around the neighborhood with up to 700 passengers in under two minutes. It's sleek silver coat is never late, and always early to make sure everyone gets where they need to go. The rails float there in the sky, ready to carry this majestic beauty to the ends of the neighborhood making sure everyone is early

From small towns to big cities, public transportation is helping to generate new vitality like never

before. Beautiful, walkable town squares combine residential, retail, office, recreation and public

transportation features to make community living easy. New bus services and light rail extensions

improve mobility and ease congestion. Even the smallest adjustments, like widening sidewalks and

adding bikeways, can provide dramatic impact and value.

A system could allow cars to drive up to a rail station and be loaded onto a platform. It could be optional to have the driver stay inside for short trips or get out for longer trips. The platforms could then allow cars to be quickly transported along rail lines instead of having to consume fuel. These can be used on older less used rail tracks, making use of existing infrastructure and help clear traffic along busy highways.

I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. The entire system could be above street level. The speed would be about 5 mph with platforms every block.

The new transportation is a light rail that also includes trolley service for my neighborhood and city. For $1.00 each way, the light rail runs from east to west and from north to south. In addition, the light rail runs until midnight Monday through Friday and 24 hours a day on weekends. The light rail takes you to all major events in the city and portion of all fares go to pay for school resources in the community.

I live in a neighborhood near an excellent metro system, but not walkable to it. I would like a people-mover sort of system that travels through the neighborhood making the existing metro station more accessible. Perhaps small cars or pods at the end of each street that travel along an elevated rail directly to the metro station.

Our City has no nearby neighbors. Any future ideas are going to require a rail system, preferably something fast like japanese trains. Maglev technology which will allow faster travel from coastal towns and cities to the capital.

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.
A electric scooter sharing program for getting around town without having to drive a car and use too much gas or take up too much space.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

I'd like to see the railroad tracks by our house be repurposed as a walking and biking route for the neighborhood.  It would be really sweet if they could use that and carry the corridor all the way to the nearest town and shopping area.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.

A Bus system, within the metro area that was funded by a tax on gas purchased by individual commuters. In otherwords, free to the people who use the bus, and costs the people who don't. have the busses rinning from a set time like 6am to 9 pm  and pickups are every 15 min, so you never need to bother with knowing the bus schedule. Also, have all busses make a stop in the center of town so if you need to get across town, take a bus from you house to the center, and from there to your final destination. There should be a bus passing every school, hospital, shopping center, library ect. Simply run smaller buses on less popular routes, use smaller buses in general. make one special route for city to city transfers. The system needs to be free or very affordable, fast and convenient. No need to waste resources and infrastructure on schedules, call centers, web pages, just keep it simple and convenient.

It makes scheduled stops, but can also be called by the app. It is free, paid for by local and state taxes, and very clean and quick. People use it for a wide variety of uses, from nights on the town, to grocery shopping, to work commute. It is very safe, clean and fun.

A jitney that makes local stops within a few miles of a small town.  My town would be perfect as an example.  Most errands can be run in a 10 mile radius.  This includes, post office, shopping centers, DMV, library, etc.  there could be a call in to meet at nearest cross stop.  We have 2 main roads that run through town so this would be very easy to implement.

I'd like to see the railroad tracks by our house be repurposed as a walking and biking route for the neighborhood.  It would be really sweet if they could use that and carry the corridor all the way to the nearest town and shopping area.

A Bus system, within the metro area that was funded by a tax on gas purchased by individual commuters. In otherwords, free to the people who use the bus, and costs the people who don't. have the busses rinning from a set time like 6am to 9 pm  and pickups are every 15 min, so you never need to bother with knowing the bus schedule. Also, have all busses make a stop in the center of town so if you need to get across town, take a bus from you house to the center, and from there to your final destination. There should be a bus passing every school, hospital, shopping center, library ect. Simply run smaller buses on less popular routes, use smaller buses in general. make one special route for city to city transfers. The system needs to be free or very affordable, fast and convenient. No need to waste resources and infrastructure on schedules, call centers, web pages, just keep it simple and convenient.
I think there should be bikes that you can easily rent. You can get them in the major shopping areas and drive them around town to get excercise as well as helping to use less gasoline.

I think that an interesting mode of transport in my mountain town would be a ski lift type system that runs behind the businesses on main street and stops at every corner. The reason for this is our huge lack of parking and the congestion that cars cause in the shopping district. It would be unusual and fun and it could connect to the large parking area at the convention center.

I'd like to see the railroad tracks by our house be repurposed as a walking and biking route for the neighborhood.  It would be really sweet if they could use that and carry the corridor all the way to the nearest town and shopping area.

There is no bus system so my idea is for a bus system in my area.  I live in a suburbs of a small town and there is no bus out here.  It would be nice to have one.  Sometimes I don't have access to a car and maybe this bus could help me get to the store or church.  I would also like the bus system to be able to take me to the small town to go shopping and stuff.

I think it would be great to have a jitney-type bus that you could hail like a cab directly from the street.  The jitney would be electric powered and follow a specific route.  I think this would be great because I live in a town that has many tourists, but does not have a large population.  It could shuttle tourists to different areas, but the tourists wouldn't have to worry about a specific bus schedule.  The jitney could drive on streets that are not bus-accessible (some of our streets are "old world" and very narrow). There is also some frustration in my town about not having a vibrant night life because of lack of public transportation.  This jitney would allow people to go downtown, especially college students, and have some drinks without worrying about driving.  One of the stops would be the college campus. The jitney would have a very low fair to encourage people not to drink and drive.  This jitney would help downtown businesses and restaurants.

I think for small towns like mine (20,000) we should have a cross between a trolley and a hoverboard. If we took small platforms (about the size of the floor of a train car) and set them up with superconductors to allow levitation, the platforms could move along on enclosed rails and move slowly enough that people can hop on and off at platforms with no danger. The entire system could be above street level. The speed would be about 5 mph with platforms every block.

This might be only useful for some places, but it's better than none.  I think there should be a moving walkway for the most common areas of a town or city.  This way foot traffic can be consistent and the flow high.  Since it's fairly low speed there shouldn't be any injury issues and transferring is as easy as getting off the one walkway and on to another.

There are many back roads and residential routes around my neighborhood, so speed isn't as much of an issue to keep pace with traffic. I'd imagine a fleet of scooters that could be rented cheaply and easily could help residents get around town without much issue.
Horse drawn carriage would rock here in this southwestern mountain town. People would really love it and it would be more reasonable for my area than just your average bus or taxi.

I live in a town right on the ocean and there are many canals here. I think a canoe taxi service would be really convenient and fun. It wouldn't get people to their desired locations super fast but it would allow people to travel leisurely and enjoy the scenery along the way. It would also be really healthy for the people driving the canoes and help them to stay fit.
Using driver-less vehicles as a taxi service around town by allowing residents to reserve a ride at any time by using the town's website.

Monorail through the city! Just like Disneyland, this city-wide system allows you to see the city from a bird's eye! Simply get on at one of the many stations around town and enjoy your ride without stops, traffic or bad weather. The rails above the city means growth can continue without getting in the way of transport, and means you can watch the world below!

I live in a small desert city with a major traffic congestion issue. However, despite the grid layout of the town, there is a diagonal irrigation canal running from the northwest corner to the southeast corner. Currently it has some poorly maintained walking paths, but that's about the extent of its development. Now, in the desert, loss of irrigation water to evaporation under the glaring sun is an issue. I'd propose creating a covered walkway/bike path where solar panels provide protection to the water, as well as pedestrians and cyclists. We could even use that solar energy to create small electric scooter rental/charging booths. It would provide a shortcut - a green highway from one end of town to the other.

From small towns to big cities, public transportation is helping to generate new vitality like never

before. Beautiful, walkable town squares combine residential, retail, office, recreation and public

transportation features to make community living easy. New bus services and light rail extensions

improve mobility and ease congestion. Even the smallest adjustments, like widening sidewalks and

adding bikeways, can provide dramatic impact and value.

Due to the amount of traffic around Tampa and surrounding towns, there is much congestion during rush hours. To help alleviate some of this, I suggest uni-directional bridge to be built that reduce traffic during rush hours. In the morning, the bridge would allow traffic going west towards the base. In the evening, traffic would flow to the east.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. It would be an underground bullet train system that connected major hubs around the city. It would take only minutes to get from one station to the other across town. There would be train systems at each neighborhood of the city, and you could get on an off at any stop in the underground tunnel.You would pay with a chip card so that you wouldn't need to carry cash or change. The bullet trains would be large capacity so that overcrowding of buses would be a thing of the past.

A central hub for a ridesharing service that provides cars for small groups to take to neighboring towns. I live in a rural area, a few minutes from a very small village. The nearest SMALL city is about 30 minutes away, and the nearest decent sized city is almost an hour away. A ridesharing service would make accessing these places much easier, and if the company provided the car (for a fee, of course), those without vehicles could be serviced.

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

My idea would be to use a moving belt (like used in airport terminals) instead of sidewalks to get around my neighborhood. I live is a small town (population about 500), so it would encourage people to drive less to get to destinations that are close to their homes.

This idea would have to be built in a city near a river, or attached to a solar farm because it relies on using naturally produced hydroelectric or solar power. Basically, it's a train on an electrified track, that moves slowly and stops at intervals in a big loop throughout a city. It would make stops the same way buses make stops. If you rode it long enough, you'd wind up at the same stop you got on at.  It relies completely on green energy, no exhaust just some electric motors driving the cars. People would be able to get on and just ride to where they needed to get off, leaving their personal vehicle in a parking area. It could be configured to have small, individual cars maybe fitted with a GPS system so you could tell it where you needed to go and it would get you as close as possible. The main idea is it would be free and the city could tax businesses a small amount for serving their parts of town, just to help pay maintenance costs.

Tampa, FL is one of the largest metro areas in the country without any sort of rail system, and traffic is bad. I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.

I would love to see a commuter rail system in our town, with a downtown hub and then lines extending north to the Wesley Chapel/Lutz area, out to Brandon, and then another line out to the Westshore/Airport area.

I live in a town with a lot of freight trains. A subway system would be nice because it would get us places faster (the town is large in size and spread out over several miles) and be able to bypass the trains, which stop constantly. The subway would run either over the existing trains or under them and run off of cards that were prepaid like the MTAs.

My town is in desparate need of a form of public transportation. Everyone is reliant on a car or scooter. I think they don't have enough need to  warrant a bus route, but I'm in favor of widening the tiny bicycle lanes they have.

Not just in my neighborhood but metro-wide, my city recently established time share bicycles people can rent and ride when they have a short distance to travel. The bikes are all of the same design, having a large sturdy frame painted light blue, three gears (the gear box is inside the rear wheel axle, and LED blinker lights for safety. Necessarily, it's a one-size-fits-all arrangement; there's no way to raise or lower the seat unless you carry your own tools around with you, so if you're a tall person and use one of these bikes you'll be knocking yourself in the chin with your knees.

Bicycles with wheels like trains are placed on rails and whoever is going to the market takes this bsicycle and with little bit of paddling the bicycle can reach the destination. There should be distance system where two bicycles should be impossible to collide.

This is about a single user system. It is similar to a bicycle. But it's does not run on road. It has specific path made only for this vehicle like a railway track. The track has frictionless surface. The bottom of the vehicle is also frictionless. The vehicle does not have round wheels. But instead flat frictionless bottom (but also can be frictionless wheel). Vehicle does not need fuel. First we clips the vehicle to the track manually. We sit and unclip the vehicle from the track and apply some mechanical force just like in the bicycle to move forward. After that the vehicle moves without any force. Because there is no friction.We just sit and relax. When we apply brake, clips is attached the bottom of track and it stops. The track should be spread all across the city. Vehicle is portable. We take it from home or rent from government.

I imagine a type of highway for bicycles where people can use on and off ramps easily to reach their destination. They wont have to worry about cars since its a bike only highway system. it will get people to their destination quicker since they dont have to stop at traffic lights and watch out for pedestrians.

I would like to see a bicycle highway.  It would go the length of regular highways, but be for bikes and pedestrians.  It should be wide enough for fast moving road cyclist, it should have passing lanes, and little road crossings.  There should be frequent on and off ramps.  There should also be many large parking areas.  Ideally it would even lead to public transportation areas with ample bike parking.

I wish we had separate bicycle highways that were enclosed spaces, both heated and cooled for summer/winter. It would be a cheaper mode of transportation. There would be protection to prevent car vs bicycle accident, a major problem in our area. It would also be healthier and exercise for the day during a commute. I picture it being a rounded space that is clear so you can see your surroundings outside.

There are many parts of my area that aren't accessible by foot or bicycle; in order to get from one section of town to another, you have to take a highway, where only motorized vehicles area allowed. This increases automobile and public transit use. By building footpaths or bike paths that bypass the highways, I think that the local government could reduce traffic, and thereby reduce gas consumption and environmental pollution.

I don't anticipate the transportation system changing too much in my area no matter the time frame. I think the car will rule for the next several decades, but I would like the cars to change. They need not be so huge, and would be powered by plug-in type electrical engines. Each home would have a solar array and this would power your home, and your car. A back-up natural gas power plant would help out if it's cloudy for weeks. Cars would be there for longer trips, but I would also like to see normal bicycle travel increase in the small city I live in. People are fat, lazy, and gross. We don't need anymore technology to go 100 yards, just less lazy people.

An electric monorail with a few cars that travel between the shopping center about a mile a way from us through the little downtown and stopping at the regional rail station a mile the other direction from us. It would have 2 or 3 trains that run back and forth all day and night transporting people between those two major zones in our neighborhood, eliminating the need for cars to travel nearby.

I think high-speed tube travel would be great in my city. The tubes could be a system of plastic or rubber tubes that were buried underground. There would be a lot of tube stations downtown, but they would branch off to the outer city and suburbs. These tubes would have pods in them that were propelled by high-pressured air. The pods could be designed to carry one or two people each, and would be shot through the tubes for quick travel to your destination.

The pods could be designed to carry one or two people each, and would be shot through the tubes for quick travel to your destination.
There should be a free bus that runs from several locations (school, downtown, etc) to the train station on a loop all day and weekend. People would be able to hop on and off with ease.

Express subway lines would be nice.  WMATA is a terrible system.  But I'd be happy if we could get some sidewalks and bike lanes in our neighborhood.  A real help would be a circulator bus system for the neighborhoods surrounding our subway station.  The current system runs point to point and doesn't reduce car trips to the grocery store and local mall.

Fully automated system of public transit; similar in function to a subway but smaller and without drivers (more like the automated tram systems used at airports). Probably using driverless car technology so it could utilize existing roadways? You would use a passcard to enter a specialized waiting area, like a covered bus stop, at which the driverless vehicle/tram/etc would stop at and allow entry (only to those allowed into the station; maybe functions like the turnstiles in a subway?). Vehicle would be the size of a small city bus but could connect to some city-run data network to find and avoid traffic stops and slowdowns (and use/switch between already existing bus lanes and subway tracks?). It could have its own roadway/railway too but it would be nice to not have to create something new. It would be more reliable than a bus system, which is rarely on time where I live, but more accessible than a subway/railway, which does not reach enough areas of my city for me to use frequently.

The streetcar would connect to the subway system which would be entirely rebuilt to accommodate new clean stations with solar panels and zero carbon foot print. This would connect with commuter and regional trains that would operate on an hourly scale.

Subways with shorter runs. NYC is filled with unused tunnels and stations. Get them up and running. Also, allow people who use any sort of wheel-based transport, that's not a bus or car, to use the bike lanes.

I would love individual Segway transporters that would go from the house to the transit station.  They would just fit one person and keep them dry.  Only about 1 mile but just far enough in the rain not to walk.  Once at the transit station, the train takes you directly every 5 minutes into the city.

An electric monorail with a few cars that travel between the shopping center about a mile a way from us through the little downtown and stopping at the regional rail station a mile the other direction from us. It would have 2 or 3 trains that run back and forth all day and night transporting people between those two major zones in our neighborhood, eliminating the need for cars to travel nearby.

Monorail through the city! Just like Disneyland, this city-wide system allows you to see the city from a bird's eye! Simply get on at one of the many stations around town and enjoy your ride without stops, traffic or bad weather. The rails above the city means growth can continue without getting in the way of transport, and means you can watch the world below!
We would ride hovercraft to a monorail station. The monorail would take us to work, school, etc.

A new transportation system would include a mono rail system that is built above the streets and sidewalks where pedestrians can move quickly from one side of the city to the next with having to negotiate with traffic. Once you get to your train station destination there will be a system of buses who would be at the train station waiting to take you to a variety of different bus stations. The busses would pick up and drop off and would take you to and from the monorail system.

I would like to see magnet-driven trains that would not only connect all the part of my very spread out city, but also could connect the major cities in the state together. Ideally, these would be largely automated, but with several emergency safety features, like an onboard override cabin and override booths at each station. There would also have to be a central monitoring hub to keep an eye on the system in general, that in the city would likely have to be run underground, but above ground tracks would be possible between most cities, allowing passengers to avoid traffic and enjoy the wonderful views at the same time. Magnetic drive and perhaps even levitation would help with getting passengers around in snow storms, which often disrupt traffic here in the winter.

A station with a tube in the ground with a high speed pod that would shoot me at a quick speed across the city or across the country in a couple hours. It would be faster than an airplane and safer too.

my neighborhood future transportation system will be made up of flying cars. This cars will be able to take off and land like helicopters. There will be no more traffic jams, traffic light, annoying speed limits and harassing cops. People will be able to travel to any part of the world without going through airports and flight connections. There will be new telecommunication and navigation technology that will help the drivers navigate safely without having mid air collisions and also mid air gas stations to refuel the cars.

I would like to see a high speed train connect all the major cities in my state as well as the major cities bordering our state.  I envision this high speed train to have minimal stations.  This would eliminate the need for air travel and long road trips.

A station with a tube in the ground with a high speed pod that would shoot me at a quick speed across the city or across the country in a couple hours. It would be faster than an airplane and safer too.

Our society's population is expanding at a rapid rate. The typical modern day modes of transportation, while convenient, have a few downsides.  Every mean of transportation, with the exception of walking, has costs that come with it.  This ranges from having to pay for the cost of gas to paying the physical price of not getting the proper amount of exercise our bodies where meant to have via walking to our destinations. There is one option that could solve these issues.  Imagine a small grass field, similar to the ones you find at playgrounds, with a small parking lot.  Within this parking lot would be a couple of electric powered cars attached to power stations. These setups would be available every few blocks (about as frequent as modern bus-stops). Within the field beside the cars stations would be stationary work out equipment. These would be modeled after the free-to-use exercise stations in places like China. They would have equipment such as: bench presses, ellipticals, bikes, etc.  All of these would be wired underground to the charging station attached to the cars. The energy created from the movement of each device will directly charge the cars in the station.  Off to the side of each piece of equipment would be a touchscreen. A person can set up an account at their local government buildings, providing a valid driver's license,e-mail address, and credit or debit card number. When signed in, each account can track how much a person exercised and convert it to an 'available miles for usage' number.  This means that the more a person uses this equipment, creating more energy for the cars, the more miles the person would be allowed to use the car for.  This however also means, that prior to using the car they would have to deduct the amount of miles they plan to use from their account.  If the person should go over their allotted miles, they will then be subsequently charged on their provided credit card.  This encourages people to work-out more at these stations, so they can avoid the fees for using the car. This set-up would immensely help those who financially can't afford their own form of transportation, while promoting a healthier lifestyle in a way that could easily fit into our society's demanding everyday regime.

An idea for getting around my city would be public Segways or other riding devices that you could take from station to station and plug back into a machine to charge up.  Obviously, anti-theft measures would have to be in place, but this could be really great in helping people get around.
